pages.title: Warang Citi
pages.text:
{{Infobox Writing system |type=[[Abugida]] |creator=[[Lako Bodra]] |languages=[[Ho language|Ho]] |fam1= original invention |iso15924=Wara |unicode=[https://www.unicode.org/charts/PDF/U118A0.pdf U+118A0–U+118FF]
[https://www.unicode.org/L2/L2012/12118-n4259-warang-citi.pdf Final Accepted Script Proposal] |note=none |altname=Varang Kshiti}} '''Warang Citi''' (also written '''Varang Kshiti''' or '''Barang Kshiti'''; {{Lang-hoc|ğ‘¢¹ğ‘£—ğ‘£ğ‘£œğ‘£Š ğ‘£ğ‘£‚ğ‘£•ğ‘£‚}},{{cite web|last=Everson|first=Michael|authorlink=Michael Everson|title=N4259: Final proposal for encoding the Warang Citi script in the SMP of the UCS|url=https://www.unicode.org/L2/L2012/12118-n4259-warang-citi.pdf|date=2012-04-19|accessdate=2016-08-20}} IPA: /wÉrÉÅ‹ Ê§ÉªtÌªÉª/) is an [[abugida]] invented by [[Lako Bodra]], used in primary and adult education and in various publications. It is used to write [[Ho language|Ho]], a language used in the Indian states of [[Jharkhand]], [[Odisha]], [[West Bengal]], [[Bihar]], [[Chhattisgarh]] and [[Assam]].{{cite web |last=Ager |first=Simon |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Varang Kshiti alphabet |work= |publisher=Omniglot.com |date= |url=http://www.omniglot.com/writing/varangkshiti.htm |doi= |accessdate= }} Community leader Bodra invented it as an alternative to the writing systems devised by Christian missionaries. He claims that the alphabet was invented in the 13th century by Deowan Turi, and that it was rediscovered in a shamanistic vision and modernized by Lako Bodra. The script begins with the letter [[Ong (letter)|Ong]], the first sound for the [[Creation myth|creation]] of the [[universe]] and has 32 letters in total with capital and small letters. It is written from [[left to right]] in [[horizontal line]]s, and each [[consonant]] has an [[inherent vowel]], usually [[/a/]] but sometimes [[/o/]] or [[/e/]]. Warang Citi uses its own set of digits. It has mainly gained acceptance among the easternmost group of speakers and is more prevalent among those who have been educated in it. Many other speakers prefer oral transmission of knowledge, Devanagari, or even Latin, but it holds prestige among many Ho speakers. ==Characters== It is classified formally as an abugida, but it has many features of a proper alphabet. It follows capitalization rules as are done in English and follows English punctuation. Vowels are added after consonants like in alphabets, but consonants may have the inherent vowel that is present in most Indic languages, so it is ambiguous. There are few ligatures that combine to form new sounds, and there are conjunct consonants that are used as well by stacking in some cases. ==Unicode== {{Main article|Warang Citi (Unicode block)}} Warang Citi was added to the [[Unicode]] Standard in June 2014 with the release of version 7.0. The Unicode block for Warang Citi is U+118A0–U+118FF. Grey areas indicate non-assigned code points: {{Unicode chart Warang Citi}} ==References== {{list of writing systems}} [[Category:Alphabets]] [[Category:Munda scripts]] [[Category:Scripts encoded in Unicode 7.0]] [[Category:Ho language]] {{writingsystem-stub}} {{austroasiatic-lang-stub}}

pages.title: Zaghawa script
pages.text:
[[File:Beria Giray Erfe.png|thumb|400px|The upper-case (left) and lower-case (right) letter pairs of the Zaghawa also known as Beria alphabet. Alphabetic order follows the Latin: {{IPA|/a b d É› f É¡ h~Ä§ Éª Ê’ k l m n É² Å‹ É” p É¾~r s Êƒ t ÊŠ w j/}}.]]
The '''Zaghawa''' or '''Beria script''', ''Beria Giray Erfe'' ('Zaghawa Writing Marks'), is an indigenous [[alphabet]]ic script proposed for the [[Zaghawa language|Zaghawa]] language (also known as Beria) of [[Darfur]] and [[Chad]].

In the 1950s, a Sudanese Zaghawa schoolteacher named Adam Tajir created an alphabet for the Zaghawa language, sometimes known as the '''camel alphabet''', deriving its glyphs from the clan [[Livestock branding|brand]]s used for [[camel]]s and other livestock.  He copied the inventory of the [[Arabic script]], so the system was not ideal for Zaghawa.

In 2000, a Zaghawa veterinarian named Siddick Adam Issa adapted Tajir's script to a form which has proven popular in the Zaghawa community. The typography is somewhat innovative in that capital letters have [[descender]]s which drop ''below'' the baseline of the lower-case letters and punctuation, contrasting with the capital letters which rise above most lower-case letters in the Latin alphabet. ''Beria Giray Erfe'' is a full alphabet, with independent letters for vowels; however, [[diacritic]]s are used to mark tone ([[grave accent]] for [[falling tone]] and [[acute accent]] for [[rising tone]]; high, mid, and low tone are unmarked), as well as [[advanced tongue root]] vowels (a [[Macron (diacritic)|macron]] derives {{IPA|/i e É™ o u/}} from the letters for {{IPA|/Éª É› a É” ÊŠ/}}).

The letter for {{IPA|/p/}}, which does not occur in Zaghawa or in Arabic, is written by adding a tail to the letter for {{IPA|/b/}}; and {{IPA|/Êƒ/}} is derived from the letter for {{IPA|/s/}} with a cross stroke. There apparently is no letter for {{IPA|/Ä§/}}, nor a distinction between {{IPA|/É¾/}} and {{IPA|/r/}}, both of which have been reported for Zaghawa.

European numerals and punctuation are used.

==External links==

*[https://www.unicode.org/L2/L2008/08265-beria-branding.pdf Preliminary proposal to encode Beria Giray Erfe] in Unicode (2008)

'''Chocolate letters''' are a form of candy associated with the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] holiday of [[Sinterklaas]] (Saint Nicholas).  Celebrants of the Sinterklaas celebration are traditionally given their initials made out of chocolate, either on Sinterklaas Eve, which is the fifth of December each year, or during the morning on Sinterklaas Day, which is the sixth day of December. Various sizes, types and flavours are available.

In order to use the same amount of chocolate for each letter the manufacturer varies the thickness of the letter. This way one letter is not favoured over another, for example, with wide letters such as the '''W''' or the '''M''' getting more chocolate than narrow letters such as '''I''' or the '''J'''.  Instead, the wide letters are made with a thinner layer of chocolate, and the narrow letters get a thicker layer of chocolate.

An often used [[typeface]] is [[Egyptienne (typeface)|Egyptienne]].<ref name="Chocolate letter font">{{cite web|title=Dutch Chocolate Letters Explained!|url=http://dutchcommunity.com/2012/10/17/dutch-chocolate-letters-explained/|publisher=Dutch Community|accessdate=February 11, 2014}}</ref>

pages.text:
{{other uses|Aleph (disambiguation)|Alef (disambiguation)}} {{Phoenician glyph|letname=Alef|nextlink=Bet (letter)|nextletter=Bet|arrowleft= |archar=Ø§|sychar=Ü|hechar=×|amchar=aleph|gechar=áŠ |phchar=aleph|grchar=Î‘|lachar=A|cychar=Ğ|ipa=Ê”, a|num=1|gem=1}} '''Aleph''' (or '''alef''' or '''alif''') is the first [[Letter (alphabet)|letter]] of the [[Semitic abjads]], including [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician]] 'Ä€lep ğ¤€, [[Hebrew alphabet|Hebrew]] 'Ä€lef {{lang|he|×}}, [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]] Ä€lap ğ¡€, [[Syriac alphabet|Syriac]] Ê¾Ä€lapÌ„ {{lang|syr|Ü}}, [[Arabic alphabet|Arabic]] {{transl|ar|ALA|Alif}} {{lang|ar|Ø§}} and [[Urdu alphabet|Urdu]] {{transl|ar|ALA|Alif}} {{lang|ar|Ø§}}. It also appears as [[Ancient South Arabian script|South Arabian]] ğ©±, and [[Ge'ez script|Ge'ez]] Ê¾Ã„lef áŠ . These letters are believed to have derived from an [[Egyptian hieroglyph]] depicting an ox's head.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/521235.stm|title=Oldest alphabet found in Egypt|work=BBC News |date=November 15, 1999}} The Phoenician variant gave rise to the [[Alpha (letter)|Greek Alpha]] (Î‘), being re-interpreted to express not the [[glottal consonant]] but the accompanying [[vowel]], and hence the [[A|Latin A]] and [[A (Cyrillic)|Cyrillic Ğ]]. In [[phonetics]], aleph {{IPAc-en|Ëˆ|É‘Ë|l|É›|f}} originally represented the onset of a vowel at the [[glottis]]. In Semitic languages, this functions as a weak consonant allowing roots with only two true consonants to be conjugated in the manner of a standard three consonant Semitic root. In most Hebrew dialects as well as Syriac, the glottal onset represented by Aleph is an absence of a true consonant although a [[glottal stop]] ({{IPAblink|Ê”}}), which is a true consonant, typically occurs as an allophone. In Arabic, the Alif has the glottal stop pronunciation when occurring initially. In text with diacritical marks, the pronunciation as a glottal stop is usually indicated by a special marking, [[hamza]] in Arabic and [[mappiq]] in Tiberian Hebrew. (Although once thought to be the original pronunciation of Aleph in all cases where it behaves as a consonant, a consistent glottal stop appears to have been absent in ancient Semitic languages such as Akkadian and Ugaritic besides being absent in Syriac and Hebrew.) Occasionally, the Aleph was also used to indicate an initial unstressed vowel before certain consonant clusters, without functioning as a consonant itself, the ''[[Prothesis (linguistics)|prosthetic (or prothetic)]] aleph''. In later Semitic languages, Aleph could sometimes function as a ''[[mater lectionis]]'' indicating the presence of a vowel elsewhere (usually long). The period at which use as a mater lectionis began is the subject of some controversy, though it had become well established by the late stage of Old Aramaic (ca. 200 BCE). Aleph is often [[transliteration|transliterated]] as {{unichar|02BE}}, based on the Greek ''[[spiritus lenis]]'' {{lang|grc|Ê¼}}, for example, in the transliteration of the letter name itself, ''{{transl|sem|Ê¾Äleph}}''.{{cite book|last1=Andersen|first1=F.I.|last2=Freedman|first2=D.N.|title=Studies in Hebrew and Aramaic Orthography|date=1992|publisher=Eisenbrauns|location=Winona Lake, Indiana|pages=79â€“90|chapter=Aleph as a vowel in Old Aramaic}} ==Origin== The name ''aleph'' is derived from the West Semitic word for "[[ox]]", and the shape of the letter derives from a [[Proto-Sinaitic]] glyph that may have been based on an [[Egyptian hieroglyphs|Egyptian hieroglyph]] F1 , which depicts an ox's head.{{cite web|url=http://blog.dictionary.com/e/a/|title=Meet The Animal That Inspired The Letter A|work=Everything After Z |publisher=Dictionary.com |accessdate=2019-05-05}} {| class=wikitable style="text-align: center;" |- ! [[Egyptian hieroglyphs|Hieroglyph]] ! [[Proto-Sinaitic script|Proto-Sinaitic]] ! [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician]] ! [[Paleo-Hebrew alphabet|Paleo-Hebrew]] |- | align="center" | F1 | align="center" | [[Image:Proto-Canaanite - aleph.png|Aleph]] | align="center" | [[Image:phoenician aleph.svg|20px|Aleph]] | align="center" | [[Image:Early Aramaic character - Alaph.png|55px|Aleph]] |} In [[Modern Standard Arabic]], the word {{lang|ar|Ø£Ù„ÙŠÙ}} {{IPA|/Ê”aliËf/}} literally means 'tamed' or 'familiar', derived from the root {{IPA|{{!}}Ê”-l-f{{!}}}}, from which the verb Ø£Ù„ÙÙ {{IPA|/Ê”alifa/}} means 'to be acquainted with; to be on intimate terms with'.{{cite book|last=Wehr|first=Hans|title=A Dictionary of Modern Written Arabic: (Arabic-English)|year=1994|publisher=Spoken Language Services|location=Urbana|isbn=0879500034|pages=28â€“29|edition=4th|authorlink=Hans Wehr}} In modern Hebrew, the same root {{IPA|{{!}}Ê”-l-p{{!}}}} (alef-lamed-peh) gives ''meâ€™ulaf'', the passive participle of the verb ''leâ€™alef'', meaning 'trained' (when referring to pets) or 'tamed' (when referring to wild animals); the [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]] rank of [[Aluf]], taken from an [[Edom]]ite title of nobility, is also cognate.{{clarify|date=October 2011}} ==Arabic== Written as {{lang|ar|Ø§}}, spelled as {{lang|ar|Ø£Ù„Ù}} and transliterated as ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}'', it is the first letter in [[Arabic alphabet|Arabic]]. Together with Hebrew Aleph, Greek [[Alpha (letter)|Alpha]] and Latin [[A]], it is descended from [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician]] {{transl|sem|Ê¾Äleph}}, from a reconstructed Proto-Canaanite ''{{transl|sem|Ê¾alp}}'' "ox". Alif is written in one of the following ways depending on its position in the word: {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Ø§}} ===Arabic variants=== ====Alif with hamza: {{big|Ø£}} and {{big|Ø¥}}==== {{Main|Hamza}} {{anchor|hamzat qaá¹­â€˜|hamzat qaá¹­`|hamzat qaá¹­}} The Arabic letter was used to render either a long {{IPA|/aË/}} or a [[glottal stop]] {{IPA|/Ê”/}}. That led to [[orthographical]] confusion and to the introduction of the additional letter ''{{transl|ar|ALA|hamzat qaá¹­â€˜}}'' {{lang|ar|ïº€}}. [[Hamzah|Hamza]] is not considered a full letter in Arabic orthography: in most cases, it appears on a carrier, either a ''{{transl|ar|ALA|wÄw}}'' ({{lang|ar|Ø¤}}), a dotless ''{{transl|ar|ALA|yÄâ€™}}'' ({{lang|ar|Ø¦}}), or an alif. The choice of carrier depends on complicated orthographic rules. Alif {{lang|ar|Ø¥ Ø£}} is generally the carrier if the only adjacent vowel is ''{{transl|ar|ALA|fatá¸¥ah}}''. It is the only possible carrier if hamza is the first phoneme of a word. Where alif acts as a carrier for hamza, hamza is added above the alif, or, for initial alif-''{{transl|ar|ALA|kasrah}}'', below it and indicates that the letter so modified is indeed a glottal stop, not a long vowel. {{anchor|hamzat waá¹£l|hamzat wasl}} A second type of hamza, ''{{transl|ar|ALA|hamzat waá¹£l}}'' ({{lang|ar|Ù‡Ù…Ø²Ø© ÙˆØµÙ„}}), occurs only as the initial phoneme of the [[Al-|definite article]] and in some related cases. It differs from ''{{transl|ar|ALA|hamzat qaá¹­â€˜}}'' in that it is elided after a preceding vowel. Again, alif is always the carrier. ====Alif maddah: {{big|Ø¢}}==== {{anchor|alif maddah|alif madda}} The ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif [[Arabic diacritics#Maddah|maddah]]}}'' is a double alif, expressing both a glottal stop and a long vowel. Essentially, it is the same as a {{lang|ar|Ø£Ø§}} sequence: {{lang|ar|Ø¢}} (final {{lang|ar|Ù€Ø¢}}) {{transl|ar|ALA|â€™Ä}} {{IPA|/Ê”aË/}}, for example in {{lang|ar|Ø¢Ø®Ø±}} ''{{transl|ar|ALA|Äkhir}}'' {{IPA|/Ê”aËxir/}} 'last'. "It has become standard for a ''hamza'' followed by a long Ä to be written as two ''alifs'', one vertical and one horizontal"{{cite book |last=Jones |first=Alan |title=Arabic Through The Qur'an |location=Cambridge |publisher=The Islamic Texts Society |year=2005 |page=4 |isbn=0946621 68 3 }} (the "horizontal" alif being the ''maddah'' sign). ====Alif maqá¹£Å«rah: {{big|Ù‰}}==== {{Anchor|alifmaqsura}}The ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif maqá¹£Å«rah}}'' ({{lang|ar|Ø£Ù„Ù Ù…Ù‚ØµÙˆØ±Ø©}}, 'limited/restricted alif'), commonly known in Egypt as ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif layyinah}}'' ({{lang|ar|Ø£Ù„Ù Ù„ÙŠÙ†Ø©}}, 'flexible alif'), looks like a dotless [[ya'|{{transl|ar|ALA|yÄâ€™}}]] {{lang|ar|Ù‰}} (final {{lang|ar|Ù€Ù‰}}) and may appear only at the end of a word. Although it looks different from a regular ''alif'', it represents the same sound {{IPA|/aË/}}, often realized as a short vowel. When it is written, ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif maqá¹£Å«rah}}'' is indistinguishable from final [[Persian alphabet|Persian]] ''[[Yodh#Perso-Arabic ye|ye]]'' or Arabic ''{{transl|ar|ALA|yÄâ€™}}'' as it is written in Egypt, Sudan and sometimes elsewhere. ''{{transl|ar|ALA|Alif maqsurah}}'' is transliterated as {{transl|ar|ALA|Ã¡}} in [[ALA-LC Romanization|ALA-LC]], {{transl|ar|DIN|Ä}} in [[DIN 31635]], {{transl|ar|ISO|Ã }} in ISO 233-2, and {{transl|ar|ISO|á»³}} in [[ISO 233]]. ===Numeral=== As a numeral, Alaph/Olaf stands for the number one. With a dot below, it is the number 1,000; with a line above it, Alaph/Olaf will represent 1,000,000. With a line below it is 10,000 and with two dots below it is 10,000,000. ==Aramaic== The Aramaic reflex of the letter is conventionally represented with the Hebrew {{lang|he|×}} in typography for convenience, but the actual graphic form varied significantly over the long history and wide geographic extent of the language. Maraqten identifies three different aleph traditions in East Arabian coins, a lapidary Aramaic form that realizes it as a combination of a V-shape and a straight stroke attached to the apex, much like a Latin K; a [[cursive]] Aramaic form he calls the "elaborated X-form", essentially the same tradition as the Hebrew [[Linguistic reconstruction|reflex]]; and an extremely cursive form with of two crossed oblique lines, much like a simple Latin X.{{cite journal|last=Maraqten|first=Mohammed|title=Notes on the Aramaic script of some coins from East Arabia|journal=[[Arabian Archaeology and Epigraphy]]|year=1996|volume=7|pages=304â€“315|url=https://www.academia.edu/1556846/Notes_on_the_Aramaic_script_of_some_coins_from_East_Arabia}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" ! Cursive Aramaic ! Lapidary Aramaic |- | align="center" | [[Image:Aleph.svg| 20 px]] | align="center" | [[Image:Lapidary Aramaic alef.png|20px|Lapidary aleph]] |} ==Hebrew== It is written as {{lang|he|×}} and spelled as {{lang|he|×Ö¸×œÖ¶×£}} In [[Modern Hebrew|Modern Israeli Hebrew]], the letter either represents a [[glottal stop]] ({{IPAblink|Ê”}}) or indicates a [[Hiatus (linguistics)|hiatus]] (the separation of two adjacent [[vowels]] into distinct [[syllable]]s, with no intervening [[consonant]]). It is sometimes silent (word-finally always, word-medially sometimes: {{Hebrew|×”×•Ö¼×}} {{IPA|[hu]}} "he", {{Hebrew|×¨Ö¸××©Ö´××™}} {{IPA|[ÊaËˆÊƒi]}} "main", {{Hebrew|×¨Ö¹××©×}} {{IPA|[ÊoÊƒ]}} "head", {{Hebrew|×¨Ö´××©××•Ö¹×Ÿ}} {{IPA|[ÊiËˆÊƒon]}} "first"). The pronunciation varies in different [[Jewish ethnic divisions]]. In [[gematria]], aleph represents the number 1, and when used at the beginning of [[Hebrew calendar|Hebrew years]], it means 1000 (e.g. {{Hebrew|×'×ª×©× "×“}} in [[Arabic numerals|numbers]] would be the Hebrew [[Calendar date|date]] 1754, not to be confused with 1754 CE). Aleph, along with [[Ayin]], [[Resh]], and [[Heth (letter)|Heth]], cannot receive a [[dagesh]]. (However, there are few very rare examples of the [[Masoretes]] adding a dagesh or [[mappiq]] to an Aleph or Resh. The verses of [[the Hebrew Bible]] for which an Aleph with a mappiq or dagesh appears are [[Book of Genesis|Genesis]] 43:26, [[Leviticus]] 23:17, [[Book of Job|Job]] 33:21 and [[Ezra]] 8:18.) In Modern Hebrew, the frequency of the usage of alef, out of all the letters, is 4.94%. Aleph is sometimes used as a [[mater lectionis]] to denote a vowel, usually {{IPA|/a/}}. That use is more common in words of [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]] and [[Arabic language|Arabic]] origin, in foreign names, and some other borrowed words. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! colspan="5" |[[Orthography|Orthographic]] variants |- ! colspan="3" |Various Print Fonts ! rowspan="2" |[[Cursive Hebrew|Cursive
Hebrew]] ! rowspan="2" |[[Rashi Script|Rashi
Script]] |- !|[[Serif]] !! [[Sans-serif]] !! [[Monospaced font|Monospaced]] |- | width="20%" |× | width="20%" |× | width="20%" |× | width="20%" |[[File:Hebrew letter Alef handwriting.svg|18px]] | width="20%" |[[File:Hebrew letter Alef Rashi.png|31px]] |} ===Rabbinic Judaism=== Aleph is the subject of a [[midrash]] that praises its humility in not demanding to start the Bible. (In [[Hebrew]], the Bible begins with the second letter of the [[alphabet]], [[Bet (letter)|Bet]].) In this folktale, Aleph is rewarded by being allowed to start the [[Ten Commandments]]. (In [[Hebrew]], the first word is {{Hebrew|×Ö¸× Ö¹×›Ö´×™}}, which starts with an aleph.) In the [[Sefer Yetzirah]], the [[letter (alphabet)|letter]] aleph is [[king]] over breath, formed air in the universe, temperate in the year, and the [[chest]] in the soul. Aleph is also the first letter of the [[Hebrew]] word ''emet'' ({{Hebrew|×Ö¶×Ö¶×ª}}), which means ''truth''. In [[Jewish mythology]], it was the letter aleph that was carved into the head of the [[golem]] that ultimately gave it life. Aleph also begins the three words that make up God's mystical name in [[Book of Exodus|Exodus]], [[I Am that I Am|I Am who I Am]] (in [[Hebrew]], Ehyeh Asher Ehyeh {{lang|he|××”×™×” ××©×¨ ××”×™×”}}), and aleph is an important part of mystical [[amulet]]s and formulas. Aleph, in [[Jewish mysticism]], represents the oneness of God. The letter can be seen as being composed of an upper yud ([[Yodh]]), a lower yud, and a vav ([[Waw (letter)]]) leaning on a diagonal. The upper yud represents the hidden and ineffable aspects of God while the lower yud represents God's revelation and presence in the world. The vav ("hook") connects the two realms. Jewish mysticism relates aleph to the element of air, the Fool (Key 0, value 1) of the major arcana of the tarot deck,{{cite web|url=http://tarotjourney.net/tarot-cards/major-arcana/1-the-magician/|title=Tarot Journey with Leisa ReFalo|work=tarotjourney.net|access-date=2010-06-21|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100704205215/http://tarotjourney.net/tarot-cards/major-arcana/1-the-magician/|archive-date=2010-07-04|dead-url=yes|df=}} and the Scintillating Intelligence (#11) of the path between Kether and Chokmah in the Tree of the Sephiroth. ===Yiddish=== In [[Yiddish]],{{cite book|last=Weinreich|first=Uriel|date=1992|title=College Yiddish|location=New York|publisher=[[YIVO]] Institute for Jewish Research|page=25â€“8|author-link=Uriel Weinreich}} aleph is used for several orthographic purposes in native words, usually with different [[diacritical mark]]s borrowed from Hebrew [[niqqud]]: * With no diacritics, aleph is silent; it is written at the beginning of words before vowels spelled with the letter [[Waw (letter)|vov]] or [[yodh|yud]]. For instance, ''oykh'' 'also' is spelled ××•×™×š. The [[digraph (orthography)|digraph]] ×•×™ represents the initial [[diphthong]] [{{IPA|oj}}], but that digraph is not permitted at the beginning of a word in Yiddish orthography, so it is preceded by a silent aleph. Some publications use a silent aleph adjecent to such vowels in the middle of a word as well when necessary to avoid ambiguity. * An aleph with the diacritic ''[[patach|pasekh]]'', ×Ö·, represents the vowel {{IPAblink|a}} in standard Yiddish. * An aleph with the diacritic ''[[kamatz|komets]]'', ×Ö¸, represents the vowel {{IPAblink|É”}} in standard Yiddish. [[Loanword]]s from Hebrew or Aramaic in Yiddish are spelled as they are in their language of origin. ===Mathematics=== In [[set theory]], the Hebrew aleph glyph is used as the symbol to denote the [[aleph number]]s, which represent the [[cardinality]] of infinite sets. This notation was introduced by mathematician [[Georg Cantor]]. In older mathematics books, the letter aleph is often printed upside down by accident, partly because a [[Monotype Imaging|Monotype]] matrix for aleph was mistakenly constructed the wrong way up.{{citation|mr=0553111 |last1=Swanson |first1=Ellen |first2=Arlene Ann |last2=O'Sean |first3=Antoinette Tingley |last3=Schleyer |title=Mathematics into type. Copy editing and proofreading of mathematics for editorial assistants and authors |edition=updated |publisher=American Mathematical Society |place= Providence, R.I. |year=1999 |origyear= 1979 |isbn=0-8218-0053-1 |page=16}} ==Syriac Alaph/Olaf== {| class="wikitable" |- !''Alaph'' |- | [[File:Syriac Eastern alap.svg|45px]] ''Madná¸«aya'' Alap |- | [[File:Syriac Serta alap.svg|45px]] ''Será¹­o'' Olaph |- | [[File:Syriac Estrangela alap.svg|45px]] ''Esá¹­rangela'' Alap |} [[File:Syriac letter shapes Alaph.PNG|500px]] In the [[Syriac alphabet]], the first letter is {{lang|syr|Ü}}, {{lang-syc|ÜÜµÜ Ü²Ü¦}}, Alap (in eastern dialects) or Olaph (in western dialects). It is used in word-initial position to mark a word beginning with a vowel, but some words beginning with ''i'' or ''u'' do not need its help, and sometimes, an initial Alap/Olaph is [[elision|elided]]. For example, when the Syriac [[grammatical person|first-person]] [[grammatical number|singular]] [[pronoun]] {{lang|syc|ÜÜµÜ¢ÜµÜ}} is in [[clitic|enclitic]] positions, it is pronounced ''no/na'' (again west/east), rather than the full form ''eno/ana''. The letter occurs very regularly at the end of words, where it represents the long final vowels ''o/a'' or ''e''. In the middle of the word, the letter represents either a [[glottal stop]] between vowels (but West Syriac pronunciation often makes it a [[palatal approximant]]), a long ''i/e'' (less commonly ''o/a'') or is silent. == South Arabian/Ge'ez == In the [[Ancient South Arabian script|Ancient South Arabian alphabet]], ğ©± appears as the seventeenth letter of the South Arabian abjad. The letter is used to render a [[glottal stop]] {{IPA|/Ê”/}}. In the [[Ge'ez script|Ge'ez alphabet]], Ê¾Ã„lef áŠ  appears as the thirteenth letter of its abjad. This letter is also used to render a glottal stop {{IPA|/Ê”/}}. {| class="wikitable" !South Arabian !Ge'ez |- |{{Huge|ğ©±|300%}} |{{Huge|áŠ |300%}} |} ==Ancient Egyptian== {{see|Transliteration of Ancient Egyptian}} {{Hiero|"Aleph" | A |align=right|era=egypt}} The Egyptian "[[Egyptian vulture#In culture|vulture]]" [[hieroglyph]] ([[Gardiner's sign list|Gardiner]] [[Vulture (hieroglyph)|G1]]), by convention pronounced {{IPA|[a]}}) is also referred to as ''aleph'', on grounds that it has traditionally been taken to represent a [[glottal stop]], although some recent suggestions{{cite journal |last=Schneider |first=Thomas |year=2003 |title=Etymologische Methode, die HistorizitÃ¤t der Phoneme und das Ã¤gyptologische Transkriptionsalphabet |journal=Lingua aegyptia: Journal of Egyptian Language Studies |issue=11 |pages=187â€“199}} tend towards an alveolar approximant ({{IPAblink|É¹}}) sound instead. Despite the name it does not correspond to an Aleph in cognate Semitic words, where instead the single "reed" hieroglyph is found instead. The [[phoneme]] is commonly [[transliterated]] by a symbol composed of two half-rings, in [[Unicode]] (as of version 5.1, in the [[Latin Extended-D]] range) encoded at U+A722 êœ¢ LATIN CAPITAL LETTER EGYPTOLOGICAL ALEF and U+A723 êœ£ LATIN SMALL LETTER EGYPTOLOGICAL ALEF. A fallback representation is the numeral ''3'', or the Middle English character ''È'' [[Yogh#In Egyptology|Yogh]]; neither are to be preferred to the genuine Egyptological characters. ==Character encodings== {{charmap |05D0|name1=Hebrew Letter Alef |0627|name2=Arabic Letter Alif |0710|name3=Syriac Letter Alaph |0800|name4=Samaritan Letter Alaf |10380|name5=Ugaritic Letter Alpa |10900|name6=Phoenician Letter Alf |2135|name7=Alef symbol }} ==See also== * [[Modifier letter right half ring|Ê¾]] * [[Al-]] * [[Aleph number]] * [[YÄÊ¼|Arabic yÄÊ¼]] * "[[The Aleph (short story)|The Aleph]]", a short story by [[Jorge Luis Borges]] describing a point in space that contains all other spaces at once * [[Hamza]]h * [[Aleph (novel)]] ==References== *{{cite web|title=The Letter Aleph (×) |url=https://hebrewtoday.com/alphabet/the-letter-alef-%d7%90/ |website=Hebrew Today |accessdate=2019-05-05}} {{Commonscat|Aleph (letter)}} {{Reflist}} {{Arabic language}} {{Hebrew language}} {{Northwest Semitic abjad}} [[Category:Phoenician alphabet]] [[Category:Arabic letters|Alef]] [[Category:Hebrew alphabet]] [[Category:Vowel letters]]

pages.title: Ayin
pages.text:
{{short description|Sixteenth letter of many Semitic alphabets}} {{about|the Semitic letter}} {{Phoenician glyph |letname=Ayin |previouslink=Samekh |previousletter=Samekh |nextlink=Pe (letter) |nextletter=Pe |archar=Ø¹ |sychar=Ü¥ |hechar= ×¢ |amchar=ayin |gechar=á‹|phchar=ayin|grchar=ÎŸ|lachar=O|cychar=Ğ|ipa=[[Ê•]] |num=16 |gem=70 (no numeric value in Maltese) |maltchar=gÄ§ }} '''''Ayin''''' (also '''''ayn''''' or '''''ain'''''; transliterated {{angle bracket|{{lang|sem|Ê¿}}}}) is the sixteenth [[Letter (alphabet)|letter]] of the [[Semitic abjads]], including [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician]] {{transl|sem|Ê¿ayin}} [[File:Phoenician_ayin.svg|10px]], [[Hebrew alphabet|Hebrew]] {{transl|sem|Ê¿ayin}} {{Hebrew|×¢}}, [[Aramaic alphabet|Aramaic]] {{transl|sem|Ê¿Ä“}} [[File:Ayin.svg| 10 px]], [[Syriac alphabet|Syriac]] {{transl|sem|Ê¿Ä“}} Ü¥, and [[Arabic alphabet|Arabic]] {{transl|sem|Ê¿ayn}} {{lang|ar|Ø¹|rtl=yes}} (where it is sixteenth in [[Abjad numerals|abjadi order]] only).{{NoteTag|{{lang|ar|ï»‰}} comes eighteenth in the [[Arabic alphabet#Alphabetical order|hijaÊ¾i order]] of Arabic and twentyâ€first in the [[Persian alphabet]].}} The letter represents or is used to represent a [[voiced pharyngeal fricative]] ({{IPAslink|Ê•}}) or a similarly articulated consonant. In some Semitic languages and dialects, the phonetic value of the letter has changed, or the phoneme has been lost altogether (thus, in [[Modern Hebrew]] it is reduced to a [[glottal stop]] or is omitted entirely). The Phoenician letter is the origin of the Greek, Latin and Cyrillic letter [[O]]. ==Origins== The letter name is derived from [[Proto-Semitic]] {{transl|sem|[[:wikt:Appendix:Proto-Semitic *Ê¿ayn-|*Ê¿ayn-]]}} "eye", and the Phoenician letter had the shape of a circle or oval, clearly representing an eye, perhaps ultimately (via [[Proto-Sinaitic]]) derived from the ''Ä±Í—r'' [[Egyptian hieroglyphs|hieroglyph]] {{lang|egy|ğ“¹}} ([[Gardiner's sign list#D. Parts of the human body|Gardiner D4]]).Simons, F., "Proto-Sinaitic â€“ Progenitor of the Alphabet" ''Rosetta'' 9 (2011), 16â€“40 (here: 38–40). See also: Goldwasser, Orly (Marâ€“Apr 2010). "How the Alphabet Was Born from Hieroglyphs". ''Biblical Archaeology Review''. Washington, DC: Biblical Archaeology Society. 36 (1), following William F. Albright, ''The Proto-Sinaitic Inscriptions and their Decipherment'' (1966), "Schematic Table of Proto-Sinaitic Characters" ([http://www.apocalypse2008-2015.com/images/Proto-Sinaitic_Table.gif fig. 1]). The Phoenician letter gave rise to the [[Greek alphabet|Greek]] [[Omicron|ÎŸ]], Latin [[O]], and [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]] [[O (Cyrillic)|Ğ]], all representing vowels. The sound represented by ayin is common to much of the [[Afroasiatic languages|Afroasiatic language family]], such as in the [[Egyptian language]], the [[Cushitic languages]] and the [[Semitic languages]]. ==Transliteration== {{see|Semitic romanization}} In [[Semitic studies|Semitic philology]], there is a long-standing tradition of rendering Semitic ayin with Greek [[rough breathing]] the mark ã€ˆÌ”ã€‰ (e.g. {{lang|ar-Latn|[[Arab|̔arab]]}} {{lang|ar|Ø¹ÙØ±ÙØ¨|rtl=yes}}). Depending on typography, this could look similar to either an articulate single opening [[quotation mark]] ã€ˆâ€˜ã€‰ (e.g. {{lang|ar-Latn|[[Arab|â€˜arab]]}} {{lang|ar|Ø¹ÙØ±ÙØ¨|rtl=yes}}). or as a raised semi-circle open to the right ã€ˆÊ¿ã€‰ (e.g. {{lang|ar-Latn|[[Arab|Ê¿arab]]}} {{lang|ar|Ø¹ÙØ±ÙØ¨|rtl=yes}}).{{NoteTag|sometimes rendered as the Greek diacritic in a [[serif]] font (as ã€ˆ̔ã€‰), e.g. [[Carl Brockelmann]]'s ''Grundriss Der Vergleichenden Grammatik der semitischen Sprachen'', 1908; Friedrich Delitzsch , Paul Haupt (eds.), ''BeitrÃ¤ge zur assyriologie und semitischen sprachwissenschaft'' (1890) ([https://archive.org/details/beitrgezurassyr02univgoog 1968 reprint]); sometimes rendered as a semi-circle open to the right with constant line thickness (as ã€ˆÊ¿ã€‰), e.g. [[Theodor NÃ¶ldeke]], ''BeitrÃ¤ge zur semitischen Sprachwissenschaft'' (1904).}} This is by analogy to the transliteration of [[alef]] ([[glottal stop]], [[hamza]]) by the Greek [[smooth breathing]] mark ã€ˆ̓ã€‰, rendered as single closing [[quotation mark]] or as raised semi-circle open to the left. This convention has been adopted by DIN in 1982 and by ISO in 1984 for Arabic ([[DIN 31635]], [[ISO 233]]) and Hebrew ([[DIN 31636]], [[ISO 259]]). The shape of the "raised semi-circle" for ayin (Unicode ã€ˆ{{transl|sem|Ê¿}}ã€‰ U+02BF) and alef (Unicode ã€ˆ{{transl|sem|Ê¾}}ã€‰ U+02BE) was adopted by the ''[[Encyclopedia of Islam]]'' (edited 1913â€“1938, 1954â€“2005, and from 2007), and from there by the ''[[International Journal of Middle East Studies]]''."MES Transliteration System" ([https://assets.cambridge.org/MES/MES_ifc.pdf assets.cambridge.org/MES/MES_ifc.pdf]). This convention has since also been followed by ISO ([[ISO 233-2]] and [[ISO 259-2]], 1993/4) and by DIN{{year needed|date=November 2017}}. A notable exception remains, [[ALA-LC romanization|ALA-LC]] (1991), the system used by the [[Library of Congress]], continues to recommend modifier letter turned comma ã€ˆÊ»ã€‰ or left single quotation mark ã€ˆâ€˜ã€‰.{{clarify|date=November 2017}} The symbols for the corresponding phonemes in the [[International Phonetic Alphabet]], ã€ˆÊ•ã€‰ for [[pharyngeal fricative]] (ayin) and ã€ˆÊ”ã€‰ for [[glottal stop]] (alef) were adopted in the [[History of the International Phonetic Alphabet#1928 revisions|1928 revision]]. In anglicized Arabic or Hebrew names or in loanwords, ayin is often omitted entirely: [[Iraq#Name|Iraq]] {{transl|ar|DIN|'''Ê¿'''irÄq}} {{lang|ar|Ø¹Ø±Ø§Ù‚|rtl=yes}}, [[Arab (etymology)|Arab]] {{transl|ar|DIN|'''Ê¿'''arab}} {{lang|ar|Ø¹Ø±Ø¨|rtl=yes}}, [[House of Saud|Saudi]] {{transl|ar|DIN|sa'''Ê¿'''Å«dÄ«}} {{lang|ar|Ø³Ø¹ÙˆØ¯ÙŠ|rtl=yes}} , etc.; [[Afula]] {{lang|he|×¢Ö²×¤×•Ö¼×œÖ¸×”|rtl=yes}}, [[Arad, Israel|Arad]] {{lang|he| ×¢Ö²×¨Ö¸×“|rtl=yes}}, etc. In Arabic, the presence of ayin in front of ''u'' can sometimes be inferred even if it is not rendered separately, as the vowel quality is shifted towards ''o'' (e.g. [[Oman]] {{lang|ar|Ø¹Ù…Ø§Ù†|rtl=yes}} {{transl|ar|DIN|'''Ê¿U'''mÄn}}, [[Omar (name)|Omar]] {{lang|ar|Ø¹Ù…Ø±|rtl=yes}} {{transl|ar|DIN|'''Ê¿U'''mar}}, etc.) [[Maltese language|Maltese]], which uses a Latin alphabet, the only Semitic language to do so in its [[standard language|standard form]], writes the ayin as ã€ˆ[[gÄ§]]ã€‰. It is usually unvocalized in speech. The [[Somali alphabets|Somali Latin alphabet]] represents the Ê¿ayin with the letter ã€ˆ[[c]]ã€‰. The informal way to represent it in [[Arabic chat alphabet]] uses the digit ã€ˆ3ã€‰ as transliteration. === Unicode === In [[Unicode]], the recommended character for the transliteration of ayin is {{transl|sem|Ê¿}} (U+02BF) "modifier letter left half ring" (a character in the [[Spacing Modifier Letters]] range, even though it is here not used as a modifier letter but as a full grapheme).{{NoteTag|Both characters U+02BE "modifier letter right half ring" and U+02BF "modifier letter left half ring" have been present since Unicode version 1.0.0 (1991). The relevant [https://www.unicode.org/charts/PDF/U02B0.pdf code chart] specifies the purpose of U+02BF as "transliteration of Arabic ain (voiced pharyngeal fricative); transliteration of Hebrew ayin".}} This convention has been adopted by [[ISO 233-2]] (1993) for Arabic and [[ISO 259-2]] (1994) for Hebrew. There are a number of alternative Unicode characters in use, some of which are easily confused or even considered equivalent in practice:"Various small, raised hook- or comma-shaped characters are often substituted for a glottal stopâ€”for instance, U+02BC modifier letter apostrophe, U+02BB modifier letter turned comma, U+02C0 modifier letter glottal stop, or U+02BE modifier letter right half ring. U+02BB, in particular, is used in Hawaiian orthography as the ''okina''." [https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/ec3a/f5a195ca71cd24761e9f486f3de0c79c60a8.pdf The Unicode Standard Version 7.0: chapter 7.1 "Latin", p. 294]. *Ì” (U+0314 {{smallcaps|combining reversed comma above}}), the character recommended to represent Greek [[rough breathing]]), * single opening [[quotation mark]] â€˜ (U+2018),{{NoteTag|1= recommended by the [[Library of Congress]] ([https://www.loc.gov/catdir/cpso/romanization/arabic.pdf loc.gov]); deprecated by [http://www.eromm.org/project/doku.php?id=transliteration:arabisch:listea The European Register of Microform Masters]}} * Ê» (U+02BB {{smallcaps|Modifier letter turned comma}}), * the [[grave accent]] ` U+0060, from its use as single opening quotation mark in [[ASCII]] environments, used for ayin in [[ArabTeX]]. Other variants chosen{{clarify|date=November 2017}} to represent ayin as a full grapheme (rather than a sign suggestive of an apostrophe or a diacritic): * a superscript c (c, or á¶œ U+1D9C {{sc|Modifier letter small C}}), * the [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] symbol for [[pharyngealization]] {{IPA|Ë¤}}, {{IPA|Ë¤}} (U+02C1 {{smallcaps|Modifier letter reversed glottal stop}}, U+02E4 {{smallcaps|Modifier letter small reversed glottal stop}}),{{NoteTag|1=deprecated by [http://www.eromm.org/project/doku.php?id=transliteration:arabisch:listea The European Register of Microform Masters].}} or a superscript {{IPA|Ê•}} (Ê•, U+0295 {{smallcaps|Latin letter pharyngeal voiced fricative}}), the [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] symbol for [[voiced pharyngeal fricative]] . It is worth noting that the phonemes corresponding to alef and ayin in [[Ancient Egyptian language|Ancient Egyptian]] are by convention [[transliteration of Ancient Egyptian|transliterated]] by more distinctive signs: [[Egyptian alef]] is rendered by ''two'' semi-circles open to the left, stacked vertically, and [[Egyptian ayin]] is rendered by a single full-width semi-circle open to the right. These characters were introduced in Unicode in version 5.1 (2008, [[Latin Extended-D]] range), êœ£ U+A723 {{smallcaps|Latin small letter Egyptologican Alef}} and êœ¥ U+A725 {{smallcaps|Latin small letter Egyptologican Ain}}. ==Arabic Ê¿ayn== {{hatnote|Not to be confused with {{lang|ar|[[Ø¡]]|rtl=yes}} (hamzah) looking similar to, and derived from, initial {{lang|ar|Ø¹Ù€|rtl=yes}}}} The Arabic letter {{lang|ar|ï»‰|rtl=yes}} (called {{lang|ar|ï»‹ï»´ï»¦|rtl=yes}} {{transl|ar|DIN|Ê¿ayn}}) is the eighteenth letter of the alphabet. It is written in one of several ways depending on its position in the word: {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Ø¹}} ===Pronunciation=== Arabic Ê¿ayn is one of the most common letters in Arabic. Depending on the region, it ranges from a [[pharyngeal consonant|pharyngeal]] {{IPA|[[[Ê•]]]}} to an [[epiglottal consonant|epiglottal]] {{IPA|[[[Ê¢]]]}}. It is [[voice (phonetics)|voiced]], its unvoiced counterpart being {{lang|ar|[[Ø­]]}}. Due to its position as the innermost letter to emerge from the throat, [[al-Khalil ibn Ahmad al-Farahidi]], who wrote the first Arabic dictionary, actually started writing with {{transl|ar|Ê¿ayn}} as the first letter instead of the eighteenth; he viewed its origins deep down in the throat as a sign that it was the first sound, the essential sound, the voice and a representation of the self.Suzanne Pinckney Stetkevych, ''The Mute Immortals Speak: Pre-Islamic Poetry and the Poetics of Ritual'', pg. 178. Cornell Studies in Political Economy. [[Ithaca, New York]]: [[Cornell University Press]], 1993. {{ISBN|9780801427640}} In the Persian language and other languages using the Persian alphabet, it is pronounced as {{IPAslink|Ê”}} (glottal stop), and rarely as {{IPAslink|Ê}} in some languages. As in Hebrew, the letter originally stood for two sounds, {{IPAslink|Ê•}} and {{IPAslink|Ê}}. When pointing was developed, the sound {{IPAslink|Ê}} was distinguished with a dot on top ({{lang|ar|Øº|rtl=yes}}), to give the letter ''ghayn''. In Maltese, which is written with the Latin alphabet, the digraph [[gÄ§]], called ''Ê¿ajn'', is used to write what was originally the same sound. ==Hebrew Ayin== {|class=wikitable style="text-align:center;" |+[[Orthography|Orthographic]] variants |- !colspan=3|Various print fonts !rowspan=2|[[Cursive Hebrew|Cursive
Hebrew]] !rowspan=2|[[Rashi script|Rashi
script]] |- !|Serif !! [[Sans-serif]] !! [[Monospaced]] |- |width=20%|×¢ |width=20%|×¢ |width=20%|×¢ |width=20%|[[File:Hebrew letter Ayin handwriting.svg|26px]] |width=20%|[[File:Hebrew letter Ayin Rashi.png|40px]] |} Hebrew spelling: {{lang|he|×¢Ö·×™Ö´×Ÿ|rtl=yes}} Ê¿ayin, along with [[Aleph (Hebrew)|Aleph]], [[Resh]], [[He (letter)|He]] and [[Heth (letter)|Heth]], cannot receive a [[dagesh]]. ===Phonetic representation=== Ê¿ayin has traditionally been described as a [[voiced pharyngeal fricative]] ({{IPA|[Ê•]}}). However, this may be imprecise. Although a pharyngeal fricative has occasionally been observed for Ê¿ayin in Arabic and so may occur in Hebrew as well, the sound is more commonly [[voiced epiglottal fricative|epiglottal]] ({{IPAblink|Ê¢}}),Ladefoged, Peter & Ian Maddieson (1996). ''The sounds of the worldâ€™s languages''. Oxford: Blackwells. {{ISBN|0-631-19814-8}} and may also be a [[pharyngealization|pharyngealized]] glottal stop ({{IPA|[Ê”Ë¤]}}). In some historical Sephardi and Ashkenazi pronunciations, Ê¿ayin represented a [[velar nasal]] ({{IPA|[Å‹]}}) (see Shabath, Heskel. â€œRomanization of the Hebrew Alphabet.â€ ProQuest Dissertations Publishing, 1973. http://search.proquest.com/docview/873832382/, p. 179). Remnants can be found in the Yiddish pronunciations of some words such as /ËˆjaÅ‹kÉ™v/ and /ËˆmansÉ™/ from Hebrew {{Hebrew|×™Ö·×¢Ö²×§Ö¹×‘}} (''yaÊ¿ÄƒqÅá¸‡'', "Jacob") and {{Hebrew|×Ö·×¢Ö²×©Ö¶×‚×”}} (''maÊ¿Äƒse'', "story"), but in other cases, the nasal has disappeared and been replaced by /j/, such as /ËˆmajsÉ™/ and /ËˆmajrÉ™v/ from Hebrew {{Hebrew|×Ö·×¢Ö²×©Ö¶×‚×”}} and {{Hebrew|×Ö·×¢Ö²×¨Ö¸×‘}} (''maÊ¿ÄƒrÄá¸‡'', "west"). In Israeli Hebrew (except for Mizrahi pronunciations), it represents a glottal stop in certain cases but is usually silent (it behaves the same as [[Aleph (Hebrew)|aleph]]). However, changes in adjoining vowels often testify to the former presence of a pharyngeal or epiglottal articulation. As well, it may be used as a [[shibboleth]] to identify the social background of a speaker, as [[Arabs]] and some of the [[Mizrahim]] (mainly of [[Yemenite Jews|Yemenite]] origin) use the more traditional pronunciation, while other Hebrew speakers pronounce it similar to Aleph. Ayin is also one of the three letters that can take a furtive [[patach]] {{transl|he|patach ganuv}}). In Hebrew loanwords in Greek and Latin, Ê¿ayin is sometimes reflected as /g/, since the biblical phonemes {{IPAslink|Ê•}} (or "'''Ê¿'''") and {{IPAslink|Ê}} (represented by "g") were both represented in Hebrew writing by the letter Ê¿ayin (see [[Ghain|Ä ain]]). [[Sodom and Gomorrah|Gomorrah]] is from the original {{IPA|/Êamora/}} (modern '''''Ê¿'''Amora'') and [[Gaza City|Gaza]] from the original {{IPA|/Êazza/}} ('''''Ê¿'''aza'') (cf. Arabic ØºØ²Ø© Ä azzah, IPA: [ËˆÉ£azza].) In Yiddish, the Ê¿ayin is used to write the vowel e when it is not part of the [[diphthong]] ''ey''. ===Significance=== In [[gematria]], Ê¿ayin represents the number 70. Ê¿ayin is also one of the seven letters which receive special crowns (called ''[[Tag (Hebrew writing)|tagin]]'') when written in a [[sefer Torah]]. Because the sound is difficult for most non-Arabs to pronounce, it is often used as a shibboleth by Arabic speakers; other sounds, such as [[Heth (letter)|{{transl|ar|á¸¤Ä}}]] and [[á¸ŒÄd|{{transl|ar|á¸ŒÄd}}]] are also used.{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} ==Character encodings== {{charmap |05E2|name1=Hebrew Letter Ayin |FB20|name2=Hebrew Letter

pages.title: Babylonian vocalization
pages.text:
[[File:Bab voc fragment 1.jpg|thumb|400px|[[Ezekiel]] 34:22-25, from a manuscript with Babylonian vocalization from the [[Cairo Geniza]]]] [[File:Bab voc fragment 2.jpg|thumb|A verse-by-verse interlinear Hebrew-Aramaic text of [[Deuteronomy]] 14:4-19 with Babylonian vocalization from the [[Cairo Geniza]]]] The '''Babylonian vocalization''', also known as '''Babylonian supralinear punctuation''', or '''Babylonian pointing''' or '''Babylonian niqqud''' [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]]: {{Hebrew|× Ö´×§Ö¼×•Ö¼×“ ×‘Ö¸Ö¼×‘Ö°×œÖ´×™}}) is a system of [[diacritic]]s ([[niqqud]]) and vowel symbols assigned above the text and devised by the [[Masoretes]] of [[Babylon]] to add to the consonantal text of the [[Hebrew Bible]] to indicate the proper pronunciation of words (vowel quality), reflecting the Hebrew of Babylon. The Babylonian system is no longer in use outside [[Yemenite Jews|Temani Judaism]], having been supplanted by the sublinear [[Tiberian vocalization]]. == History == The simple Babylonian vocalization system was created between the 6th and 7th centuries, while the complex system developed later.{{Harvcoltxt|SÃ¡enz-Badillos|1993|p=98}} There is evidence that Babylonian Hebrew had emerged as a distinct dialect by the end of the 9th century.{{Harvcoltxt|SÃ¡enz-Badillos|1993|p=94}} Babylonian Hebrew reached its peak in the 8th to 9th centuries, being used from Persia to Yemen.{{Harvcoltxt|SÃ¡enz-Badillos|1993|p=103}} Under Muslim hegemony in the 10th century, the main academies disappeared and the Babylonian vocalization was replaced by the [[Tiberian vocalization]]. However, contemporary [[Yemenite Hebrew]] is thought to be the descendant of a variety of Babylonian Hebrew, as represented in the Babylonian system.{{Harvcoltxt|SÃ¡enz-Badillos|1993|p=104}} The first example of the Babylonian vocalization to become known to modern scholars was a codex of the Prophets discovered in 1839 at [[Chufut-Kale]].{{Harvcoltxt|SÃ¡enz-Badillos|1993|p=95}} == Description == The Babylonian vocalization, along with the [[Palestinian vocalization]], are known as the ''supralinear vocalizations'' because they place the vowel graphemes above the consonant letters, rather than both above and below as in the Tiberian system.{{Harvcoltxt|Blau|2010|p=7}} As in the Palestinian vocalization, only the most important vowels are indicated.{{Harvcoltxt|SÃ¡enz-Badillos|1993|p=118}} Two Babylonian systems developed: an earlier ''simple'' (or ''einfach'', ''E'') system, and a later ''complex'' (or ''kompliziert'', ''K'') system.{{Harvcoltxt|SÃ¡enz-Badillos|1993|pp=97â€“98}} The following vowel graphemes were used in the simple system:{{Harvcoltxt|SÃ¡enz-Badillos|1993|p=97}} {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; font-size:250%" height=40 valign=top| [[File:Bab qamats.jpg|35px]] |style="font-family: 'david'; font-size:250%" height=40 valign=top| [[File:Bab tsere.jpg|35px]] |style="font-family: 'david'; font-size:250%" height=40 valign=top| [[File:Bab hirik.jpg|35px]] |style="font-family: 'david'; Shva quiescens (shva nah) is unmarked. The complex system may be subdivided into ''perfect'' and ''imperfect'' systems. The former, unlike the latter, "has special signs for each kind of syllable and uses them consistently." It marks allophones of /a e i u/, consonant gemination, distinguishes vocalic and consonantal × and ×”, and marks shva mobile and quiescens with a single grapheme. A number of manuscripts with features intermediate between Tiberian and Babylonian also exist.{{Harvcoltxt|SÃ¡enz-Badillos|1993|p=99}} Later Yemenite manuscripts, using both simple and complex systems, show Yemenite features such as confusion between patah and shva and between tsere and holam. [[File:Babylonian_Supralinear_Punctuation,_from_Yemenite_Siddur,_April_2015.jpg|thumb|right|Section of Yemenite Siddur, with Babylonian supralinear punctuation (Pirke Avot)]] == Cantillation == The Babylonian system uses [[cantillation]] similarly to the Tiberian system.{{Harvcoltxt|SÃ¡enz-Badillos|1993|pp=100â€“101}} The oldest manuscripts (which use the simple system) mark only disjunctive accents, do not write the accent over the stressed syllable, and do not mark [[mappiq]], while later manuscripts do. ==See also== * [[Tiberian vocalization]] * [[Palestinian vocalization]] * [[Niqqud]] * [[Yemenite Hebrew]] [[File:Siddur - Night of Rosh Hashanah.jpg|thumb|Yemenite Siddur written with Babylonian supralinear punctuation]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} == External links == *[http://jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/2288-babylonian-punctuation Jewish Encyclopedia, treats on subject of Babylonian punctuation, or vocalization] == Bibliography == * {{cite book|last = [[Joshua Blau]]|title = Phonology and Morphology of Biblical Hebrew|year = 2010|publisher = Eisenbrauns|location= Winona Lake, Indiana|isbn=1-57506-129-5|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last=SÃ¡enz-Badillos|first=Angel|title=A History of the Hebrew Language|year=1993|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=0-521-55634-1|ref=harv}} {{Hebrew language}} [[Category:Language of the Hebrew Bible]] [[Category:Hebrew alphabet]]

pages.title: Begadkefat
pages.text:
{{IPA notice}} '''Begadkefat''' (also '''begadkephat''', '''begedkefet''') is the name given to a phenomenon of [[lenition]] affecting the non-[[emphatic consonant|emphatic]] [[stop consonant]]s of [[Biblical Hebrew]] and [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]] when they are preceded by a vowel and not [[gemination|geminated]]. The name is also given to similar cases of spirantization of post-vocalic plosives in other [[language]]s; for instance, in the [[Berber languages|Berber language]] of [[Djerba]].See for instance: [[Werner Vycichl]], "Begadkefat im Berberischen", in: [[James Bynon|James]] and [[Theodora Bynon]] (eds.), ''Hamito-Semitica'', London 1975, pp. 315-317. [[Celtic languages]] have a similar system. The phenomenon is attributed to the following consonants: {|class=wikitable style="white-space:nowrap; text-align:center" !colspan=2|[[Letter (alphabet)|letter]]!!stop!! !![[fricative consonant|fricative]] |- valign="top" |style="border-right-style:none"|[[Bet (letter)|bet]]||style="border-left-style:none"| {{Hebrew|×‘}} {{lang|syr|Ü’}}||{{IPAblink|b}}||becomes||{{IPAblink|v}}
or
{{IPAblink|Î²}} |- valign="top" |style="border-right-style:none"|[[gimel]]||style="border-left-style:none"| {{Hebrew|×’}} {{lang|syr|Ü“}}||{{IPAblink|É¡}}||becomes||{{IPAblink|É£}} |- valign="top" |style="border-right-style:none"|[[dalet]]||style="border-left-style:none"| {{Hebrew|×“}} {{lang|syr|Ü•}}||{{IPAblink|d}}||becomes||{{IPAblink|Ã°}} |- valign="top" |style="border-right-style:none"|[[kaph]]||style="border-left-style:none"| {{Hebrew|×›}} {{lang|syr|ÜŸ}}||{{IPAblink|k}}||becomes||{{IPAblink|x}} ~ {{IPAblink|Ï‡}} |- valign="top" |style="border-right-style:none"|[[Pe (letter)|pe]]||style="border-left-style:none"| {{Hebrew|×¤}} {{lang|syr|Ü¦}}||{{IPAblink|p}}||becomes||{{IPAblink|f}}
or
{{IPAblink|É¸}} |- valign="top" |style="border-right-style:none"|[[taw]]||style="border-left-style:none"| {{Hebrew|×ª}} {{lang|syr|Ü¬}}||{{IPAblink|t}}||becomes||{{IPAblink|Î¸}} |} The name of the phenomenon is made up with these six consonants, mixed with haphazard [[vowel]]s for the sake of pronunciation: BeGaDKePaT. The Hebrew term {{Hebrew|×‘Ö¶Ö¼×’Ö¶×´×“ ×›Ö¶Ö¼×¤Ö¶×´×ª}} ([[Modern Hebrew]] {{IPA|/ËŒbeÉ¡edËˆkefet/}}) denotes the letters themselves (rather than the phenomenon of spirantization). Begedkefet spirantization developed sometime during the lifetime of Biblical Hebrew under the influence of Aramaic.Or perhaps [[Hurrian language|Hurrian]], but this is unlikely, c.f. Dolgoposky 1999, pp. 72-73.{{Citation not found|date=January 2018}} Its time of emergence can be found by noting that the Old Aramaic phonemes {{IPAslink|Î¸}}, {{IPAslink|Ã°}} disappeared in the 7th century BC.Dolgopolsky 1999, p. 72.{{Citation not found|date=January 2018}} It persisted in Hebrew until the 2nd century CE.Dolgopolsky 1999, p. 73.{{Citation not found|date=January 2018}}{{Contradict-inline|article=Semitic languages#Consonants|date=October 2014}} During this period all six plosive / fricative pairs were [[Allophone|allophonic]]. In [[Modern Hebrew]] three of the six letters, {{hebrew|×‘}} (bet), {{hebrew|×›}} (kaf) and {{hebrew|×¤}} (pe) each still denote a [[stop consonant|stop]]â€“[[fricative consonant|fricative]] variant pair; these variants are, however, no longer purely [[allophone|allophonic]] (see [[#In Modern Hebrew|below]]). Although [[Orthography|orthographic]] variants of {{hebrew|×’}} (gimel), {{hebrew|×“}} (dalet) and {{hebrew|×ª}} (tav) still exist, these letters' pronunciation always remains acoustically and phonologically indistinguishable.In modern Hebrew, the letter gimel modified by the diacritic [[geresh]] â€“ ×’×³ â€“ is pronounced as the [[affricate consonant|affricate]] {{IPAblink|dÊ’}}; this, however, denotes a separate [[phoneme]], not connected to the phenomenon of spirantization: compare e.g. ×’×– {{IPA|/'''É¡'''ez/}} ("[[wool|fleece]]") â†â†’ ×’×³×– {{IPA|/'''dÊ’'''ez/}} ("[[jazz]]"); ×—×’ {{IPA|/Ï‡a'''É¡'''/}} ("[[holiday]]") â†â†’ ×—×’×³ {{IPA|/Ï‡a'''dÊ’'''/}} ("the [[Hajj]]"). Conversely, dalet and tav with a geresh â€“ ×“×³ and ×ª×³ â€“ respectively do denote the fricatives {{IPAblink|Ã°}} and {{IPAblink|Î¸}}, however never as sounds in Hebrew words or even [[loanword]]s, but are rather used exclusively for the [[wikt:Hebraize|hebraization]] of foreign language texts or the transliteration of foreign names. Also these modern Hebrew variants have nothing to do with the phenomenon of spirantization. In [[Yiddish]], as well as in [[Ashkenazi Hebrew]] (which was heavily influenced by Yiddish), {{hebrew|×ª}} can denote a fricative variant, {{IPAblink|s}}. ==Orthography== In [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] [[Ktiv menuqad|writing with niqqud]], a dot in the center of one of these letters, called [[dagesh]] ( Ö¼ ), marks the plosive articulation: * at the beginning of a word{{#tag:ref|In Hebrew texts that are not modern, begedkefet letters at the beginning of a word ''preceded by a vowel'' are sometimes written without a dagesh and therefore pronounced as fricatives, e.g. "×Ö²×©Ö¶××¨Ö¾×‘Ö¼×•Ö¹ ×¤Ö°×¨Ö´×™Ö¾×¢Öµ×¥" ({{IPA|/aÊƒer bo '''f'''ri Ê•ets/}}, [[Book of Genesis|Genesis]] 1, 29), but not always â€“ e.g. "×¢Ö¹×©Ö¶×‚×” ×¤Ö°Ö¼×¨Ö´×™" ({{IPA|/Ê•ose '''p'''ri/}}, Genesis 1, 11 and 1, 12).{{bibleref|Gen|1|HE}}, Mechon Mamre. This is governed by the stress and [[cantillation]] mark of the preceding word, but the detailed rules are beyond the scope of this article.|group=note}} or after a consonant (in which cases it is termed "dagesh qal"In modern Hebrew [[ktiv menuqad]], the dagesh qal is marked also in the three begedkefet letters which can no longer denote a fricative variant â€“ [[×’]] ({{IPAblink|É¡}}), [[×“]] ({{IPAblink|d}}) and [[×ª]] ({{IPAblink|t}}) â€“ conserving the [[Masoretes|masoretic]] [[niqqud]] tradition.), * when the sound is â€“ or was historically â€“ [[gemination|geminated]] (in which case it is termed "dagesh áº–azaq", a mark for historical gemination in most other consonants of the language as well), and * in some modern Hebrew words independently of these conditions (see below). A line (similar to a [[Macron (diacritic)|macron]]) placed above it, called "[[rafe]]" ( Ö¿ ), marks in Yiddish (and rarely in Hebrew) the fricative articulation. ==In Modern Hebrew== As mentioned above, the fricative variants of {{IPAblink|É¡}}, {{IPAblink|d}} and {{IPAblink|t}} no longer exist in modern Hebrew. (However, Hebrew ''does'' have the [[guttural R]] consonant {{IPAslink|Ê}} which is the voiced counterpart of {{IPAslink|Ï‡}} and often coincides with [[Mizrahi Hebrew]]'s fricative variant of {{IPAblink|É¡}} á¸¡imel as well as [[Arabic]]'s Øº Ä¡ayn, both of which are {{IPAslink|É£}}~{{IPAslink|Ê}}. Modern Hebrew ×¨ resh can still sporadically be found standing in for this phoneme, for example in the Hebrew rendering of [[Raleb Majadele|Raleb (Ghaleb) Majadele]]'s name.) The three remaining pairs {{IPAslink|b}}~{{IPAslink|v}}, {{IPAslink|k}}~{{IPAslink|Ï‡}}, and {{IPAslink|p}}~{{IPAslink|f}} still sometimes [[Alternation (linguistics)|alternate]], as demonstrated in [[inflection]]s of many [[Semitic root|root]]s in which the roots' meaning is retained despite variation of begedkefet letters' [[manner of articulation]], e.g., {|cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="white-space:nowrap; border-style:none" |colspan=3|in [[verb]]s: |- |{{â€¢}}{{Hebrew|×‘×•× â† ×ª×‘×•×}}||{{IPA|/'''b'''o/ â†’ /taËˆ'''v'''o/}}||("come" ([[Imperative mood|imperative]]) â†’ "you will come"), |- |{{â€¢}}{{Hebrew|×©×‘×¨ â† × ×©×‘×¨}}||{{IPA|/ÊƒaËˆ'''v'''aÊ/ â†’ /niÊƒËˆ'''b'''aÊ/}}||("broke" ([[Transitive verb|transitive]]) â†’ "broke" ([[Intransitive verb|intransitive]]), |- |{{â€¢}}{{Hebrew|×›×ª×‘ â† ×™×›×ª×•×‘}}||{{IPA|/'''k'''aËˆtav/ â†’ /ji'''Ï‡'''Ëˆtov/}}||("he wrote" â†’ "he will write"), |- |{{â€¢}}{{Hebrew|×–×›×¨ â† ×™×–×›×•×¨}}||{{IPA|/zaËˆ'''Ï‡'''aÊ/ â†’ /jizËˆ'''k'''oÊ/}}||("he remembered" â†’ "he will remember"), |- |{{â€¢}}{{Hebrew|×¤× ×™×ª â† ×œ×¤× ×•×ª}}||{{IPA|/'''p'''aËˆnit/ â†’ /li'''f'''Ëˆnot/}}||("you (''f.'') turned" â†’ "to turn"), |- |{{â€¢}}{{Hebrew|×©×¤×˜×ª â† ×œ×©×¤×•×˜}}||{{IPA|/ÊƒaËˆ'''f'''atet/ â†’ /liÊƒËˆ'''p'''ot/}}||("you (''f.'') judged" â†’ "to judge "), |- |colspan=3|or in [[noun]]s: |- |{{â€¢}}{{Hebrew|×¢×¨×‘ â† ×¢×¨×‘×™×™×}}||{{IPA|/ËˆeÊe'''v'''/ â†’ /aÊËˆ'''b'''ajim/}}||("evening" â†’ "twilight"), |- |{{â€¢}}{{Hebrew|××œ×š â† ××œ×›×”}}||{{IPA|/Ëˆmele'''Ï‡'''/ â†’ /malËˆ'''k'''a/}}||("king" â†’ "queen"), |- |{{â€¢}}{{Hebrew|××œ×£ â† ××œ×¤×™×ª}}||{{IPA|/Ëˆele'''f'''/ â†’ /alËˆ'''p'''it/}}||("a thousand" â†’ "a thousandth"), |} however, in Modern Hebrew, stop and fricative variants of {{Hebrew|[[×‘]]}}{{rtl}}, {{Hebrew|[[×›]]}} and {{Hebrew|[[×¤]]}} are sometimes distinct phonemes, compare e.g.: {|cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="white-space:nowrap; border-style:none" |{{â€¢}}{{Hebrew|×Ö´×¤ÖµÖ¼×¨ â€“ ×Ö´×¤Öµ×¨}}||{{IPA|/iËˆ'''p'''eÊ/}} â€“ {{IPA|/iËˆ'''f'''eÊ/}}||("applied make up" â€“ "tipped ash"), |- |{{â€¢}}{{Hebrew|×¤Ö´Ö¼×¡Ö°×¤ÖµÖ¼×¡ â€“ ×¤Ö´×¡Ö°×¤Öµ×¡}}||{{IPA|/'''p'''isËˆ'''p'''es/}} â€“ {{IPA|/'''f'''isËˆ'''f'''es/}}||("striped" â€“ "missed"), |- |{{â€¢}}{{Hebrew|×”Ö´×ªÖ°×—Ö·×‘ÖµÖ¼×¨ â€“ ×”Ö´×ªÖ°×—Ö·×‘Öµ×¨}}||{{IPA|/hitÏ‡aËˆ'''b'''eÊ/}} â€“ {{IPA|/hitÏ‡aËˆ'''v'''eÊ/}}||("connected" â€“ "made friends (with)"), |- |{{â€¢}}{{Hebrew|×”Ö´×©Ö°××ªÖ·Ö¼×‘ÖµÖ¼×¥ â€“ ×”Ö´×©Ö°××ªÖ·Ö¼×‘Öµ×¥}}||{{IPA|/hiÊƒtaËˆ'''b'''ets/}} â€“ {{IPA|/hiÊƒtaËˆ'''v'''ets/}}||("got integrated" â€“ "was shocked"), |} and consider, e.g.: {|cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="border-style:none" |style="vertical-align:top; padding-right:3px"|{{â€¢}}  ||{{hebrew|×œ×›×›×‘}} "to star", whose common pronunciation {{IPA|/le'''k'''aËˆ'''Ï‡'''ev/}} preserves the [[manner of articulation]] of each [[Kaph|kaf]] in the word it is [[morphological derivation|derived]] from: {{hebrew|×›Ö¼×•Ö¹×›Ö¸×‘}} {{IPA|/'''k'''oËˆ'''Ï‡'''av/}} "a star" (first stop, then [[Fricative consonant|fricative]]), as opposed to the [[linguistic prescription|prescribed]] pronunciation {{IPA|/le'''Ï‡'''aËˆ'''k'''ev/}}, which regards the variation in pronunciation of kaf {{IPAslink|Ï‡}} â†â†’ {{IPAslink|k}} as allophonic and determines its manner of articulation according to historical phonological principles; or: |- |style="vertical-align:top; padding-right:3px"|{{â€¢}}  ||similarly, {{hebrew|×œ×¨×›×œ}} "to gossip", whose prescribed pronunciation {{IPA|/leÊaËˆkel/}} is [[Colloquialism|colloquially]] rejected, commonly pronounced {{IPA|/leÊaËˆÏ‡el/}}, preserving the fricative manner of articulation in related nouns (e.g. {{hebrew|×¨×›×™×œ×•×ª}} {{IPA|/ÊeÏ‡iËˆlut/}} "gossip", {{hebrew|×¨×›×œ×Ÿ}} {{IPA|/ÊaÏ‡Ëˆlan/}} "gossiper"). |} This phonemic divergence might be due to a number of factors, amongst others: *due to loss of consonant gemination in modern Hebrew, which formerly distinguished the stop members of the pairs from the fricatives when intervocalic â€“ e.g. in the [[inflection]]s: :{|cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="white-space:nowrap; border-style:none" |{{â€¢}}{{Hebrew|×§×¤×¥ â† ×§×™×¤×¥}}||{{IPA|/kaËˆ'''f'''ats/ â†’ /kiËˆ'''p'''ets/}}, historically {{IPA|/ki'''p'''Ëˆ'''p'''ets/}}||("jumped" â†’ "hopped"), |- |{{â€¢}}{{Hebrew|×©×‘×¨ â† ×©×™×‘×¨}}||{{IPA|/ÊƒaËˆ'''v'''ar/ â†’ /ÊƒiËˆ'''b'''er/}}, historically {{IPA|/Êƒi'''b'''Ëˆ'''b'''er/}}||("broke" â†’ "shattered"), |- |{{â€¢}}{{Hebrew|×©×›×Ÿ â† ×©×™×›×Ÿ}}||{{IPA|/ÊƒaËˆ'''Ï‡'''an/ â†’ /ÊƒiËˆ'''k'''en/}}, historically {{IPA|/Êƒi'''k'''Ëˆ'''k'''en/}}||("resided" â†’ "housed"), |} *due to the introduction, through [[loanword|foreign borrowings]], of: :{{â€¢}}syllable-initial {{IPAslink|f}} (e.g. {{hebrew|×¤×‘×¨×§}} {{IPA|/'''f'''ibËˆÊek/}} "fabricated"), :{{â€¢}}non-syllable-initial {{IPAslink|p}} (e.g. {{hebrew|×”×¤× ×˜}} {{IPA|/hi'''p'''Ëˆnet/}} "hypnotized") :{{â€¢}}non-syllable-initial {{IPAslink|b}} (e.g. {{hebrew|×¤×‘×¨×§}} {{IPA|/fi'''b'''ËˆÊek/}} "fabricated"), ×’×³×•Ö¹×‘Ö¼ {{IPA|/dÊ’o'''b'''/}} "job", {{hebrew|×§×•Ö¼×‘Ö¼}} {{IPA|/ku'''b'''/}} "cubic meter", {{hebrew|×¤Ö¸Ö¼××‘Ö¼}} {{IPA|/pa'''b'''/}} "pub"). Apart from this partial phonemic distinction, common Israeli pronunciation no longer always concords with the original [[phonology|phonological]] principle "stop variant after a consonant; fricative after a vowel", although this principle is still [[linguistic prescription|prescribed]] as standard by the [[Academy of the Hebrew Language]], e.g.: * The words {{hebrew|××¢×‘×•×¨×ª}} ([[ferry]]) and {{hebrew|××¢×‘×¨×•×ª}} ([[Ma'abarot|refugee absorption camps]]), whose respective prescribed pronunciation is {{IPA|/maÊ•Ëˆ'''b'''oÊet/}} and {{IPA|/maÊ•'''b'''aËˆÊot/}}, are commonly pronounced {{IPA|/ma.aËˆ'''b'''oÊet/}} and {{IPA|/ma.a'''b'''aËˆÊot/}}, replacing the consonant ({{IPAslink|Ê•}}) with a vowel ([[Open central unrounded vowel|{{IPA|/a/}}]]), but still preferring the stop variant {{IPAslink|b}} to its fricative counterpoint {{IPAslink|v}}. * Similarly, the words {{hebrew|×”×¢×¤×œ×”}} ([[Aliyah Bet]], called the Ha'apala which designates the covert Jewish immigration to British Palestine, 1934-1948) and {{hebrew|××¢×¤×™×œ×™×}} (the immigrants of this immigration), whose respective prescribed pronunciation is {{IPA|/haÊ•'''p'''aËˆla/}} and {{IPA|/maÊ•'''p'''iËˆlim/}}, are commonly pronounced {{IPA|/ha.a'''p'''aËˆla/}} and {{IPA|/ma.a'''p'''iËˆlim/}}, again replacing the consonant ({{IPAslink|Ê•}}) with the vowel ([[Open central unrounded vowel|{{IPA|/a/}}]]), but still preferring the stop {{IPAslink|p}} to the fricative {{IPAslink|f}}. * Conversely, words like {{Hebrew|×œ×”×›×—×™×©}} (to deny) or {{Hebrew|××›×—×•×œ}} (paintbrush), whose respective prescribed pronunciation is {{IPA|/leha'''Ï‡'''ËˆÄ§iÊƒ/}} and {{IPA|/mi'''Ï‡'''ËˆÄ§ol/}}, are commonly pronounced {{IPA|/leha'''k'''ËˆÏ‡iÊƒ/}} and {{IPA|/mi'''k'''ËˆÏ‡ol/}}, preferring the stop {{IPAslink|k}} to the fricative {{IPAslink|Ï‡}}, although following vowels (respectively [[Open central unrounded vowel|{{IPA|/a/}}]] and {{IPAslink|i}}), due to the shifting of the original semitic pronunciation of the letter {{hebrew|×—}} ([[heth]]) from {{IPAslink|Ä§}} to {{IPAslink|Ï‡}}, rendering it identical to common Israeli pronunciation of the fricative variant of the letter {{hebrew|×›}}. ==Notes== '''Bet''', '''Beth''', '''Beh''', or '''Vet''' is the second [[Letter (alphabet)|letter]] of the [[Semitic abjads]], including [[Phoenician language|Phoenician]] BÄ“t [[File:Phoenician_beth.svg|12px|]], [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] BÄ“t {{Hebrew|×‘}}, [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]] BÄ“th [[File:Beth.svg|12 px]], [[Syriac alphabet|Syriac]] BÄ“á¹¯ {{lang|syc|Ü’}}, and [[Arabic Alphabet|Arabic]] {{transl|ar|DIN|BÄÊ¾}} {{lang|ar|Ø¨}} Its sound value is a [[voiced bilabial stop]] âŸ¨bâŸ© or a [[voiced labiodental fricative]] âŸ¨vâŸ©. This letter's name means "house" in various Semitic languages (Arabic ''[[:wikt:Ø¨ÙŠØª#Arabic|bayt]]'', Akkadian ''[[:wikt:ğ’‚#Akkadian|bÄ«tu, bÄ“tu]]'', Hebrew: ''[[:wikt:×‘×™×ª#Hebrew|bayiá¹¯]]'', Phoenician ''[[:wikt:ğ¤ğ¤‰ğ¤•#Phoenician|bt]]'' etc.; ultimately all from [[Proto-Semitic]] [[:wikt:Appendix:Proto-Semitic *bayt-|*bayt-]]), and appears to derive from an [[Egyptian hieroglyph]] of a house by [[acrophony]]. O1 The Phoenician letter gave rise to, among others, the [[Greek alphabet|Greek]] [[Beta (letter)|Beta]], [[Latin alphabet|Latin]] [[B]], and [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]] [[Ğ‘]], [[Ğ’]]. ==Origin== The name ''bet'' is derived from the West Semitic word for "[[house]]", and the shape of the letter derives from a [[Proto-Sinaitic]] glyph that may have been based on the [[Egyptian hieroglyphs|Egyptian hieroglyph]] ''[[Pr (hieroglyph)|Pr]]'' O1 which depicts a house. {| class=wikitable style="text-align: center;" |- ! [[Egyptian hieroglyphs|Hieroglyph]] ! [[Proto-Sinaitic script|Proto-Sinaitic]] ! [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician]] ! [[Paleo-Hebrew alphabet|Paleo-Hebrew]] |- | align="center" | O1 | align="center" | [[File:Proto-Canaanite_-_bet.png]] | align="center" | [[File:Phoenician_beth.svg|20px|Bet]] | align="center" | [[File:Early_Aramaic_character_-_Beth.png]] |} ==Arabic {{Transl|ar|DIN|bÄÊ¾}}== The Arabic letter {{lang|ar|Ø¨}} is named {{lang|ar|Ø¨Ø§Ø¡}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|bÄÊ¾}}'' ({{transl|sem|bÄÊ”}}). It is written in several ways depending on its position in the word: {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Ø¨}} The letter normally renders {{IPA|/b/}} sound, except in some names and [[loanword]]s where it can also render {{IPA|/p/}}, often arabized as {{IPA|/b/}}, as in {{lang|ar|Ø¨Ø±Ø³ÙŠÙ„}} ([[Persil]]). For {{IPA|/p/}}, it may be used interchangeably with the Persian letter {{lang|fa|[[Ù¾]]}} - ''pe'' (with 3 dots) in this case. ==Hebrew Bet / Vet== {|class=wikitable style="text-align:center;" !colspan=5|[[Orthography|Orthographic]] variants |- !colspan=3|Various print fonts !rowspan=2|[[Cursive Hebrew|Cursive
Hebrew]] !rowspan=2|[[Rashi script|Rashi
script]] |- !|Serif !! [[Sans-serif]] !! [[Monospaced]] |- |width=20%|×‘ |width=20%|×‘ |width=20%|×‘ |width=20%|[[Image:Hebrew letter Bet handwriting.svg|22px]] |width=20%|[[Image:Hebrew letter Bet Rashi.png|35px]] |} Hebrew spelling: {{Hebrew|×‘ÖµÖ¼×™×ª}} The Hebrew letter represents two different phonemes: a "b" sound ({{IPA|/b/}}) (bet) and a "v" sound ({{IPA|/v/}}) (vet). The two are distinguished by a dot (called a [[dagesh]]) in the centre of the letter for {{IPA|/b/}} and no dot for {{IPA|/v/}}. This letter is named ''bet'' and ''vet'', following the modern Israeli Hebrew pronunciation, ''bet'' and ''vet'' ({{IPA|/bÉ›jt/}}), in [[Israel]] and by most [[Jews]] familiar with Hebrew, although some non-Israeli [[Ashkenazi Hebrew|Ashkenazi]] speakers pronounce it ''beis'' (or ''bais'')The school system [[Bais Yaakov]] or BaisYakov.net in Baltimore and ''veis'' ({{IPA|/bejs/}}) (or ''vais'' or ''vaiz'').{{cite web |title=Learning Alef-Bais |url=https://www.imamother.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=197374 |date=October 22, 2012}} "His Hebrew Morah is teaching the sounds of the alef bais based on English ... For Vais, since there are no Hebrew words that begin with a vais, ..." (whether or not it's true that "no Hebrew..." is not the point. It's that the teacher uses VAIZ) It is also named ''beth'', following the [[Tiberian Hebrew]] pronunciation, in academic circles. In modern Hebrew the frequency of the usage of bet, out of all the letters, is 4.98%. === Variations on written form/pronunciation === {{main|Modern Hebrew phonology}} {| class="wikitable" |- !! colspan=1 | Name !! colspan=1 | Symbol !! colspan=1 | [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] !! colspan=1 | [[Transliteration]] !! colspan=1 | Example |- | Vet | align=center | {{Hebrew|1=×‘}} | align="center" | {{IPA|/v/}} | align="center" | v | align="center" | '''v'''ote |- | Bet | align=center | {{Hebrew|1=×‘Ö¼}} | align="center" | {{IPA|/b/}} | align="center" | b | align="center" | '''b'''oat |- |} ====Bet with the dagesh==== When the Bet has a "dot" in its center, known as a [[dagesh]], then it represents {{IPA|/b/}}. There are various rules in [[Hebrew grammar]] that stipulate when and why a dagesh is used. ====Bet without the dagesh (Vet)==== When this letter appears as '''{{Hebrew|×‘}}''' ''without'' the [[dagesh]] ("dot") in its center then it represents a [[voiced labiodental fricative]]: {{IPA|/v/}}. ===Mystical significance of {{Hebrew|×‘}}=== Bet in [[gematria]] represents the number 2. As a [[Prefix (linguistics)|prefix]], the letter bet may function as a [[preposition]] meaning "in", "at", or "with". Bet is the first letter of the [[Torah]]. As Bet is the number 2 in gematria, this is said to symbolize that there are two parts to Torah: the Written [[Torah]] and the [[Oral Torah]]. According to [[Legends of the Jews|Jewish legend]], the letter Bet was specially chosen among the twenty two letters in Hebrew by [[God]] as the first letter of Torah as it begins with "''Bereshit'' (In the beginning) God created heaven and earth."Ginzberg, Louis (1909). ''The Legends of the Jews [http://www.swartzentrover.com/cotor/e-books/misc/Legends/Legends%20of%20the%20Jews.pdf Vol. I : Alphabet]'' (Translated by Henrietta Szold) Philadelphia: Jewish Publication Society. [[Rashi]] points out that the letter is closed on three sides and open on one; this is to teach you that you may question about what happened after creation, but not what happened before it, or what is above the heavens or below the earth. ===In mathematics=== In [[set theory]], the [[beth number]]s stand for powers of infinite sets. ==Syriac Beth== {| class="wikitable" |- !''Beth'' |- | [[File:Syriac Eastern bet.svg|50px]] ''Madná¸«aya'' Beth |- | [[File:Syriac Serta bet.svg|50px]] ''Será¹­o'' Beth |- | [[File:Syriac Estrangela bet.svg|50px]] ''Esá¹­rangela'' Beth |} [[File:Syriac letter shapes Beth.PNG|600px]] In the [[Syriac alphabet]], the second letter is {{lang|syr|Ü’}} â€” Beth ({{lang|syr|Ü’ÜÜ¼Ü¬}}). It is one of six letters that represents two associated sounds (the others are [[Gimel (letter)|Gimel]], [[Dalet]], [[Kaph]], [[Pe (letter)|Pe]] and [[Taw (letter)|Taw]]). When Beth has a hard pronunciation (''qÃ»Å¡Å¡ÄyÃ¢'') it is a [[[voiced bilabial plosive|b]]]. When Beth has a soft pronunciation (''rÃ»kkÄá¸µÃ¢'') it is traditionally pronounced as a [[[voiced bilabial fricative|v]]], similar to its Hebrew form. However, in eastern dialects, the soft Beth is more often pronounced as a [[[voiced labial-velar approximant|w]]], and can form [[diphthong]]s with its preceding vowel. Whether Beth should be pronounced as a hard or soft sound is generally determined by its context within a word. However, wherever it is traditionally [[consonant length|geminate]] within a word, even in dialects that no longer distinguish double consonants, it is hard. In the West [[Syriac language|Syriac dialect]], some speakers always pronounce Beth with its hard sound. Beth, when attached to the beginning of a word, represents the [[preposition]] 'in, with, at'. As a numeral, the letter represents the number 2, and, using various systems of dashes above or below, can stand for 2,000 and 20,000. ==Character encodings== {{charmap |05D1|name1=Hebrew Letter Bet |0628|name2=Arabic Letter Beh |0712|name3=Syriac Letter Beth |0801|name4=Samaritan Letter Bit |2136|name5=Bet Symbol }} {{charmap |10381|name1=Ugaritic Letter Beta |10841|name2=Imperial Aramaic Letter Beth |10901|name3=Phoenician Letter Bet }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|×‘}} {{Arabic language}} {{Hebrew language}} {{Northwest Semitic abjad}} [[Category:Phoenician alphabet]] [[Category:Arabic letters]] [[Category:Hebrew alphabet]]

'''Cursive Hebrew''' ({{lang-he|×›×ª×‘ ×¢×‘×¨×™ ×¨×”×•×˜}} ''{{transl|he|ktav ivri rahut}}'', "Flowing Hebrew Writing", or ×›×ª×‘ ×™×“ ×¢×‘×¨×™ ''{{transl|he|ktav yad ivri}}'', "Hebrew Handwriting", often called simply ×›×ª×‘ ''{{transl|he|ktav}}'', "Writing") is a collective designation for several styles of [[handwriting]] the [[Hebrew alphabet]]. [[Modern Hebrew]], especially in informal use in [[Israel]], is handwritten with the [[Ashkenazi]] [[cursive]] script that had developed in [[Central Europe]] by the 13th century.Ada Yardeni, ''The Book of Hebrew Script: History, Palaeography, Script Styles, Calligraphy & Design'', The British Library, 2002, {{ISBN|1-58456-087-8}}, p. 97 This is also a mainstay of handwritten [[Yiddish language|Yiddish]].Sheva Zucker, ''Yiddish: an Introduction to the Language, Literature, and Culture'', New York City, Vols. 1 & 2, 1994 & 2002, {{ISBN|1-877909-66-1}}, {{ISBN|1-877909-75-0}} It was preceded by a [[Sephardi]] cursive script, known as [[Solitreo]], that is still used for [[Judaeo-Spanish|Ladino]].Marie-Christine Varol, ''Manual of Judeo-Spanish: Language and Culture'', University of Maryland Press, 2008, {{ISBN|978-1-934309-19-3}}, p. 28 ==Contemporary forms== As with all handwriting, cursive Hebrew displays considerable individual variation. The forms in the table below are representative of those in present-day use.Jonathan Orr-Stav, ''Learn to Write the Hebrew Script: Aleph through the Looking Glass'', Yale University Press, 2006, {{ISBN|0-300-10841-9}} The names appearing with the individual letters are taken from the [[List of Unicode characters#Hebrew|Unicode standard]] and may differ from their designations in the various languages using them â€“ see [[Hebrew alphabet#Pronunciation of letter names|Hebrew alphabet / Pronunciation of letter names]] for variation in letter names. development of cursive Hebrew from the 7th through the 19th centuries. This is discussed in the following section, which makes reference to the columns in the table, numbered 1 through 14. [[Image:CursiveWritingHebrew.png]]
'''Figure 3:''' "Cursive Writing" ''(Jewish Encyclopedia, 1901-1906)''. '''Column:''' # [[Incantation]] upon [[Babylonia]]n dishIn Corpus Inscriptionum Hebraicarum 18. # [[Egypt]]ian, 12th century. # [[Constantinople]], 1506. # 10th century. # [[Spain|Spanish]], dated 1480. # Spanish, 10th century. # [[Hachmei Provence|ProvenÃ§al]], 10th century. # [[Italy|Italian]], 10th century. # [[Greece|Greek]], dated 1375. # Italian, dated 1451. # Italian, 10th century. # [[Germany|German]], 10th century. # [[Eleazer of Worms]], copied at [[Rome]] in 1515 by [[Elias Levita]]German-Ashkenazi, [[British Museum]], Additional Manuser. of 27199 (Paleographical Society, Oriental series lxxix.). # Ashkenazi, 19th century. ==History== [[Image:Besht Signature.svg|thumb|'''Figure 1:''' Signature of the [[Baal Shem Tov]] some time in the 1700s, written in the cursive Hebrew script.]] The brief inscriptions daubed in red ink upon the walls of the [[Jewish catacombs of Venosa|catacombs of Venosa]] are probably the oldest examples of cursive script. Still longer texts in a cursive alphabet are furnished by the clay bowls found in [[Babylonia]] and bearing [[exorcism]]s against magical influences and evil spirits. These bowls date from the 7th or 8th century, and some of the letters are written in a form that is very antiquated ''([[Cursive Hebrew#Historical forms|Figure 3, column 1]])''. Somewhat less of a cursive nature is the manuscript, which dates from the 8th century.Hebrew Papyri: Steinschneider, HebrÃ¤ische Papyrusfragmente aus dem Fayyum, in Aegyptische Zeitschrift, xvii. 93 et seq., and table vii.; C. I. H. cols. 120 et seq.; Erman and Krebs, Aus den Papyrus der KÃ¶niglichen Museen, p. 290, Berlin, 1899. For the Hebrew papyri in The Collection of Erzherzog Rainer, see D. H. MÃ¼ller and D. Kaufmann, in Mitteilungen aus der Sammlung der Papyrus Erzherzog Rainer, i. 38, and in FÃ¼hrer durch die Sammlung, etc. pp. 261 et seq. ''[[Cursive Hebrew#Historical forms|Columns 2â€“14]]'' exhibit cursive scripts of various countries and centuries. The differences visible in the square alphabets are much more apparent. For instance, the Sephardi rounds off still more, and, as in [[Arabic]], there is a tendency to run the lower lines to the left, whereas the Ashkenazi script appears cramped and disjointed. Instead of the little ornaments at the upper ends of the stems, in the letters [[Image:Image1Letters.jpg]] a more or less weak flourish of the line appears. For the rest the cursive of the Codices remains fairly true to the square text. Documents of a private nature were certainly written in a much more running hand, as the sample from one of the oldest Arabic letters written with Hebrew letters (possibly the 10th century) clearly shows in the papyrus, in "FÃ¼hrer durch die Ausstellung", Table XIX., Vienna, 1894, ''([[Cursive Hebrew#Historical forms|compare Figure 3, column 4]])''. However, since the preservation of such letters were not held to be of importance, material of this nature from the earlier times is very scarce, and as a consequence the development of the script is very hard to follow. The last two columns of ''[[Cursive Hebrew#Historical forms|Figure 3]]'' exhibit the Ashkenazi cursive script of a later date. The next to the last is taken from a manuscript of [[Elias Levita]]. The accompanying specimen presents Sephardi script. In this flowing cursive alphabet the ligatures appear more often. They occur especially in letters which have a sharp turn to the left ([[×’]], [[×–]], [[×›]], [[× ]], [[×¦]], [[×—]]), and above all in [[× ]], whose great open bow offers ample space for another letter ''(see Figure 2)''. The following are the successive stages in the development of each letter: * [[Aleph|Alef]] is separated into two parts, the first being written as [[Image:Image2Letters.jpg]], and the [[perpendicular]] stroke placed at the left [[Image:Image3Letters.jpg]]. By the turn of the 20th century, Ashkenazi cursive had these two elements separated, thus ×€c, and the [[acute angle]] was rounded. It received also an abbreviated form connected with the favorite old ligature [[Image:Image4Letters.jpg]], and it is to this ligature of Alef and [[Lamedh|Lamed]] that the contracted [[Mizrahi|Oriental]] Aleph owes its origin ''([[Cursive Hebrew#Historical forms|Figure 3, column 7]])''. * In writing [[Bet (letter)|Bet]], the lower part necessitated an interruption, and to overcome this obstacle it was made [[Image:Image5Letters.jpg]], and, with the total omission of the whole lower line, [[Image:Image6Letters.jpg]]. * In [[Gimel]], the left-hand stroke is lengthened more and more. * [[Dalet]] had its stroke put on obliquely to distinguish it from [[Resh]]; however, since in rapid writing it easily assumed a form similar in appearance to [[Resh]], [[Dalet]] in analogy with [[×‘]] was later changed to [[Image:Image7Letters.jpg]]. * A transformation very similar to this took place in the cases of final [[Kaph|Kaf]] and of [[Qoph|Qof]] ''([[Cursive Hebrew#Historical forms|see columns 2, 5, 11, 14]])'', except that Kaf opened out a trifle more than Qof. * The lower part of [[Zayin]] was bent sharply to the right and received a little hook at the bottom. * The left-hand stroke of [[Teth|á¹¬et]] was lengthened. * Lamed gradually lost its [[semicircle]] until (as in both [[Nabataean Arabic|Nabataean]] and [[Syriac language|Syriac]]) by the turn of the 20th century, it became a simple stroke, which was bent sharply toward the right. In the modern script today the Lamed has regained its semicircle. * Final [[Mem]] branches out at the bottom, and in its latest stage is drawn out either to the left or straight down. * In [[Samekh]] the same development also took place, but it afterward became again a simple circle. * To write '[[Ayin]] without removing the pen from the surface, its two strokes were joined with a curl. * The two forms of the letter [[Pe (letter)|Pe]] spread out in a marked flourish. * For [[Tsade|Tsadi]] the right-hand head is made longer, at first only to a small degree, but later on to a considerable extent. * In the beginning [[Shin (letter)|Shin]] develops similarly to the same letter in Nabataean, but afterward the central stroke is lengthened upward, like the right arm of Tsadi, and finally it is joined with the left stroke, and the first stroke is left off altogether. * The letters [[×”]], [[×“]], [[×—]], [[×Ÿ]], [[× ]], [[×¨]], [[×ª]], have undergone little modification: they have been rounded out and simplified by the omission of the heads. == See also == *[[Cursive]] *[[Handwriting]] *[[RuqÊ¿ah script]] == Notes == {{reflist|2}} *[http://jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?artid=1308&letter=A#3547 Cursive Hebrew] in the 1901â€“1906 [[Jewish Encyclopedia]] ==External links== *[http://www.oketz.com/fonts/script.html Cursive Hebrew fonts for download at ''www.oketz.com''] *[http://www.ladinotype.com LadinoType - System for Solitreo and Rashi] {{Hebrew language}} {{list of writing systems}} [[Category:Hebrew alphabet]] [[Category:Penmanship]]
