{{about|the Semitic letter|the designation as "untouchable" in the Hindu caste system|Dalit|other uses}} {{Phoenician glyph|letname=Dalet|previouslink=Gimel|previousletter=Gimel|nextlink=He (letter)|nextletter=He|archar=Ø¯|sychar=Ü•|hechar=×“|amchar=daleth|gechar=á‹°|phchar=daleth|grchar=Î”|lachar=D|cychar=Ğ”|ipa=d, Ã°|num=4|gem=4}} '''Dalet''' ({{transl|sem|dÄleth}}, also spelled '''Daleth''' or '''Daled''') is the fourth [[Letter (alphabet)|letter]] of the [[Semitic abjads]], including [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician]] DÄlet [[File:Phoenician daleth.svg|12px]], [[Hebrew alphabet|Hebrew]] 'DÄlet {{lang|he|×“}}, [[Aramaic alphabet|Aramaic]] DÄlath [[File:Daleth.svg|12 px]], [[Syriac alphabet|Syriac]] DÄlaá¹¯ {{lang|syc|Ü•}}, and [[Arabic Alphabet|Arabic]] {{transl|ar|DIN|DÄl}} {{lang|ar|Ø¯}} (in [[abjadi order]]; 8th in modern order). Its sound value is a [[voiced alveolar plosive]] ({{IPA|[d]}}). The letter is based on a glyph of the [[Middle Bronze Age alphabets]], probably called ''dalt'' "door" (''door'' in Modern Hebrew is '''delet'''), ultimately based on a [[Egyptian hieroglyphs|hieroglyph]] depicting a door, O31 The Phoenician letter gave rise to the Greek [[delta (letter)|delta]] (Î”), Latin [[D]], and the [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]] letter [[De (Cyrillic)|Ğ”]]. ==Arabic dÄl== {{see also|á¸Äl}} The letter is named ''dÄl'', and is written in several ways depending on its position in the word: {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Ø¯}} The letter represents a {{IPA|/d/}} sound. ==Hebrew== {|class=wikitable style="text-align:center;" !colspan=5|[[Orthography|Orthographic]] variants |- !colspan=3|Various print fonts !rowspan=2|[[Cursive Hebrew|Cursive
Hebrew]] !rowspan=2|[[Rashi script|Rashi
script]] |- !Serif !! [[Sans-serif]] !! [[Monospaced]] |- |width=20% style="font:30pt 'Times New Roman', 'SBL Hebrew', David, Narkisim, 'Taamey Frank CLM', serif;" | ×“ |width=20% style="font:29pt Arial, 'DejaVu Sans Condensed', 'DejaVu Sans', Tahoma, Alef, sans-serif;" | ×“ |width=20% style="font:30pt 'Courier New', 'Miriam Fixed', FreeMono, monospace;" | ×“ |width=20%|[[File:Hebrew letter Daled handwriting.svg|22px]] |width=20%|[[File:Hebrew letter Daled Rashi.png|35px]] |} Hebrew spelling: {{lang|he|×“Ö¸Ö¼×œÖ¶×ª}} The letter is ''dalet'' in the modern Israeli Hebrew pronunciation (see [[Taw (letter)|Tav (letter)]]). ''Dales'' is still used by many [[Ashkenazi]] Jews and ''daleth'' by some [[Jew]]s of [[Middle East|Middle-Eastern]] background, especially in the diaspora. In some academic circles, it is called ''daleth'', following the [[Tiberian Hebrew]] pronunciation. It is also called ''daled''. The '''×“''' like the [[English language|English]] [[D]] represents a [[voiced alveolar stop]]. Just as in English, there may be subtle [[voiced alveolar stop#Varieties of d|varieties]] of the sound that are created when it is spoken. ===Variations=== Dalet can receive a [[dagesh]], being one of the six letters that can receive Dagesh Kal (see Gimel). There are minor variations to this letter's pronunciation, such as *'''×“''' dhalet {{IPA|/d/}} ({{IPA|/Ã°/}} among [[Teimani]]m, [[Mizrahi Jews|Mizrachim]] and some [[Sephardi]]m; {{IPA|/z/}} among some Ashkenazim.) or *'''×“Ö¼''' dalet {{IPA|/d/}}. In addition, in modern Hebrew, the combination '''×“×³''' (dalet followed by a [[geresh]]) is used when transcribing foreign names to denote {{IPA|/Ã°/}}. ===Significance=== In [[gematria]], dalet symbolizes the number four. The letter dalet, along with the [[He (letter)|He]] (and very rarely [[Gimel (letter)|Gimel]]) is used to represent the [[Names of God in Judaism]]. The letter He is used commonly, and the dalet is rarer. A good example is the keter (crown) of a [[tallit]], which has the blessing for donning the [[tallit]], and has the name of God usually represented by a dalet. A reason for this is that He is used as an abbreviation for HaShem "The Name" and the dalet is used as a non-sacred way of referring to God.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} Dalet as a [[Prefix (linguistics)|prefix]] in Aramaic (the language of the [[Talmud]]) is a preposition meaning "that", or "which", or also "from" or "of"; since many [[Talmud]]ic terms have found their way into Hebrew, one can hear dalet as a prefix in many phrases (as in ''[[Mitzvah]] '''D'''oraitah''; a mitzvah from the [[Torah]].) In modern Hebrew the frequency of the usage of dalet, out of all the letters, is 2.59%. ==Syriac daled/dolath== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Daled/Dolath |- | [[File:Syriac Eastern dalat.svg|50px]] ''Madná¸«aya'' daled |- | [[File:Syriac Serta dalat.svg|50px]] ''Será¹­o'' dolath |- | [[File:Syriac Estrangela dalat.svg|50px]] ''Esá¹­rangela'' dalath |} [[File:Syriac letter shapes Dalath.PNG|600px]] In the [[Syriac alphabet]], the fourth letter is {{lang|syr|Ü•}} â€” dolath in western pronunciation, dalath and daled in eastern pronunciation ({{lang|syr|Ü•ÜµÜ ÜµÜ¬}}). It is one of six letters that represents two associated sounds (the others are [[Bet (letter)|bet]], [[Gimel (letter)|gimel]], [[kaph]], [[Pe (letter)|pe]] and [[Taw (letter)|taw]]). When daled/dolath has a hard pronunciation (''qÃ»Å¡Å¡ÄyÃ¢'') it is a {{IPA|{{bracket|[[voiced alveolar plosive|d]]}}}}. When it has a soft pronunciation (''rÃ»kkÄá¸µÃ¢'') it is traditionally pronounced as a {{IPA|{{bracket|[[Voiced dental fricative|Ã°]]}}}}. The letter is very common in Syriac as it is often attached to the beginning of words as the [[relative pronoun]]. Daled/dolath is always written with a point below it to distinguish it from the letter [[resh]] ({{lang|syr|Üª}}), which is identical apart from having a point above. As a numeral, dalad/dolath stands for the number four. With various systems of dots and dashes, it can also stand for 4,000 and 40,000. ==Character encodings== {{charmap |05D3|name1=Hebrew Letter Dalet |062F|name2=Arabic Letter Dal |0715|name3=Syriac Letter Dalath |0803|name4=Samaritan Letter Dalat |2138|name5=Dalet Symbol }} {{charmap |10384|name1=Ugaritic Letter Delta |10843|name2=Imperial Aramaic Letter Daleth |10903|name3=Phoenician Letter Delt }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|×“}} {{Arabic language}} {{Hebrew language}} {{Northwest Semitic abjad}} [[Category:Hebrew alphabet]] [[Category:Phoenician alphabet]] [[Category:Arabic letters]]

pages.title: DIN 31636
Gematria
pages.text:
'''Gematria''' {{IPAc-en|g|É™|Ëˆ|m|eÉª|t|r|i|É™}} ({{lang-he-n|×’××˜×¨×™×}} or {{hebrew|×’×™××˜×¨×™×”}}, plural {{hebrew|×’××˜×¨××•×ª}} or {{hebrew|×’××˜×¨×™××•×ª}}, ''gematriot'') is an alphanumeric [[code]] of assigning a [[number|numerical value]] to a name, word or phrase based on its letters. People who practice gematria believe that words with identical numerical values may bear some relation to each other or to the number itself. A single word can yield multiple values depending on the [[cipher]] used. Gematria originated as an Assyro-Babylonian-Greek system of alphanumeric code or cipher that was later adopted into [[Jewish culture]]. Similar systems have been used in other languages and cultures: earlier, the Greek [[isopsephy]], and later, derived from or inspired by Hebrew gematria, Arabic [[abjad numerals]], and English gematria. A well-known example of Hebrew gematria is the word ''[[Chai (symbol)|chai]]'' ("alive"), which is composed of two letters that (using the assignments in the ''Mispar gadol'' table shown below) add up to 18. This has made 18 a "[[luck#Numerology|lucky number]]" among the Jewish people. Gifts of money in multiples of 18 are very popular.{{cite web |title= Chabad.org Chani Benjaminson |url= http://www.chabad.org/library/article_cdo/aid/484894/jewish/What-is-the-reason-giving-money-in-multiples-of-18.htm}} ==Etymology== Although the term is [[Hebrew Language|Hebrew]], it may be derived from the [[Greek Language|Greek]] Î³ÎµÏ‰Î¼ÎµÏ„ÏÎ¯Î± ''geÅmetriÄ'', "[[geometry]]", which was used as a translation of gÄ“maá¹­riyÄ, though some scholars believe it to derive from Greek Î³ÏÎ±Î¼Î¼Î±Ï„ÎµÎ¹Î± ''grammateia'' "knowledge of [[writing]]". It's likely that both Greek words had an influence on the formation of the Hebrew word.[http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=gematria&r=66 "Gematria" at Dictionary.com]{{OED|gematria}} ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' Some also hold it to derive from the order of the [[Greek alphabet]], gamma being the third letter of the Greek alphabet.Benjamin Blech, "The Complete Idiot's Guide to Jewish Culture", p. 395 (2004) The word has been extant in English since at least the 17th century from translations of works by [[Giovanni Pico della Mirandola]]. Although ostensibly derived from Greek [[isopsephy]], it is largely used in Jewish texts, notably in those associated with the [[Kabbalah]]. The term does not appear in the [[Hebrew Bible]] itself. ==Traditional fields of use== Some identify two forms of gematria: the "revealed" form, which is prevalent in many hermeneutic methods found throughout [[rabbinic literature]], and the "mystical" form, a largely [[Kabbalah|Kabbalistic]] practice.e.g. Aish HaTorah, http://www.aish.com/spirituality/prayer/Prayer_6_-_Hear_O_Israel_Part_1.asp, which says "It is part of a Kabbalistic tradition ... Gematria is a Kabbalistic way of showing how two ideas are related on a conceptual level; it is using numerology as a basis to confirm (not create) the connection." Although gematria is most often used to calculate the values of individual words, [[Chapters and verses of the Bible|psukim]] (Biblical verses), [[Talmud]]ical aphorisms, sentences from the standard [[Jewish liturgy|Jewish prayers]], personal, angelic and Godly names, and other religiously significant material, Kabbalists use them often for arbitrary phrases and, occasionally, for various languages.{{cn|date=April 2019}} A few instances of gematria in Arabic, Spanish and Greek, spelled with the Hebrew letters, are mentioned in the works of [[Abraham Abulafia]];Otzar Eden ha-Ganuz, some [[Rebbe|Hasidic Rebbis]] also used it, although rarely, for [[Yiddish]].E.g. the rebbes of the [[Zidichov (Hasidic dynasty)|Zhidichov dynasty]] noticed that the Yiddish word ''vaser'' (water) has the same value as ''Geshem'' (''rain'' in Hebrew), and used this fact for [[Theurgy|theurgic]] meditations However, the primary language for gematria calculations has always been and remains Hebrew and, to a lesser degree, [[Aramaic]].{{cn|date=April 2019}} A classic Biblical commentary incorporating ''gematria'' is ''Baal ha-Turim'' by [[Jacob ben Asher]].{{cn|date=April 2019}} ''Gematria'' is often used by the [[Judah Loew ben Bezalel]] and [[Hasidic Judaism|Hasidic]] [[Torah]] commentators (such as the ''Sefath Emmeth'' from [[GÃ³ra Kalwaria]]).{{cn|date=April 2019}} ==Textual sources== A [[Mishnah|Mishnaic]] textual source makes clear that the word ''gematria'' is dated to at least the [[Tannaic]] period.

|style="font-size:350%;vertical-align:top;"| {{lang|he| Ö± }} |} |} Sometimes the names of the vowels are spelled out and their gematria is calculated using standard methods. ==Methods in Hebrew== There are several methods used to calculate the numerical value for the individual Hebrew/Aramaic words, phrases or whole sentences. More advanced methods are usually used for the most significant Biblical verses, [[Jewish liturgy|prayers]], names of God and angels etc. * ''Mispar Hechrachi'' (absolute value) that uses full numerical value of the 22 letters. Sometimes it is also called ''Mispar ha-Panim'' (face number), as opposed to the more complicated ''Mispar ha-Akhor'' (back number). * ''Mispar Gadol'' counts the final forms (sofit) of the Hebrew letters as a continuation of the numerical sequence for the alphabet, with the final letters assigned values from 500 to 900. * The same name, ''Mispar ha-Gadol'', is also used for another method, which spells the name of each letter and adds the standard values of the resulting string. * ''Mispar Katan'' calculates the value of each letter, but truncates all of the zeros. It is also sometimes called ''Mispar Me'ugal''. * ''Mispar Siduri'' (ordinal value) with each of the twenty-two letters given a value from one to twenty-two. * ''Mispar Bone'eh'' (building value, also ''Revu'a'', squareToras Menachem - Tiferes Levi Yitzchok, Vol. I - Bereshis, p. 2, fn. 7) is calculated by walking over each letter from the beginning to the end, adding the value of all previous letters and the value of the current letter to the running total. Therefore, the value of the word ''achad'' (one) is 1 + (1 + 8) + (1 + 8 + 4) = 23. * ''Mispar Kidmi'' (triangular value) uses each letter as the sum of all the standard gematria letter values preceding it. Therefore, the value of Aleph is 1, the value of Bet is 1 + 2 = 3, the value of Gimmel is 1+2+3=6, etc. It's also known as ''Mispar Meshulash'' (triangular or tripled number). * ''Mispar P'rati'' calculates the value of each letter as the square of its standard gematria value. Therefore, the value of Aleph is 1 Ã— 1 = 1, the value of Bet is 2 Ã— 2 = 4, the value of gimmel is 3 Ã— 3 = 9, etc. It's also known as ''Mispar ha-Merubah ha-Prati'''. * ''Mispar ha-Merubah ha-Klali'' is the square of the standard absolute value of each word. * ''Mispar Meshulash'' calculates the value of each letter as the cube of their standard value. The same term is more often used for ''Mispar Kidmi''. * ''Mispar ha-Akhor'' â€“ The value of each letter is its standard value multiplied by the position of the letter in a word or a phrase in either ascending or descending order. This method is particularly interesting, because the result is sensitive to the order of letters. It is also sometimes called ''Mispar Meshulash'' (triangular number). * ''Mispar Mispari'' spells out the standard values of each letter by their Hebrew names ("Achad" (one) is 1+8+4=13 etc.), and then adds up the standard values of the resulting string. * ''Mispar Shemi'' (also Millui letter "filling"), uses the value of each letter as equal to the value of its name.the spelling of the name of the number comes from the Talmud For example, the value of the letter Aleph is (1 + 30 + 80) = 111, Bet is (2 + 10 + 400) = 412, etc. Sometimes the same operation is applied two or more times recursively. * ''Mispar Ne'elam'' (hidden number) spells out the name of each letter without the letter itself (e.g. "Leph" for "Aleph") and adds up the value of the resulting string. * ''Mispar Katan Mispari'' (integral reduced value) is used where the total numerical value of a word is reduced to a single digit. If the sum of the value exceeds 9, the integer values of the total are repeatedly added to produce a single-digit number. The same value will be arrived at regardless of whether it is the absolute values, the ordinal values, or the reduced values that are being counted by methods above. * ''Mispar Misafi'' adds the number of the letters in the word or phrase to their gematria. * ''Kolel'' is the number of words, which is often added to the gematria. In case of one word, the standard value is incremented by one. Within the wider topic of Gematria are included the various alphabet transformations where one letter is substituted by another based on a logical scheme: * ''[[Atbash]]'' exchanges each letter in a word or a phrase by ''opposite'' letters. Opposite letters are determined by substituting the first letter of the Hebrew alphabet (Aleph) with the last letter (Tav), the second letter (Bet) with the next to last (Shin), etc. The result can be interpreted as a secret message or calculated by the standard gematria methods. A few instances of Atbash are found already in the Hebrew [[Bible]]. For example, see [[Jeremiah]] 25:26, and 51:41, with [[Targum Jonathan|Targum]] and [[Rashi]], in which the name ×©×©×š ("Sheshek") is thought to represent ×‘×‘×œ ([[Babylon]]).[[Solomon Schechter]] & Caspar Levias, "Gematria". ''The Jewish Encyclopedia'', Volume 5. New York: Funk & Wagnalls Co. 1904. [https://archive.org/stream/jewishencyclopedia05sing#page/588/mode/2up p.589.] * ''Albam'' â€“ the alphabet is divided in half, eleven letters in each section. The first letter of the first series is exchanged for the first letter of the second series, the second letter of the first series for the second letter of the second series and so forth. * ''Achbi'' divides the alphabet into two equal groups of eleven letters. Within each group, the first letter is replaced by the last, the second by the tenth, etc. * ''Ayak Bakar'' replaces each letter by another one that has a 10-times-greater value. The final letters usually signify the numbers from 500 to 900. Thousands is reduced to ones (1000 becomes 1, 2000 becomes 2 etc.) * ''Ofanim'' replaces each letter by the last letter of its name (e.g. "Fe" for "Aleph"). * ''Akhas Beta'' divides the alphabet into three groups of 7, 7 and 8 letters. Each letter is replaced cyclically by the corresponding letter of the next group. The letter [[Tav (letter)|Tav]] remains the same. * ''Avgad'' replaces each letter by the next one. Tav becomes Aleph. The opposite operation is also used. Most of the above-mentioned methods and ciphers are listed by Rabbi [[Moses ben Jacob Cordovero|Moshe Cordevero]].Moshe Cordevero, ''Sefer Pardes ha-Rimonim'', ''×©×¢×¨ ×”××•×ª×™×•×ª'' Some authors provide lists of as many as 231 various replacement ciphers, related to the 231 mystical Gates of the [[Sefer Yetzirah]].Elazar Rokeach, Sefer ha-Shem Dozens of other far more advanced methods are used in Kabbalistic literature, without any particular names. In Ms. Oxford 1,822, one article lists 75 different forms of gematria.''Encyclopedia Judaica'', 2007, vol. 7, 426 Some known methods are [[recursion|recursive]] in nature and are reminiscent of the [[graph theory]] or use heavily [[combinatorics]]. Rabbi [[Eleazar of Worms|Elazar Rokeach]] often used multiplication, instead of addition, for the above-mentioned methods. For example, spelling out the letters of a word and then multiplying the squares of each letter value in the resulting string produces very large numbers, in orders of [[10^12|trillions]]. The spelling process can be applied recursively, until a certain pattern (e.g. all the letters of the word "[[Talmud]]") is found; the gematria of the resulting string is then calculated. The same author also used sums of all possible unique letter combinations, which add up to the value of a given letter. For example, the letter [[He (letter)|Hei]], which has the standard value of 5, can be produced by combining 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 + 1, 2 + 1 + 1 + 1, 3 + 1 + 1, 4 + 1, 2 + 2 + 1 or 2 + 3, which adds up to 30. Sometimes combinations of repeating letters are not allowed (e.g. 2 + 3 is valid, but 3 + 1 + 1 is not). The original letter itself can also be viewed as a valid combination. Variant spellings of some letters can be used to produce sets of different numbers, which can be added up or analyzed separately. Many various complex [[formal systems]] and recursive algorithms, based on graph-like structural analysis of the letter names and their relations to each other, [[modular arithmetic]], pattern search and other highly advanced techniques, are found in the "Sefer ha-Malchuth" by Rabbi David ha-Levi of [[Draa|Draa Valley]], a Spanish-Moroccan Kabbalist of the 15â€“16th century.Sefer ha-Malchut, "Sifrei Chaim", Jerusalem, 2008 Rabbi David ha-Levi's methods take into consideration the numerical values and other properties of the [[Niqqud|vowels]] as well. Kabbalistic [[Jewish views of astrology|astrology]] uses some specific methods to determine the astrological influences on a particular person. According to one method, the gematria of the person's name is added to the gematria of his or her mother's name; the result is then divided by 7 and 12. The remainders signify a particular planet and Zodiac sign.Commentary to [[Sefer Yetzirah]], attributed to [[Saadia Gaon]], 6:4; Rabbi Aryeh Kaplan, Sefer Yetzirah, "WeiserBooks", Boston, 1997, pp. 220-221 ==Mathematical== A formula for finding a letter's corresponding number in Mispar Gadol is: f(x) = \left(10^{\mathrm{floor}\left(\left(x-1\right)\div 9\right)}\right)\times\left(\left(\left(x-1\right)\ \mathrm{mod}\ 9\right)+1\right) where ''x'' is the position of the letter in the language letters index (Regular order of letters), and the [[Floor and ceiling functions|floor]] and [[modulo operation|modulo]] functions are used. ==Absolute value== The most common form of Hebrew ''gematria'' is used in the [[Talmud]] and [[Midrash]], and elaborately by many post-Talmudic [[rabbinic literature|commentators]]. It involves reading words and sentences as numbers, assigning numerical instead of phonetic value to each letter of the [[Hebrew alphabet]]. When read as numbers, they can be compared and contrasted with other words or phrases â€“ cf. the Hebrew proverb {{lang|he|× ×›× ×¡ ×™×™×Ÿ ×™×¦× ×¡×•×“}} (''{{transl|he|nichnas yayin yatza sod}}'', lit. "wine entered, secret went out", i.e. "''in vino veritas''"). The gematric value of {{lang|he|×™×™×Ÿ}} ("wine") is 70 ({{lang|he|×™}}=10; {{lang|he|×™}}=10; {{lang|he|×Ÿ}}=50) and this is also the gematric value of {{lang|he|×¡×•×“}} ("secret", {{lang|he|×¡}}=60; {{lang|he|×•}}=6; {{lang|he|×“}}=4)‎.Babylonian Talmud, [[Sanhedrin (tractate)|tractate Sanhedrin]] 38a, see of [[Ghil'ad Zuckermann|Zuckermann, Ghil'ad]] (2006), "'[[false etymology|Etymythological]] [[Othering]]' and the Power of 'Lexical Engineering' in Judaism, Islam and Christianity. A Socio-Philo(sopho)logical Perspective", ''Explorations in the Sociology of Language and Religion'', edited by [[Tope Omoniyi]] and [[Joshua A. Fishman]], Amsterdam: John Benjamins, pp. 237-258. ==Use in other languages== ===Assyrian=== The first attested use of gematria occurs in an inscription of [[Assyria]]n ruler [[Sargon II]] (727â€“705 BCE) stating that the king built the wall of [[Khorsabad]] 16,283 cubits long to correspond with the numerical value of his name.p.197, Ratzan{{dubious|Actually insufficiently clear: what language did he use? Pls. fill in and adapt heading accordingly.|date=November 2018}} ===Greek isopsephy=== Gematria or [[isopsephy]] was borrowed from the Greek probably soon after their adoption of the Semitic writing system.p.164, Davies & Allison The extant examples of use in Greek come primarily from the Christian literature and, unlike rabbinic sources, is always explicitly stated as being used.p.164, Davies & Allison It has been asserted{{Where|date=January 2012}} that [[Plato]] (c. 427-347 BC) offers a discussion of gematria "in its simplest forms" in the [[Cratylus]], where he is said to have claimed that "the 'essential force' of a thing's name is to be found in its numerical value, and that words and phrases of the same numerical value may be substituted in context without loss in meaning." A direct review of the Cratylus, however, shows that Plato made no such claim and that gematria is not discussed in it either explicitly or implicitly.{{Citation needed|date=January 2012}} What can be more accurately stated is that Plato's discussion in the Cratylus involves a view of words and names as referring (more or less accurately) to the "essential nature" of a person or object, and that this view may have influenced â€“ and is central to â€“ ''Greek gematria''.Marc Hirshman, ''Theology and exegesis in midrashic literature'', in Jon Whitman, [https://books.google.com/books?id=7EjIm3pAfhQC&pg=PA113 Interpretation and allegory: antiquity to the modern period]. Brill, 2003. pp. 113-114.John Michell, [https://books.google.com/books?id=7nyuYu4TBAYC&pg=PA59 The Dimensions of Paradise: Sacred Geometry, Ancient Science, and the Heavenly Order on Earth], 2008. pp.59-65 ff. ===Latin-script languages=== The Latin-script languages exhibit borrowing of gematria methods dating from the early [[Middle Ages]] after the use lapsed following the collapse of the Roman Empire in the 5th century. Many researchers connect the "[[Number of the Beast]]", referred to in the [[Book of Revelation]] of the [[New Testament]], with Hebrew gematria as used by the early Christians. According to such interpretations, the number in question, ''six hundred sixty-six'' (666; see {{Bibleref2|Revelation 13:18}}) was originally derived from the [[Latin]] name of the Roman emperor at the time, [[Nero Caesar]], via the Greek, 'Neron Kaisar', and transliterated into Hebrew gematria. The result of this operation is six hundred sixty-six (50+200+6+50+100+60+200=666). ({{lang|he|× ×¨×•×  ×§×¡×¨}} ''{{transl|he|Neron Qesar}}'').Sanders, H. A. "The Number of the Beast in Revelation." It has two meanings. #An [[apostrophe]]-like [[sign]] (also known colloquially as a ''chupchik''){{cite web|last1=Kordova|first1=Shoshana|title=Word of the Day / Chupchik ×¦'×•Ö¼×¤Ö°Ö¼×¦Ö´'×™×§|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/features/word-of-the-day/word-of-the-day-chupchik-1510-1493-1468-1508-1468-1456-1510-1460-1497-1511.premium-1.506815|website=Haaretz|publisher=Haaretz Daily Newspaper Ltd.|accessdate=29 October 2014|date=3 Mar 2013}} placed after a letter: #* as a [[diacritic]] that modifies the [[pronunciation]] of some [[Letter (alphabet)|letters]] (in modern Hebrew), #* as a [[diacritic]] that signifies [[Yiddish]] [[etymology|origin]] of a word or [[suffix]],{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} ([[#Yiddish origin|examples below]]) #* as a [[punctuation mark]] to denote [[initialisms]] or abbreviations, #* or to denote a single-digit [[Hebrew numerals|Hebrew numeral]] # A note of [[cantillation]] in the reading of the [[Torah]] and other [[Bible|Biblical]] books, taking the form of a curved diagonal stroke placed above a letter. ==Diacritic== As a [[diacritic]], the Geresh is written immediately after (left of) the letter it modifies. It indicates three sounds native to speakers of [[modern Hebrew]] that are common in [[loan word]]s and [[slang]]: {{IPA|[dÊ’]}} as in '''''j'''u'''dg'''e'', {{IPA|[Ê’]}} as in ''mea'''s'''ure'' and {{IPA|[tÊƒ]}} as in '''''ch'''ur'''ch'''''. Sometimes the Vav is indeed doubled, however not to denote {{IPA|[w]}} as opposed to {{IPA|[v]}} but rather, when [[Ktiv male|spelling without niqqud]], to denote the [[phoneme]] /v/ at a non-initial and non-final position in the word, whereas a single Vav at a non-initial and non-final position in the word in [[Ktiv male|spelling without niqqud]] denotes one of the [[phoneme]]s /u/ or /o/. To pronounce foreign words and [[loanword]]s containing the sound {{IPAblink|w}}, Hebrew readers must therefore rely on former knowledge and context, see also [[Waw (letter)#Pronunciation|pronunciation of Hebrew Vav]]. ===Yiddish origin=== Some words or suffixes with [[Yiddish]] origin or pronunciation are marked with a geresh, e.g. the [[diminutive]] [[suffix]] {{lang|he|×œÖ¶×³×”}} â€“ {{lang|yi-Latn|-le}}, e.g. {{lang|he|×™×¢× ×§×œ×³×”}} â€“ {{lang|he-Latn|Yankale}} (as in [[Yaakov Bodo|Yankale Bodo]]), or the words {{lang|he|×—×‘×¨×³×”}} â€“ {{IPA|[ËˆÏ‡evre]}}, 'guys' (which is the Yiddish pronunciation of Hebrew {{lang|he|×—×‘×¨×”}} {{IPA|[Ï‡evËˆra]}} 'company'), or {{lang|he|×ª×›×œ×³×¡}} â€“ {{IPA|[ËˆtaÏ‡les]}}, 'down-to-earth'. ==Punctuation mark== The geresh is used as a punctuation mark in [[initialism]]s and to denote [[Numerical digit|numerals]]. ===Indicating initialisms=== In [[initialism]]s, the Geresh is written after the last letter of the initialism. For example: the title ×’Ö°Ö¼×‘Ö¶×¨Ö¶×ª (literally "lady") is abbreviated ×’×‘×³, equivalent to English "Mrs" and "Ms".{{cite web|title=(Academy of the Hebrew Language)|url=http://hebrew-academy.huji.ac.il/decision5.html Hebrew Punctuation }} ===Denoting a numeral=== A Geresh can be appended after (left of) a single letter to indicate that the letter represents a [[Hebrew numeral]]. For example: ×§×³‎ represents 100. A multi-digit Hebrew numeral is indicated by the [[Gershayim]] {{angle bracket|×´}}. ==Cantillation mark== {{main|Geresh (trope)}} As a note of [[cantillation]] in the reading of the [[Torah]], the Geresh is printed above the accented letter: ×‘Öœ. The '''{{lang|he-Latn|Geresh Muqdam}}''' (lit. 'a Geresh made earlier'), a variant cantillation mark, is also printed above the accented letter, but slightly before (i.e. more to the right of) the position of the normal Geresh: ×‘Ö. As a cantillation mark it is also called {{lang|he-Latn|á¹¬Ã¨res}} ({{lang|he|×˜Ö¶×¨Ö¶×¡}})‎. ==Computer encoding== Most keyboards do not have a key for the geresh. As a result, an [[apostrophe]] ( [[']], [[Unicode]] U+0027) is often substituted for it. {| class="wikitable" ! Appearance ! Code Points ! ({{lang-he-n|×’Ö°Ö¼×¨Ö¸×©Ö·××™Ö´×}}), is two distinct [[Typography|typographical]] marks in the [[Hebrew language]]. The name literally means "double [[geresh]]". ==Punctuation mark== Gershayim most commonly refers to the [[punctuation mark]] {{angle bracket|×´}}. It is always written before the last letter of the non-inflected form of a word or numeral. It is used in the following ways: *To indicate an [[acronym]].[http://hebrew-academy.huji.ac.il/decision5.html Hebrew punctuation guidelines, Â§ 31], [[Academy of the Hebrew Language]] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071015065211/http://hebrew-academy.huji.ac.il/decision5.html |date=October 15, 2007 }} For example: {{Hebrew|×“Ö¼×•Ö¼×´×—Ö·}} (singular), {{Hebrew|×“Ö¼×•Ö¼×´×—×•Ö¹×ª}} (plural), "report" represents {{Hebrew|'''×“'''×™×Ÿ '''×•×—'''×©×‘×•×Ÿ}}; and {{Hebrew|××´×›}} (masculine), {{Hebrew|×Ö·×´×›Ö´Ö¼×™×ª}} (feminine), "squad commander" represents {{Hebrew|'''×'''×¤×§×“ '''×›'''×™×ª×”}}. *To indicate a multi-digit [[Hebrew numeral]]. For example: ×™×´×— represents 18.{{Cite GHG|5|k}} ff. (Single-digit numerals are indicated with a following geresh.) *To indicate the names of Hebrew letters, differentiating them from any [[homograph]]s. Compare {{Hebrew|×”×•Ö¼× ×©Ö´×‚×¨Ö°×˜Öµ×˜ ×¢Ö·×™Ö´×Ÿ}} "he sketched an [[eye]]" with {{Hebrew|×”×•Ö¼× ×©Ö´×‚×¨Ö°×˜Öµ×˜ ×¢Ö·×™Ö´×´×Ÿ }} "he sketched an [[ayin]]". *To indicate Hebrew word [[Semitic root|roots]]. For example: the root of {{Hebrew|×ªÖ·Ö¼×©Ö°××‘ÖµÖ¼×¦Ö´×™×}}{{IPA|/taÊƒbeËˆtsim/}} "crossword puzzles" is {{Hebrew|×©×‘×´×¦}} (Å¡â€”bâ€”á¹£); the root of {{Hebrew|×œÖ°×”Ö·×˜Ö¼×•Ö¹×ª}} {{IPA|/lehaËˆtot/}} "to tilt, to conjugate" is {{Hebrew|× ×˜×´×”}} (nâ€”á¹­â€”h); and the root of {{Hebrew|×”Ö´×¡Ö°×ªÖ·Ö¼× Ö°×›Ö°Ö¼×¨Ö°× ×•Ö¼×ª}} {{IPA|/histankreËˆnut/}} "becoming synchronized" is {{Hebrew|×¡× ×›×¨×´× }} (sâ€“nâ€“kâ€“râ€“n). *In older texts, to indicate the [[transliteration]] of a foreign word. This use corresponds to [[english language|English]]'s use of [[italics]]. For example: in printed works of [[Rashi]], the town of Rashi's birth, [[Troyes]], is spelled {{Hebrew|×˜×¨×•×™×´×©}}. ==Cantillation mark== {{details|Gershayim (trope)}} Gershayim is a disjunctive [[cantillation]] accent in the [[Tanakh]] - Ö. It is placed above the stressed syllable, as in ×•Ö·×™Ö´Ö¼×§Ö·Ö¼Ö×— (Genesis 22:3). ==Computer encoding== Most keyboards do not have a key for the gershayim. {{about|the Semitic letter}} {{Redirect|Gimmel|the music group|Gimmel (music group)}} {{Phoenician glyph|letname=Gimel|previouslink=Bet (letter)|previousletter=Bet|nextlink=Dalet|nextletter=Dalet|archar=Ø¬|sychar=Ü“|hechar=×’|amchar=gimel|gechar=áŒˆ|phchar=gimel|grchar=Î“|lachar=C G|cychar=Ğ“ Ò|ipa=dÍ¡Ê’, Ê’, É¡, ÉŸ, É£|num=3|gem=3}} '''Gimel''' is the third [[Letter (alphabet)|letter]] of the [[Semitic abjads]], including [[Phoenician language|Phoenician]] GÄ«ml [[File:Phoenician_gimel.svg|12px]], [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] ËˆGimel {{lang|he|×’}}, [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]] GÄmal [[File:Gimel.svg| 12 px]], [[Syriac alphabet|Syriac]] GÄmal {{lang|syc|Ü“}}, and [[Arabic Alphabet|Arabic]] {{transl|ar|DIN|Ç§Ä«m}} {{lang|ar|Ø¬}} (in alphabetical order; fifth in spelling order). Its sound-value in the original Phoenician and in all derived alphabets, save Arabic, is a [[voiced velar plosive]] {{IPAblink|É¡}}; in [[Modern Standard Arabic]], it represents either a {{IPA|/dÍ¡Ê’/}} or {{IPA|/Ê’/}} for most Arabic speakers except in [[Lower Egypt]], the southern parts of [[Yemen]] and some parts of [[Oman]] where it is pronounced as a [[voiced velar plosive]] {{IPAblink|É¡}} ([[#Arabic Ç§Ä«m|see below]]). In its unattested, yet hypothetical, [[Proto-Canaanite]] form, the letter may have been named after a weapon that was either a [[sling (weapon)#Staff sling|staff sling]] or a [[throwing stick]], ultimately deriving from a [[Proto-Sinaitic]] glyph based on the [[throw stick (hieroglyph)|hieroglyph]] below:
T14
The [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician]] letter gave rise to the [[Greek alphabet|Greek]] [[gamma]] (Î“), the [[Latin alphabet|Latin]] [[C]] and [[G]], and the [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]] [[Ğ“]] and [[Ò]]. ==Arabic Ç§Ä«m {{anchor|Arabic Ç§Ä«m}}== [[File:The_realisation_of_the_letter_Ø¬_jÄ«m_as_a_phoneme_through_the_Arabic_Speaking_Countries.png|thumb|an approximation of the main pronunciations of written ⟨{{lang|ar|Ø¬}}⟩ in Arabic dialects.|500x500px|alt=]] The Arabic letter {{lang|ar|Ø¬}} is named {{lang|ar|Ø¬ÙŠÙ…}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|Ç§Ä«m}}''. It is written in several ways depending on its position in the word: {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Ø¬}} In most [[Modern Standard Arabic]] (Literary Arabic) registers and languages that use the [[Arabic script]] (e.g. [[Persian alphabet|Persian]], [[Urdu alphabet|Urdu]], [[Pashto alphabet|Pashto]], [[Uyghur Arabic alphabet|Uyghur]], [[Jawi alphabet|Malay]], etc) The standard pronunciation is an affricate {{IPAblink|dÍ¡Ê’}}, which is also the only acceptable value in which to recite the [[Qur'an]]. Less often, it is pronounced as a fricative {{IPAblink|Ê’}}, except in [[Lower Egypt]] and some parts of Southern [[Arabian Peninsula]]. Differences in pronunciation occur because speakers of Modern Standard Arabic pronounce words in accordance to their spoken [[variety of Arabic]]. In such varieties, cognate words will have consistent differences in pronunciation of the letter: The three main pronunciations: *{{IPAblink|dÍ¡Ê’}}: In most of the [[Arabian Peninsula]], [[Algerian Arabic|Algeria]], [[Iraqi Arabic|Iraq]], some parts of the [[Levantine Arabic|Levant]]. However, in [[Algerian Arabic|Algeria]] and the [[Gulf Arabic|Arabian Peninsula]], it may be softened to {{IPAblink|Ê’}} in some environments. *{{IPAblink|Ê’}}: In most of the [[Levantine Arabic|Levant]] and [[Maghrebi Arabic|Northwestern Africa]]. *{{IPAblink|g}}: In [[Lower Egypt|lower]] [[Egyptian Arabic|Egypt]], parts of [[Yemeni Arabic|Yemen]] ([[Tihamiyya Arabic|West]] and [[Ta'izzi-Adeni Arabic|South]]), and parts of [[Oman]], as in Hebrew and the other Semitic languages. This pronunciation also exists colloquially in Northwestern Africa in words that contain grooved alveolar sounds ({{IPAslink|s}}, {{IPAslink|z}}) but not to pronounce Literary Arabic. Other pronunciations: *{{IPAblink|ÉŸ}}: In some regions of [[Sudanese Arabic|Sudan]] and [[Yemeni Arabic|Yemen]], as well as being a common reconstruction of the [[Classical Arabic]] pronunciation. *{{IPAblink|j}}: In parts of the Arabian Peninsula in the most colloquial speech but {{IPAblink|dÍ¡Ê’}} or sometimes {{IPAblink|Ê’}} to pronounce Literary Arabic loan words. Egyptians always use the letter to represent {{IPAblink|É¡}} as well as in names and loanwords, such as {{lang|ar|Ø¬ÙˆÙ„Ù}} "golf". However, {{lang|ar|Ø¬}} may be used in Egypt to transcribe {{IPAslink|Ê’}}~{{IPAslink|dÍ¡Ê’}} (normally pronounced {{IPAblink|Ê’}}) or if there is a need to differentiate between them completely then {{lang|ar|[[Ú†]]}} can be used instead to represent {{IPAslink|Ê’}}~{{IPAslink|dÍ¡Ê’}}. ==Hebrew gimel== ===Variations=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" ! colspan="5" |[[Orthography|Orthographic]] variants |- ! colspan="3" |Various print fonts ! rowspan="2" |[[Cursive Hebrew|Cursive
Hebrew]] ! rowspan="2" |[[Rashi script|Rashi
script]] |- !|Serif !! [[Sans-serif]] !! [[Monospaced]] |- | width="20%" |×’ | width="20%" |×’ | width="20%" |×’ | width="20%" |[[File:Hebrew letter Gimel handwriting.svg|25px]] | width="20%" |[[File:Hebrew letter Gimel Rashi.png|46px]] |} Hebrew spelling: {{lang|he|×’Ö´Ö¼×™×Ö¶×œ}} Bertrand Russell posits that the letter's form is a conventionalized image of a camel.{{cite book|last=Russell|first=Bertrand|title=A history of western philosophy|year=1972|publisher=Touchstone book|location=New York|isbn=9780671314002|edition=60th print.}}{{cite web|url=http://www.meru.org/letteressays/gimel.html|title=Meru Foundation Research: Letter Portrait: Gimel|author=Stan Tenen - Meru Foundation|work=meru.org}} The letter may be the shape of the walking animal's head, neck, and forelegs. [[Barry B. Powell]], a specialist in the history of writing, states "It is hard to imagine how gimel = "camel" can be derived from the picture of a camel (it may show his hump, or his head and neck!)".{{cite book|last=Powell|first=Barry B.|title=Writing: Theory and History of the Technology of Civilization|date=27 March 2009|publisher=Wiley Blackwell|isbn=978-1405162562|page=182|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PZ2Gr3d9X2UC&pg=PA182&dq=Gimel+shaped+like+a+camel%27s+neck&hl=en&sa=X&ei=mnPqUvfRBoWR0AXBg4GICg&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=Gimel%20shaped%20like%20a%20camel's%20neck&f=false}} Gimel is one of the six letters which can receive a [[dagesh]]. The two functions of dagesh are distinguished as either qal (light) or hazaq (strong). The six letters are [[Beth (letter)|bet]], gimel, [[Daleth (letter)|daled]], [[kaph]], [[Pe (letter)|pe]], and [[Taw (letter)|taf]]. Three of them (bet, kaph, and pe) have their sound value changed in modern Hebrew from the fricative to the plosive by adding a dagesh. The other three represent the same pronunciation in modern Hebrew, but have had alternate pronunciations at other times and places. They are essentially pronounced in the fricative as ×’ gh Øº, dh Ø° and th Ø«. In the [[Yemenite Hebrew|Temani]] pronunciation, gimel represents {{IPA|/É¡/}}, {{IPA|/Ê’/}}, or {{IPA|/dÍ¡Ê’/}} when with a dagesh, and {{IPA|/É£/}} without a dagesh. In modern Hebrew, the combination '''{{Hebrew|×’×³}}''' (gimel followed by a [[geresh]]) is used in loanwords and foreign names to denote {{IPAblink|dÍ¡Ê’}}. ===Significance=== In [[gematria]], gimel represents the number three. It is written like a ''[[Waw (letter)|vav]]'' with a ''[[Yodh|yud]]'' as a "foot", and it resembles a person in motion; symbolically, a rich man running after a poor man to give him charity, as in the [[Hebrew alphabet]] ''gimel'' directly precedes ''[[dalet]]'', which signifies a poor or lowly man, from the Hebrew word ''dal'' (b. ''[[Shabbat (Talmud)|Shabbat]]'', 104a).{{cite book|last1=Ginzburgh|first1=Yitzchak|first2=Avraham Arieh|last2=Trugman|first3=Moshe Yaakov|last3=Wisnefsky|title=The Alef-beit: Jewish Thought Revealed Through the Hebrew Letters|location=Lanham|publisher=[[Rowman & Littlefield]]|pages=42,389|date=1991|isbn=9780876685181|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=5YVLC35h3B8C&printsec=frontcover}} The word ''gimel'' is related to ''gemul'', which means 'justified repayment', or the giving of reward and punishment. Gimel is also one of the seven letters which receive special crowns (called ''[[Tag (Hebrew writing)|tagin]]'') when written in a [[Sefer Torah]]. See ''[[Shin (letter)|shin]]'', ''[[ayin]]'', ''[[teth]]'', ''[[Nun (letter)|nun]]'', ''[[zayin]]'', and ''[[Tsade|tsadi]]''. The letter gimel is the [[electoral symbol]] for the [[United Torah Judaism]] party, and the party is often nicknamed ''Gimmel''.{{cite web|url=https://hamodia.com/2015/03/11/mass-rally-for-united-torah-judaism/|title=Mass Rally for United Torah Judaism - Hamodia.com|date=11 March 2015|website=Hamodia}}{{cite web|url=https://hamodia.com/2019/04/01/gedolim-special-conference-call-strengthen-utj-uphold-torah-shabbos-religious-character/|title=Gedolim at Special Conference Call to Strengthen UTJ to Uphold Torah, Shabbos and Religious Character - Hamodia.com|date=1 April 2019|website=Hamodia}} In Modern Hebrew, the frequency of usage of gimel, out of all the letters, is 1.26%. ==Syriac Gamal/Gomal== {| class="wikitable" |- !'''Gamal/Gomal''' |- | [[File:Syriac Eastern gamal.svg|50px]] ''Madná¸«aya'' Gamal |- | [[File:Syriac Serta gamal.svg|50px]] ''Será¹­o'' Gomal |- | [[File:Syriac Estrangela gamal.svg|50px]] ''Esá¹­rangela'' Gamal |} [[File:Syriac letter shapes Gamal.PNG|600px]] In the [[Syriac alphabet]], the third letter is {{lang|syr|Ü“}} â€” Gamal in eastern pronunciation, Gomal in western pronunciation ({{lang|syr|Ü“ÜµÜ¡ÜµÜ }}). It is one of six letters that represent two associated sounds (the others are [[Bet (letter)|Bet]], [[Dalet]], [[Kaph]], [[Pe (letter)|Pe]] and [[Taw (letter)|Taw]]). When Gamal/Gomal has a hard pronunciation (''qÃ»Å¡Å¡ÄyÃ¢ '') it represents {{IPAblink|É¡}}, like "'''g'''oat". When Gamal/Gomal has a soft pronunciation (''rÃ»kkÄá¸µÃ¢ '') it traditionally represents {{IPAblink|É£}} ({{lang|syr|Ü“İ‚ÜµÜ¡ÜµÜ }}), or ''Ghamal/Ghomal''. The letter, renamed ''Jamal/Jomal'', is written with a [[tilde]]/tie either below or within it to represent the borrowed [[phoneme]] {{IPAblink|dÍ¡Ê’}} ({{lang|syr|Ü“Ì°Ü¡ÜµÜ }}), which is used in [[Garshuni]] and some [[Neo-Aramaic languages]] to write loan and foreign words from Arabic or Persian. ==Ethiopian/Sudanese Gimel== The dialect of Eastern Africa often utilizes the gimel sofit when the gimel ends a word. The letter is a traditional gimel with an add-on curve on the bottom. ==Character encodings== {{charmap |05D2|name1=Hebrew Letter Gimel |062C|name2=Arabic Letter Jeem |06AF|name3=Arabic Letter Gaf |0713|name4=Syriac Letter Gamal |0802|name5=Samaritan Letter Gaman |2137|name6=Gimel Symbol }} {{charmap |10382|name1=Ugaritic Letter Gamla |10842|name2=Imperial Aramaic Letter Gimel |10902|name3=Phoenician Letter Gaml }} ==See also== The serif form \gimel of the Hebrew letter gimel is occasionally used for the [[gimel function]] in mathematics. == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|×’}} *[http://www.inner.org/hebleter/gimmel.htm The Mystical Significance of the Hebrew Letters: Gimel] {{Arabic language}} {{Hebrew language}} {{Northwest Semitic abjad}} [[Category:Phoenician alphabet]] [[Category:Hebrew alphabet]]

pages.text:
{{for|the Japanese letter|He (kana)}} {{Phoenician glyph|letname=He|previouslink=Dalet|previousletter=Dalet|nextlink=Vav (letter)|nextletter=Waw|archar=Ù‡|sychar=Ü—|hechar=×”|amchar=he0|gechar=áˆ€|phchar=he|grchar=Î•|lachar=E Ã‹ Æ |cychar=E Ğ Ğ„ Ğ­|ipa=h|num=5|gem=5}} {{UgariticText}} '''He''' is the fifth [[Letter (alphabet)|letter]] of the [[Semitic abjads]], including [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician]] HÄ“ [[File:Phoenician_he.svg|12px|]], [[Hebrew alphabet|Hebrew]] HÄ“ {{hebrew|×”}}, [[Aramaic alphabet|Aramaic]] HÄ“ [[File:He0.svg| 12 px]], [[Syriac alphabet|Syriac]] HÄ“ Ü—, and [[Arabic alphabet|Arabic]] {{transl|ar|DIN|HÄÊ¾}} Ù‡. Its sound value is a [[voiceless glottal fricative]] ({{IPA|[h]}}). The [[Proto-Canaanite_alphabet|proto-Canaanite]] letter gave rise to the [[Greek alphabet|Greek]] [[Epsilon]], [[Etruscan alphabet|Etruscan]] [[File:Alfabeto camuno-e.svg|14px|E]] ğŒ„, [[Latin alphabet|Latin]] [[E]], [[Ã‹]] and [[Latin epsilon|Æ]], and [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]] [[Ye (Cyrillic)|Ğ•]], [[Yo (Cyrillic)|Ğ]], [[Ukrainian Ye|Ğ„]] and [[E (Cyrillic)|Ğ­]]. ''He'', like all Phoenician letters, represented a [[consonant]], but the Latin, Greek and Cyrillic equivalents have all come to represent [[vowel]] sounds. ==Origins== {{Unreferenced section|date=April 2010}} In Proto-[[Northwest Semitic]] there were still three voiceless fricatives: uvular {{transl|sem|á¸«}}, glottal {{transl|sem|h}}, and pharyngeal {{transl|sem|á¸¥}}. In the [[Wadi el-Hol script]], these appear to be expressed by derivatives of the following Egyptian hieroglyphs V28''{{transl|sem|á¸«ayt}}'' "[[yarn|thread]]", A28 ''{{transl|sem|hillul}}'' "[[wiktionary:jubilation|jubilation]]", compare [[South Arabian alphabet|South Arabian]] [[File:himjar ha.PNG|20px]] {{transl|sem|h}}, [[File:himjar ha2.PNG|20px]] {{transl|sem|á¸¥}}, [[File:himjar kha.PNG|20px]] {{transl|sem|á¸«}}, [[Ge'ez alphabet|Ge'ez]] áˆ€, áˆ, áŠ€, and O6 ''{{transl|sem|á¸¥asir}}'' "[[court]]". In the [[Phoenician alphabet]], ''{{transl|sem|á¸«ayt}}'' and ''{{transl|sem|á¸¥asir}}'' are merged into [[Heth (letter)|Heth]] "fence", while ''{{transl|sem|hillul}}'' is replaced by ''He'' "[[window]]". ==Arabic hÄÊ¾== The letter is named ''{{Transl|ar|DIN|hÄÊ¾}}''. It is written in several ways depending on its position in the word: {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Ù‡}} ''{{Transl|ar|DIN|HÄÊ¾}}'' is used as a suffix (with the ''[[harakat]]'' dictated by ''{{Transl|ar|DIN|[[Ê¾IÊ¿rab]]}}'') indicating [[possession (linguistics)|possession]], indicating that the noun marked with the suffix belongs to a specific [[grammatical gender|masculine]] possessor; for example, {{lang|ar|ÙƒÙØªÙØ§Ø¨}} ''{{Transl|ar|DIN|kitÄb}}'' ("book") becomes {{lang|ar|ÙƒÙØªÙØ§Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù}} ''{{Transl|ar|DIN|kitÄbuhu}}'' ("his book") with the addition of final ''{{Transl|ar|DIN|hÄÊ¾}}''; the possessor is implied in the suffix. A longer example, {{lang|ar|Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ ÙŠÙÙ‚Ù’Ø±ÙØ£Ù ÙƒÙØªÙØ§Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù}}, (''huwa yaqraÊ¼u kitÄbahu'', "he reads his book") more clearly indicates the possessor. HÄÊ¾ is also used as the Arabic abbreviation for dates following the Islamic era [[AH (era)|{{sc|ah}}]]. The ''{{Transl|ar|DIN|hÄÊ¾}}'' suffix appended to a verb represents a masculine [[object (grammar)|object]] (e.g. {{lang|ar|ÙŠÙÙ‚Ù’Ø±ÙØ£ÙÙ‡Ù}}, ''{{Transl|ar|DIN|yaqraÊ¾uhu}}'', "he reads it"). The feminine form of this construction is in both cases {{lang|ar|Ù€Ù‡ÙØ§}} ''{{Transl|ar|DIN|-hÄ}}''. In [[NastaÊ¿lÄ«q]] the letter has its own particular shapes. As Urdu and other languages of Pakistan are usually written in NastaÊ¿lÄ«q, they normally employ those shapes, which are given an independent code point (U+06C1) for compatibility: {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Û}} For aspiration Urdu and other languages of Pakistan use a special form of ''hÄÊ¾'', called in Urdu ''do chashmÄ« he'' ("two-eyed he"): {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Ú¾}} Many Turkic languages of Central Asia like Uyghur as well as Kurdish use the modification of the letter for front vowels /{{IPA link|Ã¦}}/ or /{{IPA link|É›}}/. This has its own code point (U+06D5). To distinguish it from Arabic ''hÄÊ¾'' /h/ the letter lacks its initial and medial forms: {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Û•}} ==Hebrew Hei== {|class=wikitable style="text-align:center;" !colspan=5|[[Orthography|Orthographic]] variants |- !colspan=3|Various print fonts !rowspan=2|[[Cursive Hebrew|Cursive
Hebrew]] !rowspan=2|[[Rashi script|Rashi
script]] |- !|Serif !! [[Sans-serif]] !! [[Monospaced]] |- |width=20%|×” |width=20%|×” |width=20%|×” |width=20%|[[File:Hebrew letter He handwriting.svg|22px]] |width=20%|[[File:Hebrew letter He Rashi.png|35px]] |} Hebrew spelling: {{hebrew|×”Öµ×}} ===Pronunciation=== In [[Hebrew Language|modern Hebrew]], the letter represents a [[voiced glottal fricative]] {{IPA|/É¦/}}, and may also be dropped, although this pronunciation is seen as substandard. Also, in many variant Hebrew pronunciations the letter may represent a glottal stop. In word-final position, ''Hei'' is used to indicate an ''a''-vowel, usually that of [[qamatz]] ( {{Hebrew|1=ָ}} ), and in this sense functions like [[Aleph]], [[Vav (letter)|Vav]], and [[Yodh|Yud]] as a [[mater lectionis]], indicating the presence of a long vowel. ''Hei'', along with [[Aleph (Hebrew)|Aleph]], [[Ayin]], [[Resh|Reish]], and [[Heth (letter)|Khet]], cannot receive a [[dagesh]]. Nonetheless, it does receive a marking identical to the dagesh, to form ''Hei-[[mappiq]]'' ({{Hebrew|×”Ö¼}}). Although indistinguishable for most modern speakers or readers of Hebrew, the mapiq is placed in a word-final ''Hei'' to indicate that the letter is not merely a mater lectionis but the consonant should be aspirated in that position. It is generally used in Hebrew to indicate the third-person feminine singular genitive marker. Today, such a pronunciation only occurs in religious contexts and even then often only by careful readers of the scriptures. ===Significance of Hei=== In [[gematria]], ''Hei'' symbolizes the number five, and when used at the beginning of [[Hebrew calendar|Hebrew years]], it means 5000 (i.e. ×”×ª×©× ×´×“ in [[Arabic numerals|numbers]] would be the [[calendar date|date]] 5754). Attached to words, ''Hei'' may have three possible meanings: *A [[preposition]] meaning the definite article "the", or the relative pronouns "that", or "who" (as in "a boy ''who'' reads"). For example, ''yeled'', a boy; '''''ha'''yeled'', the boy. *A prefix indicating that the sentence is a question. (For example, ''Yadata'', You knew; '''''Ha'''yadata''?, Did you know?) *A suffix after place names indicating movement towards the given noun. (For example, ''Yerushalayim'', [[Jerusalem]]; ''Yerushalaym'''ah''''', towards Jerusalem.) In modern Hebrew the frequency of the usage of he, out of all the letters, is 8.18%. ''Hei'', representing five in gematria, is often found on amulets, symbolizing the five fingers of a hand, [[Hamsa|a very common talismanic symbol]]. ====In Judaism==== ''Hei'' is often used to represent the name of God as an abbreviation for [[Names of God in Judaism#Hashem.2FHadavar|Hashem]], which means ''The Name'' and is a way of saying ''God'' without actually saying the name of God. In print, Hashem is usually written as ''Hei'' with a [[geresh]]: {{Hebrew|×”×³}}. ==Syriac Heh== {| class="wikitable" |- !'''Heh''' |- | [[File:Syriac Eastern he.svg|50px]] ''Madná¸«aya'' Heh |- | [[File:Syriac Serta he.svg|50px]] ''Será¹­o'' Heh |- | [[File:Syriac Estrangela he.svg|50px]] ''Esá¹­rangela'' Heh |} [[File:Syriac letter shapes Heh.PNG|600px]] In the [[Syriac alphabet]], the fifth letter is {{lang|syr|Ü—}} â€” Heh ({{lang|syr|Ü—Ü¹Ü}}). It is pronounced as an [[[voiceless glottal fricative|h]]]. At the end of a word with a point above it, it represents the [[grammatical person|third-person]] [[grammatical gender|feminine]] [[grammatical number|singular]] [[suffix]]. Without the point, it stands for the masculine equivalent. Standing alone with a horizontal line above it, it is the [[abbreviation]] for either ''hÄnoh'' ({{lang|syr|Ü—ÜµÜ¢Ü˜Ü¿}}), meaning 'this is' or 'that is', or ''[[Hallelujah|halelÃ»ya]]'' ({{lang|syr|Ü—ÜµÜ Ü¹Ü Ü˜Ü¼ÜÜµÜ}}). As a numeral, He represents the number five. ==Character encodings== {{charmap |05D4|name1=Hebrew Letter He |0647|name2=Arabic Letter Heh |0717|name3=Syriac Letter He |0804|name4=Samaritan Letter Iy }} {{charmap |10385|name1=Ugaritic Letter Ho |10844|name2=Imperial Aramaic Letter He |10904|name3=Phoenician Letter He }} ==External links== {{commonscat|×”}} {{Hebrew language}} {{Arabic language}} {{Northwest Semitic abjad}} [[Category:Phoenician alphabet]] [[Category:Arabic letters]] [[Category:Hebrew alphabet]] [[kk:Ù‡]] [[tr:He (harf)]]

{{short description|Transliteration of English language into Hebrew script}} {{About|the Hebraization of English|Romanization of Hebrew|Romanization of Hebrew|phonetic transcription|International Phonetic Alphabet for Hebrew}} {{Cleanup-rewrite|date=May 2009}} The '''Hebraization of English''' (or '''Hebraicization''')[http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=Hebraize Random House Unabridged Dictionary: Hebraize][http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/hebraicize Random House Unabridged Dictionary: Hebraicize] is the use of the [[Hebrew alphabet]] to write [[English language|English]]. Because Hebrew uses an [[abjad]], it can render English words in multiple ways. There are many uses for hebraization, which serve as a useful tool for [[Israel]]i learners of English by indicating the pronunciation of unfamiliar letters. An example would be the English name spelled "Timothy", which can be Hebraized as "{{lang|en|×˜×™××•×ª×™}}" in the Hebrew alphabet. ==Table== === Consonants === For [[full spelling]], when a reader is likely to err in the reading of a word, the use of [[niqqud]] or [[partial vowelling|partial niqqud]] is recommended. That means, that the letters' appearances change when they are at the end of words from [[×›]], [[×¤]], [[×¦]], [[×]], [[× ]] to [[×š]], [[×£]], [[×¥]], [[×]], [[×Ÿ]] respectively. Final forms are used in transliteration when appropriate, with the exception of foreign words ending in a [p] sound, which retain the non-final form of [[×¤]], such as "×§×˜×©×•×¤" ("ketchup"). === Vowels and diphthongs=== Since vowels are not consistent in English, they are more difficult to transliterate into other languages. Sometimes they are just transcribed by the actual English letter, and other times by its actual pronunciation (which also varies). For the most accurate transliteration, below is a table describing the different vowel sounds and their corresponding letters. Hebrew has only 5 vowel sounds, with lack of discrimination in Hebrew between long and short vowels. In comparison, English which has around 12 vowel sounds (5 long, 7 short) depending on dialect. As a result, words such as sit/seat ({{IPA|/sÉªt/}} and {{IPA|/siËt/}}), hat/hut ({{IPA|/hÃ¦t/}} and {{IPA|/hÊŒt/}}), and cop/cope ({{IPA|/kÉ’p/}} and {{IPA|/koÊŠp/}}) are transliterated as the Hebrew vowels {{IPA|/i/}}, {{IPA|/a/}} and {{IPA|/o/}}. The English pronunciation can be known through prior context. Vowels will sometimes be put into Hebrew by their letters, and not by their sounds, even though it is less accurate phonetically. For example, any sort of "a" sound written with the letter "o", (ex. mom, monitor, soft), will often be transliterated as an "o" vowel, that is, with a vav (×•). The same is the case for an -or ending (pronounced -er), it will also often be transliterated with a vav as well. If the word with the "a" sound (such as "a" or "ah"), as in "ta ta", or "spa", it will be treated as an "a". For [[full spelling]], the ''[[niqqudot]]'' (the "dots") is simply omitted, if [[partial vowelling]] is desired, especially for letters like Vav, then the niqqudot is retained. {{Infobox writing system | name = Hebrew Braille | altname = {{Hebrew|×‘×¨×™×™×œ ×¢×‘×¨×™}} | type = [[Abjad]] | typedesc = | time = | languages = [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] | fam1 = [[Braille]] | fam2 = [[English Braille]] | print = [[Hebrew alphabet]] | creator = | sample = Hebrew Braille chart.jpg | imagesize = | note = none }} '''Hebrew Braille''' ({{lang-he|×‘×¨×™×™×œ ×¢×‘×¨×™}}) is the [[braille]] alphabet for [[Hebrew]]. The International Hebrew Braille Code is widely used. It was devised in the 1930s and completed in 1944. It is based on [[unified international braille|international norms]], with additional letters devised to accommodate differences between [[English Braille]] and the [[Hebrew alphabet]]. Unlike Hebrew, but in keeping with other braille alphabets, Hebrew Braille is read from left to right instead of right to left.,{{cite book|last1=Mackenzie|first1=Clutha Nantes|author2=Sir Clutha Nantes Mackenzie|title=World Braille Usage: a survey of efforts towards uniformity of braille notation|year=1954|publisher=UNESCO}} and unlike English Braille, it is a [[Abjad]], all consonants. ==History== Prior to the 1930s, there were several regional variations of Hebrew Braille, but no universal system.{{cite news | title = I Shall Light a Candle | last = Okin | first = Tessie | date = August 15, 1952 | accessdate = October 19, 2010 | work = Canadian Jewish Chronicle | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5rMqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PGEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6631,2004612&dq=jewish-braille-institute&hl=en}} In 1930, the [[JBI International|Jewish Braille Institute of America]], under the direction of the [[Synagogue Council of America]], assembled an international committee for the purpose of producing a unified embossed code to be used by sightless people throughout the world. The committee membership consisted of Isaac Maletz, representing the Jewish Institute for the Blind, Jerusalem; Dr. Max Geffner, of the Blindeninstitut of Vienna; Canon C. F. Waudby, of the National Institute for the Blind, Great Britain; Leopold Dubov, of the Jewish Braille Institute of America; and Rabbi Harry J. Brevis, representing the New York Board of Rabbis. Rabbi Brevis, who had lost his eyesight in his mid 20s, and who had developed a system of Hebrew braille for his personal use as a rabbinical student while attending the Jewish Institute of Religion from 1926 and 1929, was named chairman of the committee, and Leupold Dubov, the executive director of the Jewish Braille Institute of America, was appointed secretary. In 1933, the committee voted unanimously to approve and sponsor Brevis' system for adoption as the International Hebrew Braille Code. Brevis published a selection of readings from the Bible, Mishnah, and contemporary literature using this system in 1935 under the title ''A Hebrew Braille Chrestomathy''.{{Cite web|url=http://americanjewisharchives.org/publications/journal/PDF/1969_21_02_00.pdf|title=The Story of Hebrew Braille|last=Brevis|first=Harry|date=1969|website=http://americanjewisharchives.org/publications/journal/PDF/1969_21_02_00.pdf|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Among the greater challenges faced by the committee was the accommodation of the Hebrew vowel points. In 1936, the first Hebrew Braille book was published with sponsorship from the [[Library of Congress]]: a volume of excerpts from the ''[[Talmud]]'' and other sources.{{cite book|last=Blumenthal|first=Walter Hart|title=Bookmen's Bedlam: an Olio of Literary Oddities|year=1969|publisher=Ayer Publishing|isbn=978-0-8369-1022-3|page=175}} The code underwent further refinements for the better part of a decade until its completion in 1944. ==Basic alphabet== Because Hebrew Braille derives from English Braille, there is not a one-to-one match between Hebrew letters in print and in braille. Most obviously, four consonants with the ''[[dagesh]]'' point in print have distinct letters in braille, but three others require a ''dagesh'' prefix {{bc|45}} in braille. The different placements of the dot on the print letter ''shin'' also correspond to two different letters in braille. On the other hand, the distinct final forms of some letters in print are not reflected in braille. It is not clear if the prefix can be added to letters that have partners in the bottom row of the table above to distinguish, say, dagesh hazak ''kk'' from dagesh kal ''k'', or ''ww'' from ''Ã»''. {{Use American English|date = February 2019}} {{Short description|Punctuation conventions of the Hebrew language over time}} {{Use mdy dates|date = February 2019}} {{Hebrew punctuation}} '''Hebrew [[punctuation]]''' is similar to that of [[English language|English]] and other [[Western world|Western]] languages, [[Modern Hebrew]] having imported additional punctuation marks from these languages in order to avoid the ambiguities sometimes occasioned by the relative paucity of such symbols in [[Biblical Hebrew]]. ==Punctuation== ===Quotation marks=== {{Details|Quotation mark#Summary table}} {| class="wikitable" style="float: right; width: auto;" |+ Example ! scope="col" | Standard ! scope="col" | Alternate |- style="font-size: 325%; line-height: 1em; text-align: center; font-family: serif;" | {{Script/Hebrew|1=â€×©Ö¸××œ×•Ö¹×â€}} | {{Script/Hebrew|1=â€×©Ö¸××œ×•Ö¹×â€}} |} [[File:OldHebrewQuotationStyle from1923 translation of RobinsonCrusoe.png|alt=Old style Hebrew quotation marks, from a 1923 translation of Robinson Crusoe|thumb|412px|Old style Hebrew quotation marks, from a 1923 translation of [[Robinson Crusoe]]]] With most printed Hebrew texts from the early 1970s and before, opening quotation marks are low (as in [[German language|German]]), and closing ones are high, often going above the letters themselves (as opposed to the [[gershayim]], which is level with the top of letters). An example of this system is {{Script/Hebrew|1=â€×©Ö¸××œ×•Ö¹×â€}}. However, this distinction in Hebrew between opening and closing quotation marks has mostly disappeared, and today, quotations are most often punctuated as they are in English (such as {{Script/Hebrew|1="×©Ö¸××œ×•Ö¹×"}}), with both quotation marks high. This is due to the advent of the [[Hebrew keyboard|Hebrew keyboard layout]], which lacks the opening quotation mark âŸ¨â€âŸ©, as well as to the lack in Hebrew of "[[quotation mark#Curved quotes and Unicode|smart quotes]]" in certain word processing programs. In addition, the quotation mark is often used for the similar looking but different ''[[gershayim]]'' mark âŸ¨{{Script/Hebrew|×´}}âŸ©, as that too is absent from the [[Hebrew keyboard]]. {| class="wikitable" ! Standard ! Alternative ! style="text-align: left;" | Names |- | style="text-align: center;" | ‏ "â€¦" ‏ | style="text-align: center;" | ‏ "â€¦" ‏ | ''{{transl|he|merkhaÊ¾ot}}'' â€” {{Script/Hebrew|×Öµ×¨Ö°×›Ö¸××•Ö¹×ª}} (plural of ''{{transl|he|merkha}}'' â€” {{Script/Hebrew|×Öµ×¨Ö°×›Ö¸×}}); a similar punctuation mark unique to Hebrew is called [[gershayim]] â€” {{Script/Hebrew|×’×¨×©×™×™×}} |} ===Period, question mark, exclamation mark, comma=== Periods ([[full stops]]), [[Question mark|question marks]], [[Exclamation mark|exclamation marks]], and [[Comma|commas]] are used as in English. A Hebrew period in a traditional '''''[[serif]]''''' face usually looks like a tiny tilted square (a [[geometric shapes|diamond]]; â—Š). This is also true for the dot part of the [[question mark]], and [[exclamation mark]]. In [[Arabic language|Arabic]], which is also written from right to left, the question mark âŸ¨{{lang|ar|ØŸ}}âŸ© is mirrored right-to-left from the English question mark. (Some browsers may display the character in the previous sentence as a forward question mark due to font or text directionality issues.) [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] is also written right-to-left, but uses a question mark that appears on the page in the same orientation as the English âŸ¨?âŸ©.Truss, Lynne. ''Eats, Shoots & Leaves'', 2003. p. 143. {{ISBN|1-59240-087-6}}. ===Colon and ''{{lang|he-Latn|sof pasuq}}''=== Stemming from Biblical Hebrew, a ''{{lang|he-Latn|[[sof pasuq]]}}'' âŸ¨ {{Script/Hebrew|×ƒ}} âŸ© is the equivalent of a period, and is used in some writings such as prayer books. Since a ''{{lang|he-Latn|sof pasuq}}'' is absent from the [[Hebrew keyboard|Hebrew keyboard layout]], and looks very similar to the [[colon (punctuation)|colon]] âŸ¨:âŸ©, a colon is often substituted for it. {| class="wikitable" ! Glyph ! Unicode ! Name |- | {{Script/Hebrew|×ƒ}} | U+05C3 | HEBREW PUNCTUATION SOF PASUQ |- | : | U+003A | COLON |} === Vertical bar and ''paseq'' === {| class="wikitable" style="float: right; width: auto;" |+ Example ! scope="col" | Standard ! scope="col" | Alternate |- style="font-size: 325%; line-height: 1em; text-align: center; font-family: serif;" | {{Script/Hebrew|1=×Ö±×œÖ¹×”Ö´×™××€}} | {{Script/Hebrew|1=×Ö±×œÖ¹×”Ö´×™×|}} |} [[File:Crop of Hebrew manuscript meant to illustrate Hebrew punctuation paseq.jpg|thumb|In the image above, the ''paseq'' can be seen on the last occurrence of the word {{Hebrew|×Ö±×œÖ¹×”Ö´×™×}}]] The ''[[paseq]]'' ({{Hebrew|×¤Ö¸Ö¼×¡Öµ×§}}) âŸ¨{{Hebrew|×€}}âŸ© originates from Biblical Hebrew. As it is not on a standard [[Hebrew keyboard]], a [[vertical bar]] âŸ¨|âŸ© is often used instead. However, it is seldom if ever used in modern Israeli Hebrew, and is not mentioned on the [[Academy of the Hebrew Language]]'s guide to modern Hebrew punctuation. The height of the ''paseq'' depends on the font, but it is generally the same as the letter {{Script/Hebrew|×}}.{{Cite book|url=http://archive.org/details/thenotelineinthe00kennuoft|title=The note-line in the Hebrew scriptures commonly called PÄsÄ“q, or PesÃ®q|last=Kennedy|first=James|date=1903|publisher=Edinburgh T. & T. Clark|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}} Like much Biblical Hebrew punctuation, the meaning of the ''paseq'' is not known, although a number of hypotheses exist. The word itself means "separator", but this name was a medieval innovation by later Jews; the root {{Hebrew|×¤Ö¼×¡×§}} does not exist in the Biblical Hebrew canon. James Kennedy, an English [[hebraist]], wrote a book about the ''paseq'' in which he hypothesized that it was an ancient mark serving the same purpose as the modern word [[sic]] (in non-Latin texts). The [[Westminster Leningrad Codex]] contains over 500 ''paseq''s; William Wickes, an influential scholar in this area, divide them into nine classes;{{Cite book|url=http://archive.org/details/treatiseonaccent00wickuoft|title=A treatise on the accentuation of the twenty-one so-called prose books of the Old Testament|last=Wickes|first=William|date=1887|publisher=Oxford : Clarendon Press|others=Robarts - University of Toronto}} [[Wilhelm Gesenius]], drawing on Wickes, divided them into five:{{Cite book|url=https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Gesenius%27_Hebrew_Grammar/15._The_Accents#cite_note-6|title=Gesenius' Hebrew grammar|last=Gesenius|first=Wilhelm|last2=Kautzsch|first2=E. (Emil)|last3=Cowley|first3=A. E. (Arthur Ernest)|date=1910|publisher=Oxford : Clarendon Press|others=Gerstein - University of Toronto|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}} * as a divider between two words which end and begin with the same letters, e.g. {{Hebrew|×©Ö¸××œ×•Ö¹××€ ×Ö·}} (''[[Shalom]]'', [[Mama and papa|ma]]) * between identical or very similar words, e.g. {{Hebrew|×¨Ö·×§×“Ö¸×Ÿ×€ ×¨Ö¸×§Ö·×“}} (the dancer danced) * between words which are to a high degree contradictory, e.g. {{Hebrew|×Ö±×œÖ¹×”Ö´×™××€ ×¨Ö¶×©Ö·××¢}} ([[Omnibenevolence|God, evil]]) * between words otherwise liable to be wrongly connected, e.g. {{Hebrew|×Ö·×€ ×‘Ö¸Ö¼×!}} (prevents [[onomatopoeia]] "Ah, bah" from being merged to {{Hebrew|×Ö·×‘Ö¸Ö¼×}} meaning father) * "and lastly, between heterogeneous terms, as Eleazar the High Priest, and Joshua" ({{Hebrew|×Ö¶×œÖ°×¢Ö¸×–Ö¸Ö£×¨ ×”Ö·×›Ö¹Ö¼×”ÖµÖ£×Ÿ×€ ×•Ö´×™×”×•Ö¹×©Ö»×Öª×¢Ö·}}{{Em dash}}see context in {{Tanakhverse|Joshua|19:51}}) An example may be found in {{Bibleverse|Genesis|1:5|WLC}} in the Westminster Leningrad Codex and many other manuscripts: {{Quote|text={{Script/Hebrew|×•Ö·×™Ö´Ö¼×§Ö°×¨Ö¸Ö¨× ×Ö±×œÖ¹×”Ö´Ö¤×™××€ ×œÖ¸××•Ö¹×¨Ö™ ×™Ö”×•Ö¹× ×•Ö°×œÖ·×—Ö¹Ö–×©Ö¶××šÖ° ×§Ö¸Ö£×¨Ö¸× ×œÖ¸Ö‘×™Ö°×œÖ¸×” ×•Ö·Ö½×™Ö°×”Ö´×™Ö¾×¢Ö¶Ö¥×¨Ö¶×‘ ×•Ö·Ö½×™Ö°×”Ö´×™Ö¾×‘Ö¹Ö–×§Ö¶×¨ ×™Ö¥×•Ö¹× ×Ö¶×—Ö¸Ö½×“×ƒ ×¤}}|sign=|source=}} {| class="wikitable" ! Glyph ! Unicode ! Name |- |{{script|Hebr|×€}} | U+05C0 | HEBREW PUNCTUATION PASEQ |- | | | U+007C | VERTICAL LINE |} ===Hyphen and ''maqaf''=== {| class="wikitable" style="float: right; width: 30em; margin-left: 1em;" |+ Example ! scope="col" | Hebrew ''{{lang|he-Latn|maqaf}}'' ! scope="col" | Standard English hyphen |- style="font-size: 325%; line-height: 1em; text-align: center; font-family: serif;" | {{Script/Hebrew|×¢Ö·×œÖ¾×™Ö°×“Öµ×™}} | {{Script/Hebrew|×¢Ö·×œâ€‘×™Ö°×“Öµ×™}} |- | colspan="2" style="text-align: center;" | Notice how the maqaf aligns with the top horizontal strokes whereas the standard English hyphen is in the middle of the letters. |} The ''{{lang|he-Latn|maqaf}}'' ({{Script/Hebrew|×Ö·×§Ö¸Ö¼×£}}) âŸ¨{{Script/Hebrew|Ö¾}}âŸ© is the Hebrew [[hyphen]] âŸ¨-âŸ©, and has virtually the same purpose for connecting two words as in English. It is different from the hyphen in its positioning (a hyphen is in the middle in terms of height, the ''{{lang|he-Latn|maqaf}}'' is at the top) and it has a biblical origin,{{Cite GHG|16}} unlike many other [[Modern Hebrew]] punctuation symbols, which have simply been imported from European languages. The original purpose of the ''maqaf'' was to show that two words should be pronounced in one ''á¹­aÊ¿am'' ({{Script/Hebrew|×˜Ö·×¢Ö·×}}, breath, {{Literally|taste}}). For example, a person singing the word [[Tel Aviv|{{Script/Hebrew|×ªÖµÖ¼×œ ×Ö¸×‘Ö´×™×‘}}]] may take a pause for breath between {{Script/Hebrew|×ªÖµÖ¼×œ}} and {{Script/Hebrew|×Ö¸×‘Ö´×™×‘}}, while one singing the word {{Script/Hebrew|×ªÖµÖ¼×œÖ¾×Ö¸×‘Ö´×™×‘}} may not do the same.{{Cite web|url=https://hebrew-academy.org.il/topic/hahlatot/punctuation|title=×›×œ×œ×™ ×”×¤×™×¡×•×§|last=|first=|date=|website=[[Academy of the Hebrew Language]]|language=he|trans-title=Common [Hebrew] punctuation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2019-04-23|quote=×”×¢×¨×” ×‘: ×”××§×£ ×”×‘× ×‘××§×¨× ×©×™××•×©×• ××—×¨, ×•×”×•× ×©×™×™×š ×‘×¢×™×§×¨×• ×œ×˜×¢××™ ×”××§×¨×: ×”×•× ××•×¨×” ×¢×œ ×¦×™×¨×•×£ ×©×ª×™ ××™×œ×™× ××• ×™×•×ª×¨ ×”× ×§×¨××•×ª ×‘×˜×¢× ××—×“. (''Maqaf'' in the Bible has another use primarily associated with [[cantillation]], it indicates that two or more words are to be pronounced in one breath.)}} This use continues into the present beyond reprintings of Biblical texts; for example, the [[sheet music]] for modern Hebrew songs, such as {{Interlanguage link|Chag Purim|lt=|he|×—×’ ×¤×•×¨×™× (×©×™×¨)|WD=}}, are normally printed with them.{{Cite web|url=https://www.jewish-music.huji.ac.il/he/node/22403|title=Hag Purim â€“ The story behind its melody|last=Cohen-Zentner|first=Naomi|date=2015-03-01|website=[[The Hebrew University of Jerusalem]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2019-04-23}} The ''{{lang|he-Latn|maqaf}}'' is well-used in Hebrew typography; most books and newspapers use it and have the hyphens higher than one would find in English.{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}} In typed documents, however, it is frequently not used because it is absent from the keyboard or cumbersome to type. As a result, a standard English hyphen âŸ¨-âŸ© is most often used in online writings. This situation can be compared to that of users writing in Latin alphabets using the easily available [[hyphen-minus]] âŸ¨-âŸ© over [[hyphen]] âŸ¨â€âŸ©, [[minus sign|minus]] âŸ¨âˆ’âŸ©, [[dash#en dash|en dash]] âŸ¨â€“âŸ©, and [[dash#Em dash|em dash]] âŸ¨â€”âŸ©. It is possible to insert ''{{lang|he-Latn|maqaf}}'' using keyboard combinations: e.g. [[Option key]] + [[Backslash]] on [[MacOS]].https://apps.carleton.edu/its/flt/assets/MacHebrLayout.pdf {| class="wikitable" ! Glyph ! Unicode ! Name |- | {{Script/Hebrew|Ö¾}} | U+05be | HEBREW PUNCTUATION MAQAF |- | - | U+002d | HYPHEN-MINUS |} ===Brackets/parentheses=== Brackets or parentheses, âŸ¨(âŸ© and âŸ¨)âŸ© are the same in Hebrew as in English. Since Hebrew is written from right to left, âŸ¨)âŸ© becomes an opening bracket, and âŸ¨(âŸ© a closing bracket, the opposite from English, which is written left to right. ===Israeli currency=== {{Details|Shekel sign}} {| class="wikitable" style="float: right; width: auto; margin-left: 1em;" |+ Example |- ! scope="col" | With shekel sign ! scope="col" | With abbreviation |- ! colspan="2" |[[Israeli new sheqel|Israeli new shekel]] |- style="font-size: 250%; line-height: 1em; text-align: center; font-family: serif;" | {{Script/Hebrew|â‚ª12,000}} | {{Script/Hebrew|12,000×©×´×—}} |- ! colspan="2" |[[Israeli pound]] |- style="font-size: 250%; line-height: 1em; text-align: center; font-family: serif;" | {{Script/Hebrew|IÂ£12,000}} | {{Script/Hebrew|12,000×œ×´×™}} |} The [[shekel sign]] ({{Script/Hebrew|â‚ª}}) is the currency sign for the Israeli currency (the [[Israeli new shekel]]), in the way [[dollar sign|$]], [[pound sign|Â£]], and [[euro sign|â‚¬]] exist for other currencies. The shekel sign, like the dollar sign âŸ¨$âŸ©, is usually placed to the left of the number (so ''{{Script/Hebrew|â‚ª12,000}}'', rather than ''{{Script/Hebrew|12,000â‚ª}}''), but since Hebrew is written from right to left, the symbol is actually written after the number. It is either not [[space (punctuation)|separated]] from the preceding number, or is separated only by a [[thin space]]. Unlike the dollar sign, the new shekel sign is not used that often when handwriting monetary amounts, and is generally replaced by the abbreviation {{Script/Hebrew|×©×´×—}} (standing for ''{{lang|he-Latn|sheqel áº–adash}}'', lit. "new shekel"). The short-lived [[Israeli old shekel]], on the other hand, which had as its symbol [[File:Old Sheqel sign.svg|20x20px]],As of April 2019, this symbol does not exist in [[Unicode]]. is rarely referred to in modern Israeli writing; both due to its lifespan of only five years and the fact that due to hyperinflation it lost value daily, so that referring to a value in Israeli old shekels, even in retrospective writing, is essentially meaningless without knowing the exact time the figure was quoted.{{Cite news|url=https://www.haaretz.com/1.5190129|title=Requiem for the Shekel|last=Schechter|first=Asher|date=2012-02-24|work=[[Haaretz]]|access-date=2019-04-24|language=en}} As prices changed so rapidly, advertising of the time predominately used dollars;{{Cite web|url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/the-rise-and-fall-of-israeli-inflation|title=The Rise & Fall of Israeli Inflation|last=|first=|date=|year=2011|website=[[Jewish Virtual Library]]|publisher=American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2019-04-24}} when the shekel was referred to at all, it was with the letter S or its full Hebrew nameâ€”{{Hebrew|×©Ö¶××§Ö¶×œ}}; although certain banks, such as [[Bank Leumi]], used the letter {{Hebrew|×©}} to refer to it on checks, as well as the Latin letters "I.S."{{Cite web|url=https://kavimvenekudot.wordpress.com/2015/02/17/%d7%92%d7%9c%d7%92%d7%95%d7%9c%d7%95-%d7%a9%d7%9c-%d7%a1%d7%99%d7%9e%d7%9f-%e2%82%aa-%d7%a1%d7%99%d7%a4%d7%95%d7%a8-%d7%91%d7%90%d7%a8%d7%91%d7%a2%d7%94-%d7%a4%d7%a8%d7%a7%d7%99%d7%9d-%d7%a7%d7%a6/|title=×’×œ×’×•×œ×• ×©×œ ×¡×™××Ÿ â‚ª {{!}}{{!}}{{!}} ×¡×™×¤×•×¨ ×‘××¨×‘×¢×” ×¤×¨×§×™× ×§×¦×¨×™×|last=|first=|date=2015-02-17|website=×§×•×•×™× ×•× ×§×•×“×•×ª|language=he-IL|trans-title=The transformation of the shekel sign {{!}}{{!}}{{!}} A story in four parts|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2019-04-24}} The [[Israeli pound]], used mostly in modern Israel in historical writing, has as its symbol IÂ£, and its abbreviation is {{Hebrew|×œ×´×™}}. ===''Geresh'' and ''gershayim''=== {{Details|Geresh|gershayim}} {| class="wikitable" style="float: right; width: 20em; margin-left: 1em;" |+ Example ! scope="col" | [[Geresh]] ! scope="col" | [[Apostrophe]] used as a geresh |- style="font-size: 325%; line-height: 1em; text-align: center; font-family: serif;" | {{Script/Hebrew|×¦×³××¨×œ×¡}} | {{Script/Hebrew|1=×¦'××¨×œ×¡}} |- ! scope="col" | [[Gershayim]] ! scope="col" | [[Quotation mark]]s used as gershayim |- style="font-size: 325%; line-height: 1em; text-align: center; font-family: serif;" | {{Script/Hebrew|×¦×”×´×œ}} | {{Script/Hebrew|1=×¦×”"×œ}} |} The ''[[geresh]]'' âŸ¨{{Script/Hebrew|×³}}âŸ©, is the Hebrew equivalent of a period in abbreviations (e.g. abbrev.), in addition to being attached to Hebrew letters to indicate sounds like [[hard and soft G|soft ''g'']] {{IPAblink|dÊ’}} and [[ch (digraph)|''ch'']] {{IPAblink|tÊƒ}} in foreign names such as Charles ({{Script/Hebrew|[[:he:×¦'××¨×œ×¡|×¦×³××¨×œ×¡]]}}) and Jake ({{Script/Hebrew|×’×³×™×™×§}}). The ''[[gershayim]]'' âŸ¨{{Script/Hebrew|×´}}âŸ©, is a Hebrew symbol indicating that a sequence of characters is an acronym, and is placed ''before'' the last character of the word. Owing to a [[Hebrew keyboard]]'s having neither a ''geresh'' nor ''gershayim'', they are usually replaced online with, respectively, the visually similar apostrophe âŸ¨'âŸ© and quotation mark âŸ¨"âŸ©. The quotation mark and apostrophe are higher than the ''geresh'' and ''gershayim'': where the latter are placed level with the top of Hebrew letters, the apostrophe and quotation marks are above them. Some Hebrew-specific [[font]]s (fonts designed primarily for Hebrew letters), such as [[David (font)|David]], [[Narkisim]] and [[FrankRuehl]], do not feature the apostrophe and quotation marks as such but use the ''geresh'' and ''gershayim'' to substitute for them. {| class="wikitable" ! Glyph ! Unicode ! Name |- | {{Script/Hebrew|×³}} | U+05f3 | HEBREW PUNCTUATION GERESH |- | {{Script/Hebrew|×´}} | U+05f4 | HEBREW PUNCTUATION GERSHAYIM |- | ' | U+0027 | APOSTROPHE |- | " | U+0022 | QUOTATION MARK |} ===Mathematics=== Mathematical expressions are written in Hebrew using the same symbols as in English, including [[Arabic numerals|Western numerals]], which are written left to right. The only variant that exists is an [[alternative plus sign]], which is a plus sign which looks like an inverted [[capital letter|capital]] T. [[Unicode]] has this symbol at position U+FB29 "Hebrew letter alternative plus sign" (ï¬©).[http://www.decodeunicode.org/U+FB29 Unicode U+FB29 reference page] The reason for this practice is that it avoids the writing of a symbol "+" that looks like a [[Christian cross]].{{cite book|url=http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/4776-cross|title=Jewish Encyclopedia|author=Kaufmann Kohler|year=1901â€“1906|editor=[[Cyrus Adler]]|chapter=Cross|display-editors=etal}}[https://books.google.com/books?id=m8sWAAAAIAAJ&dq=Jewish+plus+sign&q=%22plus+sign+used+in+mathematics%22&pgis=1 Christian-Jewish Dialogue: Theological Foundations By Peter von der Osten-Sacken (1986 â€“ Fortress Press)] {{ISBN|0-8006-0771-6}} "In Israel the plus sign used in mathematics is represented by a horizontal stroke with a vertical hook instead of the sign otherwise used all over the world, because the latter is reminiscent of a cross." |} [[Reversed Nun|Reversed ''nun'']] (also called inverted ''nun'', ''nun hafukha'', or ''nun menuzzeret'') is a rare character found in two Biblical Hebrew texts. Although in Judaic literature it is known as ''nun hafukha'' ("reversed ''[[nun (letter)|nun]]''"), it does not function as any sort of letter in the text. It is not part of a word, and it is not read aloud in any way. It is simply a mark that is written, and is therefore a punctuation mark, not a letter. Also, it is surrounded by space. While it depends on the particular manuscript or printed edition, it is found in nine places: twice in the [[Book of Numbers]] (prior to and after Numbers 10:34-36), and seven times in [[Psalm]] 107. It is uncertain today what it was intended to signify. In many manuscripts, it does not even resemble a transformed ''nun'' at all, and when it does, it sometimes appears reversed (as mentioned above), sometimes inverted, and sometimes turned through 180Â°.[http://std.dkuug.dk/jtc1/sc2/wg2/docs/n2714.pdf Universal Multiple-Octet Coded Character Set: International Organization for Standardization] Other times it appears to look like the letter Z. {| class="wikitable" !
