pages.title: Hebrew spelling
pages.text:
'''Hebrew spelling''' ({{lang-he|×›×ª×™×‘ ×¢×‘×¨×™}} {{IPA|/ktiv Ê•ivËˆri/}}, "Hebrew spelling") refers to the way words are spelled in the [[Hebrew language]]. The [[Hebrew alphabet]] contains 22 letters, all of which are primarily consonants. This is because the Hebrew script is an [[abjad]], that is, its letters indicate consonants, not vowels or syllables. An early system to overcome this, still used today, is [[mater lectionis|''matres lectionis'']], where four of these letters, [[Aleph|alef]], [[He (letter)|he]], [[Waw (letter)|waw]] and [[yodh]] also serve as vowel letters. Later, a system of vowel points to indicate vowels (diacritics), called [[niqqud]], was developed. ==History== {{Further information|Biblical Hebrew orthography}} Throughout history, there have been two main systems of Hebrew spelling. One is vocalized spelling, the other is unvocalized spelling. In vocalized spelling (''[[ktiv menuqad]]''), all of the vowels are indicated by vowel points (called [[niqqud]]). In unvocalized spelling (''[[ktiv hasar niqqud]]''), the vowel points are omitted, but some of them are substituted by additional vowel letters - [[Waw (letter)|waw]] and [[yodh]] (''Ktiv malÄ“''). This system is the spelling system commonly used in Israel today. Vowel points are always optional in Hebrew. They can be used fully, partially or not used at all. The recommended approach endorsed today by the [[Academy of the Hebrew Language]] and other Israeli educational institutions is to use ''plÄ“nÄ“'' spelling (''matres lectionis'') when not adding vowel dots (which is the usual case), and place a vocalization sign on a letter only when ambiguity cannot be resolved otherwise. The [[defective script|"defective" spelling]] is recommended for a fully vocalized text, hence its use is becoming rare. Texts older than 50â€“60 years may be written in an unvocalized ''defective'' spelling (for example, the word ''Ä§amiÅ¡Ã­m'' "fifty", was written ×—××©×™× on banknotes issued in [[Mandatory Palestine]] or the [[Bank of Israel]] in its early days. Today, the common spelling is ×—××™×©×™×). A vocalized ''plene'' spelling system is common in [[children's books]], when it is better to accustom the children to the more popular ''plene'' spelling, while still letting them benefit from the vowel dots as a reading aid in early learning stages. A third system that was endorsed in the past by the Academy of the Hebrew Language as an optimal system, but abandoned due to low popularity, calls for the use of ''Ä§olÃ¡m'' (×•Ö¹), ''Å¡urÃºq'' (×•Ö¼), ''dagÃ©Å¡'' in ''Bet'', ''Kaf'' and ''Pe'' (×‘Ö¼, ×›Ö¼, ×¤Ö¼ vs. ×‘, ×›, ×¤), ''Å in SmalÃ­t'' (×©×‚) and ''mappÃ­q'' (×”Ö¼), while abandoning all other vowel dots (in everyday writing). According to this system, ''matres lectionis'' are still introduced to mark vowels, but the letter ''Vav'' is used only as a consonant, while its variants ''Ä§olÃ¡m'' and ''Å¡urÃºq'' serve as vowel letters. This system also makes clear distinction between final ''He'' used as a vowel marker (e.g. ×™×œ×“×” {{IPA|/jalËˆda/}} "a girl" ) and as a consonant (e.g. ×™×œ×“×”Ö¼ {{IPA|/jalËˆdah/}} "her child"). This system was never extensively used, and the Academy of the Hebrew Language finally abandoned it in 1992, when new rules were published not assuming any use of vowel dots. Rules for unvocalized spelling were first issued by the Hebrew Language Committee in 1890 (which became the [[Academy of the Hebrew Language]] in 1953) and formally standardised in 1996. Even though the rules are established, some of the rules and specific spellings are disputed by writers and publishers, who often create their own in-house spelling system. Also, because having two spelling systems within the same language is confusing, some would like to reform it. In 2004, [[Mordechai Mishor]], one of the academy's linguists, proposed in a session of the Academy of the Hebrew Language a modest reform.[http://kdictionaries.com/kdn/kdn12-3spell.html Kernerman Dictionary News â€¢ Number 12 â€¢ July 2004] ==Usage today== There are three systems of spelling used for [[Modern Hebrew]]. #'''Ktiv hasar''' ("missing spelling"): This [[defective script]] may be found in the [[Sefer Torah]] read in [[synagogue]]. It is sometimes considered to be [[anachronism|anachronistic]] in everyday life, although it is still sometimes found in newspapers and published books.{{cite web |url = http://www.articles.co.il/print.php?id=46399 |first = Einat |last = Kedem|publisher = articles.co.il |title=×›×ª×™×‘ ××œ× (×‘×¢×™×•×ª), ×›×ª×™×‘ ×—×¡×¨ (×”×™×’×™×•×Ÿ)}} This is the original Hebrew spelling. It is called the "missing spelling" because it does not use [[niqqud]]. #'''[[Ktiv menuqad]]''' ("dotted spelling" or "vowelized spelling"): This system of spelling is called "vowelized spelling" and "dotted spelling" because unlike "missing spelling," this system shows exactly how the vowels are in addition to using the dots system ("[[niqqud|nekudot]]"). It is rarely used in everyday life. However, it is used wherever someone wants their writings to be clear and unambiguous, such as [[children's books]], poetry, language instruction for newcomers, or ambiguous or foreign terms. However, it is very cumbersome and inconvenient in everyday life. #'''Ktiv male''' or '''[[Ktiv hasar niqqud]]''' ("full spelling" or "spelling lacking niqqud"): This is the dominant system of spelling in Israel, personal correspondence, movie subtitles, etc. Ktiv Male is created to be a niqqud-less spelling that uses ''matres lectionis'' (consonant that are also used as vowels: [[aleph]], [[He (letter)|he]], waw, yodh) instead of the vowel pointers. ===Examples=== {| class="wikitable" |- style="text-align: center;" |- ! colspan="2" | Word ! rowspan="2" | Ktiv haser ! rowspan="2" | Ktiv menuqad ! rowspan="2" | Ktiv male (Ktiv haser niqqud) |- !English!!IPA |- | courage | {{IPA|/ËˆË€omets/}} | {{Hebrew|×××¥}} | {{Hebrew|×Ö¹×Ö¶×¥}} | {{Hebrew|××•××¥}} |- | air | {{IPA|/aËˆvir/}} | {{Hebrew|××•×™×¨}} 1 | {{Hebrew|×Ö²×•Ö´×™×¨}} | {{Hebrew|××•×•×™×¨}} |- | distribution | {{IPA|/Ä§aluËˆqa/}} | {{Hebrew|×—×œ×§×”}} 2 | {{Hebrew|×—Ö²×œÖ»×§Ö¸Ö¼×”}} | {{Hebrew|×—×œ×•×§×”}} |- | two | {{IPA|/ËˆÊƒnajim/}} | {{Hebrew|×©× ×™×}} 3 | {{Hebrew|×©Ö°×× Ö·×™Ö´×}} | {{Hebrew|×©× ×™×™×}} |} To illustrate the problem with Ktiv haser:
1 spelled the same as {{Hebrew|××•×™×¨}} - {{IPA|/U'jar/}} = "was drawn" - in Ktiv menuqad {{Hebrew|××•Ö¼×™Ö¸×¨}}
2 spelled the same as {{Hebrew|×—×œ×§×”}} - {{IPA|/Ä§elËˆqa/}} = "land plot" - in Ktiv menuqad {{Hebrew|×—Ö¶×œÖ°×§Ö·×”}}
3 spelled the same as {{Hebrew|×©× ×™×}} - {{IPA|/ËˆÊƒanim/}} = "years" - in Ktiv menuqad {{Hebrew|×©Ö¸×× Ö´×™×}} ==Usage of multiple systems== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | header = Examples | header_align = left/right/center | header_background = | footer = | footer_align = left/right/center | footer_background = | width = | image1 = Kosher McDonalds.JPG | width1 = 235 | caption1 = A kosher (×”×›×©×¨ "the Kosher") [[McDonald's]], with the word kosher spelled without niqqud. | image2 = Kosher McDonald's restaurant in Ramat-Gan.jpg | width2 = 205 | caption2 = Another kosher (×”×›Ö¼×©×¨ "the Kosher") McDonald's, with the word kosher spelled with partial niqqud to reduce ambiguity. }} In practice, many times two or more spelling systems are used in one text. The most common example of this is a word may be vowelized (using [[niqqud]], the "dots") partially, for instance with {{Hebrew|××•Ö¹××¥}}, where only the vav ({{Hebrew|×•}}) is vowelized. This clarifies that the vowel is an "o" ({{Hebrew|×•Ö¹}}) and not "u" ({{Hebrew|×•Ö¼}}). In addition, 3 letters (historically 6), can take a different sound depending on if there is a dot (called a [[dagesh]]) in the middle of the letter (a [[bet (letter)|bet]], [[Kaph|kaf]], and [[Pe (letter)|pe]]). In full spelling, the dot is not included, regardless if it is making one sound or the other. An example when a mixture of systems would be used is to clarify when the letter is taking a dagesh. An example of this is shown in the adjacent picture, where for the word kosher ({{Hebrew|×›Ö¸Ö¼×©Öµ××¨}} (with niqqud), {{hebrew|×›×©×¨}} (full spelling), {{IPA|/kaËˆÊƒer/}}) may be written as ×›Ö¼×©×¨ (a mixture of the two systems) to be unambiguous that it is the letter ×›Ö¼ {{IPA-he|k|}} and not ×› {{IPA-he|Ï‡|}}. Words may be written in ''ktiv haser'' ("missing spelling") if it is unambiguous and clear enough (ex. ×—× ×›×” {{IPA|/[[Hanukkah|Ä§anuËˆka]]/}} instead of the "full" form ×—× ×•×›×”). In this case, the reader deciphers the word mostly by its context. Also, some words are almost always written in the "missing" form (''ktiv haser'') in everyday life: ×œ× ({{IPA|/lo/}}, no), ××× ({{IPA|/ima/}}, mother), ×× ({{IPA|/im/}}, if), and ×›× ×¨×ª ({{IPA|/kiËˆneret/}}, [[Kinneret (archaeological site)|Kinneret]]). ==See also== *[[Hebrew grammar]] ==References== {{Hebrew language}} [[Category:Hebrew language]] [[Category:Hebrew alphabet]] [[Category:Language orthographies]]

{{about|the Semitic letter}} {{Phoenician glyph |letname=Het |previouslink=Zayin |previousletter=Zayin |nextlink=Teth |nextletter=Tet |archar={{Lang|ar|Ø­}} |sychar=Üš |hechar= ×— |amchar=heht |gechar= |phchar=heth |grchar={{lang|grc|Î—}} |lachar=H |cychar=Ğ˜ Ğ™ |ipa=[[Ä§ (IPA)|Ä§]] ([[Ï‡ (IPA)|Ï‡]], [[x (IPA)|x]]) |num=8 |gem=8}} '''{{Transl|sem|á¸¤et}}''' or '''HÌ±et''' (also spelled '''Khet''', '''Kheth''', '''Chet''', '''Cheth''', '''Het''', or '''Heth''') is the eighth [[Letter (alphabet)|letter]] of the [[Semitic abjads]], including [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician]] á¸¤Ä“t [[File:phoenician heth.png|10px]], [[Hebrew alphabet|Hebrew]] á¸¤Ä“th {{Hebrew|×—}}, [[Aramaic alphabet|Aramaic]] á¸¤Ä“th [[File:Heth.svg| 10 px]], [[Syriac alphabet|Syriac]] á¸¤Ä“á¹¯ Üš, [[Arabic alphabet|Arabic]] á¸¤Ä' {{Lang|ar|Ø­}}, [[Maltese alphabet|Maltese]] Ä¦, Ä§. Heth originally represented a voiceless fricative, either [[voiceless pharyngeal fricative|pharyngeal]] {{IPA|/Ä§/}}, or [[voiceless velar fricative|velar]] {{IPA|/x/}}. In Arabic, two corresponding letters were created for both phonemic sounds: unmodified ''{{Transl|ar|DIN|á¸¥ÄÊ¾}}'' {{Lang|ar|Ø­}} represents {{IPA|/Ä§/}}, while ''{{Transl|ar|DIN|[[á¸«ÄÊ¾]]}}'' {{Lang|ar|Ø®}} represents {{IPA|/x/}}. The Phoenician letter gave rise to the [[Greek alphabet|Greek]] [[eta]] {{lang|el|Î—}}, [[Etruscan alphabet|Etruscan]] [[File:EtruscanH-01.png|14px|H]], [[Latin alphabet|Latin]] [[H]] and [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]] [[I (Cyrillic)|Ğ˜]]. While H is a consonant in the Latin alphabet, the Greek and Cyrillic equivalents represent [[vowel]] sounds. ==Origins== The letter shape ultimately goes back to the [[Egyptian hieroglyphs|Egyptian hieroglyph]] for "courtyard", O6 Possibly named {{Transl|sem|á¸¥asir}} in the [[Proto-Sinaitic script]]. The corresponding [[South Arabian alphabet|South Arabian letters]] are [[File:himjar ha2.PNG|14px|á¸¥]] á¸¥ and [[File:himjar kha.PNG|14px|á¸«]] á¸«, corresponding to the [[Ge'ez script|Ge'ez letters]] {{Transl|sem|á¸¤awá¹­}} áˆ and {{Transl|sem|á¸ªarm}} áŠ€. This letter is usually transcribed as ''á¸¥'', h with a dot underneath. In some romanization systems, a capital H is also used. The latter method has the advantage of being easy to type on a computer. ==Arabic á¸¥ÄÊ¾== {{see also|Ø®}} The letter is named {{lang|ar|Ø­Ø§Ø¡}} ''{{Transl|ar|DIN|á¸¥ÄÊ¾}}'' and is the sixth letter of the alphabet. Its shape varies depending on its position in the word: {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Ø­}} This form is used to denote two letters, the second being {{lang|ar|Ø®}} [[á¸«ÄÊ¾]]. ===Pronunciation=== In Arabic, {{transl|ar|DIN|á¸¥ÄÊ¾}} is similar to the [[English language|English]] {{IPAblink|h}}, but it is much "raspier",{{cite book|last=Bouchentouf|first=Amine|title=Arabic for Dummies|year=2006|publisher=Wiley Publishing, Inc|page=15}} IPA: {{IPAblink|Ä§}}~{{IPAblink|Êœ}}. In Persian, it is {{IPAblink|h}}, like {{angbr|{{lang|fa|[[ï»«]]}}}} and the English ''h''. ==Hebrew á¸¤et== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" ! colspan="5" |[[Orthography|Orthographic]] variants |- ! colspan="3" |Various print fonts ! rowspan="2" |[[Cursive Hebrew|Cursive
Hebrew]] ! rowspan="2" |[[Rashi script|Rashi
script]] |- !|Serif !! [[Sans-serif]] !! [[Monospaced]] |- | width="20%" |×— | width="20%" |×— | width="20%" |×— | width="20%" |[[File:Hebrew letter Het handwriting.svg|24px]] | width="20%" |[[File:Hebrew letter Het Rashi.png|35px]] |} Hebrew spelling: {{Script/Hebrew|×—Öµ×™×ª}} ===Pronunciation=== In [[Modern Hebrew|Modern Israeli Hebrew]] (and [[Ashkenazi Hebrew]], although not under strict pronunciation), the letter á¸¤et ({{Hebrew|×—Öµ×™×ª}}) usually has the sound value of a [[voiceless uvular fricative]] ({{IPA|/Ï‡/}}), as the historical phonemes of the letters {{Transl|sem|á¸¤et}} ×— ({{IPA|/Ä§/}}) and {{Transl|sem|[[Kaph|Khaf]]}} ×› ({{IPA|/x/}}) merged, both becoming the voiceless uvular fricative ({{IPA|/Ï‡/}}). In more rare phonologies, it is pronounced as a [[voiceless pharyngeal fricative]] ({{IPA|/Ä§/}}) and is still among [[Mizrahi Jews]] (especially among the older generation and popular [[Mizrahi music|Mizrahi singers]], mostly [[Yemenite Jews]]), in accordance with oriental Jewish traditions (see, e.g., [[Mizrahi Hebrew]] and [[Yemenite Hebrew]]). The ability to pronounce the Arabic letter ''{{Transl|ar|DIN|á¸¥ÄÊ¾}}'' ({{lang|ar|Ø­}}) correctly as a [[voiceless pharyngeal fricative]] {{IPA|/Ä§/}} is often used as a [[shibboleth]] to distinguish [[Varieties of Arabic|Arabic]]-speakers from non-Arabic-speakers; in particular, pronunciation of the letter as {{IPAslink|x}} is seen as a hallmark of [[Ashkenazi Jews]] and [[Romaniote Jews|Greek Jews]]. ''á¸¤et'' is one of the few Hebrew consonants that can take a vowel at the end of a word. This occurs when [[Niqqud|patach gnuva]] comes under the á¸¤et at the end of the word. The combination is then pronounced {{IPA|/-aÏ‡/}} rather than {{IPA|/-Ï‡a/}}. For example: ×¤×ª×•×— ({{IPA|/ËŒpaËˆtuaÏ‡/}}), and ×ª×¤×•×— ({{IPA|/ËŒtaËˆpuaÏ‡/}}). ===Variations=== á¸¤et, along with [[Aleph (Hebrew)|Aleph]], [[Ayin]], [[Resh]], and [[He (letter)|He]], cannot receive a [[dagesh]]. As pharyngeal fricatives are difficult for most English speakers to pronounce, loanwords are usually Anglicized to have {{IPA|/h/}}. Thus ''challah'' (×—×œ×”), pronounced by native Hebrew speakers as {{IPA|/Ï‡ala/}} or {{IPA|/Ä§ala/}} is pronounced {{IPA|/halÉ™/}} by most English speakers, who cannot often perceive the difference between {{IPAblink|h}} and {{IPAblink|Ä§}}. ===Significance=== In [[gematria]], á¸¤et represents the number eight. In [[chat rooms]], [[Internet forum|online forums]], and [[Social networking service|social networking]] the letter á¸¤et repeated (×—×—×—×—×—×—×—×—×—×—) denotes laughter, just as in English, in the saying 'Haha'. ==Character encodings== {{charmap |05D7|name1=Hebrew Letter Het |062D|name2=Arabic Letter Hah |071A|name3=Syriac Letter Heth |0807|name4=Samaritan Letter Hit }} {{charmap |10388|name1=Ugaritic Letter Hota |10847|name2=Imperial Aramaic Letter Heth |10907|name3=Phoenician Letter Het }} ==See also== *Ä¦, Ä§ : [[H with stroke]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|×—}} {{Arabic language}} {{Hebrew language}} {{Northwest Semitic abjad}} [[Category:Phoenician alphabet]] [[Category:Arabic letters]] [[Category:Hebrew alphabet]]

pages.title: History of the Hebrew alphabet
pages.text:
[[Image:Aleppo Codex Joshua 1 1.jpg|300px|thumb|[[Aleppo Codex]]: 10th century [[Hebrew Bible]] with [[Masoretic]] pointing]] [[Image:Page from Yiddish-Hebrew-Latin-German dictionary by Elijah Levita.jpg|200px|thumb|right|A page from a 16th-century [[Yiddish]]-[[Hebrew language|Hebrew]]-[[Latin]]-[[German language|German]] dictionary by [[Elijah Levita]]]] The '''[[history]] of the [[Hebrew alphabet]]''' spans several thousand years. ==History== According to contemporary scholars, [[Paleo-Hebrew alphabet|the original Hebrew script]] developed alongside others in the region (the region is the Land of Cannan and Arabia) during the course of the late second and first millennia BCE; it is closely related to the [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician script]], which itself probably gave rise to the use of alphabetic writing in [[Greece]] ([[Greek alphabet|Greek]]). It is sometimes claimed that around the 10th century BCE{{Cite web|url=http://www.godandscience.org/apologetics/tel-zayit.html|title=Early (10th Century B.C.) Evidence of Written Hebrew Language at Tel Zayit, Israel|last=Deem|first=Rich|date=June 2006|website=God And Science.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=http://mnamon.sns.it/index.php?page=Esempi&id=8&lang=en#120|title=Hebrew - (12th century BC? - today)|last=|first=|date=|website=Mnamon Ancient writing systems in the Mediterranean A critical guide to electronic resources|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.biblicalarchaeology.org/daily/biblical-artifacts/inscriptions/the-oldest-hebrew-script-and-language/|title=The Oldest Hebrew Script and Language|last=Rollston|first=Christopher|date=April 2018|website=Biblical Archaeology Society|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/11/09/world/middleeast/a-is-for-ancient-describing-an-alphabet-found-near.html|title=A Is for Ancient, Describing an Alphabet Found Near Jerusalem|last=NOBLE WILFORD|first=JOHN|date=November 2005|website=The New York Times|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} a distinct Hebrew variant, the original "Hebrew script", emerged, which was widely used in the ancient kingdoms of [[Kingdom of Israel (Samaria)|Israel]] and [[Kingdom of Judah|Judah]] until they fell in the 8th and 6th centuries BCE, respectively. It is not straightforward, however, to distinguish [[Israelite]]/[[Judahite]] scripts from others which were in use in the immediate area, most notably by the [[Moabites]] and [[Ammon]]ites. Following the [[Babylonian captivity of Judah|Babylonian exile]], [[Jew]]s gradually stopped using the Hebrew script, and instead adopted the "square" [[Aramaic script]] (another offshoot of the same family of scripts). This script, used for writing Hebrew, later evolved into the Jewish, or "square" script, that is still used today.[http://jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?artid=1308&letter=A&search=Alphabet#3531 Jewish Encyclopedia: Alphabet, The Hebrew: Samaritan Alphabet]: "While the Jews adopted the Aramaic alphabet, gradually abandoning their own, the Samaritans held fast to the original forms, in order to show themselves the veritable heirs of ancient Hebraism. ... It is the same character used in all the Samaritan books of to-day, and remains the only offshoot of the old Hebrew script extant, while the modern Hebrew Alphabet is of Aramaic origin." Closely related scripts were in use all over the Middle East for several hundred years, but following the rise of [[Christianity]] (and later, the rise of [[Islam]]), they gave way to the [[Latin script|Latin]] and [[Arabic alphabet|Arabic]] scripts, respectively. The Hebrew alphabet was later adapted in order to write down the languages of the [[Jewish diaspora]] ([[Karaim language|Karaim]], [[Judeo-Arabic language|JudÃ¦o-Arabic]], [[Ladino language|Ladino]], [[Yiddish language|Yiddish]], etc.), and was retained all the while in relatively unadapted form throughout the diaspora for Hebrew, which remained the language of Jewish law, scriptures and scholarship. The Hebrew alphabet was also retained as the alphabet used for writing down the [[Hebrew language]] during its [[revival of the Hebrew language|rebirth]] as an everyday modern language starting in the 18th to 19th century. According to one Jewish tradition,{{cite web|year=2002 |title = The Script of the Torah |publisher=Aishdas |location=Jerusalem, Israel |url=http://www.aishdas.org/toratemet/en_pamphlet9.html}}, Sanhedrin 21b-22a however, the block script seen today in Hebrew Torah Scrolls, known as [[Ashuri alphabet|Kthav Ashurith]], was the original Hebrew script carved into the [[Ten Commandments]].''[[Talmud|Babylonian Talmud]]'', Tractate Shabbat 104a, Tractate Megilla 2b. "Rav Chisda says that the (final) mem and samech in the tablets were miraculously hanging in the air." This can only happen in Kthav Ashurith and not in Kthav Ivri. According to this opinion, the Ktav Ashurith was lost over time, as the masses used [[Paleo-Hebrew alphabet|Paleo-Hebrew]] and its cousins, known as Kthav Ivri, for day to day writing, just as Jews today use a non block script for everyday writing.''[[Talmud|Babylonian Talmud]]'', Tractate Megilla 3a. According to the Talmud, the original script was known as Lebonae and was associated with the Samaritan community who continued to preserve the script even after the Jews switched to Ashurith.Klein, Reuven Chaim, ''[https://www.amazon.com/Lashon-HaKodesh-History-Holiness-Hebrew/dp/1937887367/ Lashon HaKodesh: History, Holiness, & Hebrew]''. [[Shva]]{{Â·}}[[Hiriq]]{{Â·}}[[Tzere]]{{Â·}}[[Segol]]{{Â·}}[[Patach]]{{Â·}}[[Kamatz]]{{Â·}}Holam{{Â·}}[[Dagesh]]{{Â·}}[[Mappiq]]{{Â·}}[[Shuruk]]{{Â·}}[[Kubutz]]{{Â·}}[[Rafe]]{{Â·}}[[Shin dot|Sin/Shin Dot]] |} '''Cholam''' ({{lang-he-n|×—×•Ö¹×œÖ¸×}} ''{{transl|he|á¸¥olam}}'', [[Modern Hebrew]]: {{IPA-he|Ä§oËˆlam|}}, [[Biblical Hebrew]]: {{IPA-he|Ä§oËˆlam|}}) is a [[Hebrew alphabet|Hebrew]] [[niqqud]] [[vowel]] sign represented by a dot above the upper left corner of the consonant letter. For example, here the ''Cholam'' appears after the letter ''[[Mem (letter)|mem]]'' {{angle bracket|{{Hebrew|×}}}}‎: {{Hebrew|×Ö¹}}. In [[modern Hebrew]] it indicates the [[mid back rounded vowel]], {{IPAblink|oÌ}}, and is [[Romanization of Hebrew|transliterated]] as an ''o''. The [[mater lectionis]] letter which is usually employed with ''Cholam'' is [[Vav (letter)|vav]], although in a few words, the letters ''{{transl|he|[[aleph|alef]]}}'' or ''{{transl|he|[[He (letter)|he]]}}'' are used instead of ''{{transl|he|vav}}''. When it is used with a mater lectionis, the '' Cholam'' is called ''Cholam malei'' (Modern: {{IPA-he|Ä§oËˆlam maËˆle|}}, Biblical: {{IPA-he|Ä§oËˆlam maËˆle|}}, "full {{transl|he|á¸¥olam}}"), and without it the ''Cholam'' is called ''Cholam chaser'' (Modern: {{IPA-he|Ä§oËˆlam Ä§aËˆser|}}, Biblical: {{IPA-he|Ä§oËˆlam Ä§aËˆser|}}). ==Appearance== Cholam without ''mater lectionis'' after it or with the letter He, as in {{Hebrew|×¤Ö¹Ö¼×”}} ({{IPA|/po/}}, "here"), is written as a dot above the upper left corner of the letter after which it is pronounced. [[Letter-spacing]] is not supposed to be affected by it, although some buggy computer fonts may add an unneeded space before the next letter. [[File:Dor-Doar.svg|150px|thumb|left|In the word {{Hebrew|×“Ö¹Ö¼××¨}}, the Biblical Hebrew spelling of the name [[Tel Dor|Dor]], the ''{{transl|he|alef}}'' is a ''mater lectionis'', and in traditional typography the Holam is written above the {{transl|he|alef}}'s right arm. In the word {{Hebrew|×“Ö¹Ö¼×Ö·×¨}} ({{IPA|/Ëˆdo.aÊ/}}, "mail"), the ''{{transl|he|alef}}'' is a consonant (a [[glottal stop]]), under which appears the vowel ''{{transl|he|[[patah|pataá¸¥]]}}'', so the ''{{transl|he|á¸¥olam}}'' is written above the previous letter's upper left corner. Not all fonts actually implement these placement rules, however.]] If the ''mater lectionis'' is ''{{transl|he|vav}}'', the ''Cholam'' appears above the ''{{transl|he|vav}}''. If the ''mater lectionis'' is ''{{transl|he|alef}}'', as in {{Hebrew|×œÖ¹×}} ({{IPA|/lo/}}, "no"), it is supposed to appear above the {{transl|he|alef}}'s right hand, although this is not implemented in all computer fonts, and does not always appear even in professionally typeset modern books, so ''Cholam'' with ''{{transl|he|alef}}'' may, in fact, appear in the same place as a regular ''Cholam chaser''. If the ''{{transl|he|alef}}'' itself is not a ''mater lectionis'', but a consonant, the ''Cholam'' appears in its regular place above the upper left corner of the previous letter, as in {{Hebrew|×ªÖ¹Ö¼×Ö·×¨}} ({{IPA|/Ëˆto.aÊ/}}, "epithet"). If ''Cholam chaser'' is written after ''{{transl|he|vav}}'', as in {{Hebrew|×œÖ´×’Ö°×•Öº×¢Ö·}} ({{IPA|/liÉ¡Ëˆvo.a/}}, "to agonize"), it may appear above the ''{{transl|he|vav}}'', or slightly further to the left; this varies between different fonts. In some fonts Holam merges with the Shin dot, in words such as {{script/Hebrew|×—Ö¹×©Ö¶××šÖ°}} ({{IPA|/ËˆÄ§oÊƒeÏ‡/}}, 'darkness') or with the Sin dot, as in {{script/Hebrew|×©Ö¹×‚×‘Ö·×¢}} ({{IPA|/Ëˆsova/}}, 'satiation'). (These dots may or may not appear merged on your screen, as that depends on your device's Hebrew font.) ==Usage== ''Cholam malei'' is, in general, the most common way to write the {{IPA|/o/}} sound in modern spelling with niqqud. If a word has ''Cholam malei'' in spelling with niqqud, the ''[[mater lectionis]]'' letter ''{{transl|he|vav}}'' is without any exception retained in spelling without niqqud, both according to the spelling rules of the [[Academy of the Hebrew Language]] and in common practice. The use of ''Cholam chaser'' is restricted to certain word patterns, although many common words appear in them. In most cases the Academy's spelling rules mandate that the ''{{transl|he|vav}}'' will be written even when the spelling with niqqud does not have it. The normative exceptions from this rule are listed below. It must also be noted that the Academy's standard is not followed perfectly by all speakers, and common deviations from it are also noted below. In Biblical Hebrew the above rules are not followed consistently, and sometimes the ''{{transl|he|vav}}'' is omitted or added.''Academy Decisions: Grammar, 2nd edition'', Â§1.3; {{Cite GHG|8|l|nologo=1}} For further complications involving ''Kamatz katan'' and ''Hataf kamatz'', see the article [[Kamatz]]. ===Holam chaser which is written as ''{{transl|he|vav}}'' in text without niqqud=== :''For details on the transcription of Hebrew, see [[Help:IPA/Hebrew]] and [[Modern Hebrew phonology|Hebrew phonology]] * In words, in which the penultimate syllable has the vowel {{IPA|/o/}} and is stressed (sometimes called ''[[segolate]]''): ** {{script/Hebrew|×§Ö¹×˜Ö¶×¨}} ('diameter') {{IPA|/ËˆkoteÊ/}} ** {{script/Hebrew|×–Ö¹×”Ö·×¨}} ('radiance', ''[[Zohar]]''), {{IPA|/ËˆzohaÊ/}} ** {{script/Hebrew|× Ö¹×’Ö·×”Ö¼}} ('brightness', ''Nogah''), {{IPA|/noËˆÉ¡a/}} ** {{script/Hebrew|×“Ö¹Ö¼×Ö·×¨}} ('mail'), {{IPA|/Ëˆdo.aÊ/}} or {{IPA|/ËˆdoÊ”aÊ/}}. : Some people tend to spell some of these words without the ''{{transl|he|vav}}'', e.g. ×“××¨ instead of ×“×•××¨, although the Academy mandates ×“×•××¨. The tendency is especially strong when the words can be used as personal names. * When ''Kubutz'' is changed to ''Holam'' before guttural letters in the passive [[binyan]] Pual due to ''tashlum dagesh'' (a vowel-change due to the inability of guttural letters to carry a [[dagesh]]): ** {{script/Hebrew|×Ö°×¤Ö¹×Ö¸×¨}} ('fancy'), {{IPA|/mÉ™foËˆÊ”aÊ/}} ** {{script/Hebrew|×¤Ö¹Ö¼×¨Ö·×©×}} ('was explained'), {{IPA|/poËˆÊaÊƒ/}}. Without niqqud: ××¤×•××¨‎, ×¤×•×¨×©. * In words which have the pattern /CaCoC/ in the singular and become /CÉ™CuCCim/ with Kubutz in the plural, especially names of colors: ** {{script/Hebrew|×›Ö¸Ö¼×ªÖ¹×}} ('orange'), {{IPA|/kaËˆtom/}}, pl. {{script/Hebrew|×›Ö°Ö¼×ªÖ»×Ö´Ö¼×™×}} {{IPA|/kÉ™tumËˆmim/}} ** {{script/Hebrew|×¢Ö¸×’Ö¹×œ}} ('round'), {{IPA|/Ê•aËˆÉ¡ol/}}, pl. {{script/Hebrew|×¢Ö²×’Ö»×œÖ´Ö¼×™×}} {{IPA|/Ê•aÉ¡ulËˆlim/}}. * When the last letter of the [[Semitic root|root]] is guttural, ''Cholam chaser'' is preserved due to ''tashlum dagesh'': ** {{ script/Hebrew|×©Ö¸××—Ö¹×¨}} ('black'), {{IPA|/ÊƒaËˆÄ§oÊ/}}, pl. {{script/Hebrew|×©Ö°××—Ö¹×¨Ö´×™×}} {{IPA|/ÊƒÉ™Ä§oËˆÊim/}}. *: Without niqqud: ×›×ª×•×‎, ×›×ª×•××™×‎, ×¢×’×•×œ‎, ×¢×’×•×œ×™×‎, ×©×—×•×¨‎, ×©×—×•×¨×™×‎. * A similar pattern, in which the last letter of the root is not doubled in declination, has ''Cholam malei'' in the base form, which is preserved in declination: ** sg. {{script/Hebrew|×’Ö¸Ö¼×“×•Ö¹×œ}} ('big'), {{IPA|/É¡aËˆdol/}}, pl. {{script/Hebrew|×’Ö°Ö¼×“×•Ö¹×œÖ´×™×}} {{IPA|/É¡É™doËˆlim/}}. * In three words ''Cholam malei'' is changed to ''[[shuruk]]'' in declination: ** {{script/Hebrew|×Ö¸×’×•Ö¹×¨}} ('place of living'), {{IPA|/maËˆÉ¡oÊ/}}, pl. {{script/Hebrew|×Ö°×’×•Ö¼×¨Ö´×™×}} {{IPA|/mÉ™É¡uËˆÊim/}}Rarely used in the singular in Modern Hebrew. ** {{script/Hebrew|×Ö¸× ×•Ö¹×¡}} ('escape'), {{IPA|/maËˆnos/}}, pl. {{script/Hebrew|×Ö°× ×•Ö¼×¡Ö´×™×}} {{IPA|/mÉ™nuËˆsim/}};Rarely used in the plural in Modern Hebrew. ** {{script/Hebrew|×Ö¸×ª×•Ö¹×§}} ('sweet'), {{IPA|/maËˆtok/}}, pl. {{script/Hebrew|×Ö°×ª×•Ö¼×§Ö´×™×}} {{IPA|/mÉ™tuËˆkim/}}.''Academy Decisions: Grammar, 2nd edition'', Â§1.3. * Similar to the above is the pattern /CÉ™CaCCoC/, with [[reduplication]] of the second and third letters of the [[Semitic root|root]]: ** {{script/Hebrew|×¤Ö°Ö¼×ªÖ·×œÖ°×ªÖ¹Ö¼×œ}} ('crooked'), {{IPA|/pÉ™talËˆtol/}}, pl. {{script/Hebrew|×¤Ö°Ö¼×ªÖ·×œÖ°×ªÖ»Ö¼×œÖ´Ö¼×™×}} {{IPA|/pÉ™taltulËˆlim/}}. Without niqqud: ×¤×ª×œ×ª×•×œ‎, ×¤×ª×œ×ª×•×œ×™×. * In the future, infinitive and imperative forms of most verbs in [[binyan]] Qal: ** {{script/Hebrew|×Ö¶×¡Ö°×’Ö¹Ö¼×¨}} ('I shall close'), {{IPA|/Ê”esËˆÉ¡oÊ/}}, {{script/Hebrew|×œÖ´×¡Ö°×’Ö¹Ö¼×¨}} ('to close'), {{IPA|/lisËˆÉ¡oÊ/}}, {{script/Hebrew|×¡Ö°×’Ö¹×¨}} ('close!'), {{IPA|/sÉ™É¡oÊ/}}. Despite this, some people occasionally omit the ''{{transl|he|vav}}'' in some of those words and spell ×¨×‘‎, ×ª×£ etc. * Several common words are spelled with ''Cholam chaser'' in the Bible, but the Academy mandates that they be spelled with ''Cholam malei'' in modern Hebrew, among them: ** {{script/Hebrew|×›Ö¹Ö¼×—Ö·/×›Ö¼×•Ö¹×—Ö·}} ('force'), {{IPA|/ËˆkoaÄ§/}} ** {{script/Hebrew|×Ö¹×—Ö·/××•Ö¹×—Ö·}} ('brain'), {{IPA|/ËˆmoaÄ§/}} ** {{script/Hebrew|×™Ö·×”Ö²×œÖ¹×/×™Ö·×”Ö²×œ×•Ö¹×}} ('a precious stone', in modern Hebrew 'diamond'), {{IPA|/jahaËˆlom/}} ** {{script/Hebrew|×Ö°×Ö¹×“/×Ö°××•Ö¹×“}} ('very'), {{IPA|/mÉ™Ê”od/}} ** {{script/Hebrew |×¤Ö´Ö¼×ªÖ°×Ö¹×/×¤Ö´Ö¼×ªÖ°××•Ö¹×}}‎ ('suddenly'), {{IPA|/pitËˆÊ”om/}} *: Some people still spell them without ''{{transl|he|vav}}'', but the standard spelling is with ''{{transl|he|vav}}''.The full list appears at ''Academy Decisions: Grammar, 2nd edition'', Â§1.3. * The participle of most verbs in [[binyan]] Qal is often written with ''Cholam chaser'' in the Bible, but always with ''Cholam malei'' in modern Hebrew. ** For example, in the Bible appear both {{script/Hebrew|×—Ö¹×–Ö¶×”}} and {{script/Hebrew|×—×•Ö¹×–Ö¶×”}} ('seer'), {{IPA|/Ä§oËˆze/}}, but in modern Hebrew only {{script/Hebrew|×—×•Ö¹×–Ö¶×”}}. ===Holam with other matres lectionis=== * The most common occasion for not writing the {{IPA|/o/}} sound as a ''{{transl|he|vav}}'' in text without niqqud is when in text with niqqud the ''[[mater lectionis]]'' is [[Aleph|Alef]] (×) or [[He (letter)|He]] (×”) instead of ''{{transl|he|vav}}''. In the Bible some words are irregularly and inconsistently spelled with ×” as a [[mater lectionis]]: ** {{script/Hebrew|×–Ö¹×”}}‎ alongside {{script/Hebrew|×–×•Ö¹}}‎, e.g. {{script/Hebrew|×‘ÖµÖ¼×™×ªÖ¹×”}} alongside {{script/Hebrew|×‘ÖµÖ¼×™×ª×•Ö¹}}‎, etc. *: but the number of these irregularities was brought to minimum in modern Hebrew. * In the future forms of several verbs whose [[Semitic root|root]]s' first letter is [[Aleph|Alef]]: ** {{script/Hebrew|×ªÖ¹Ö¼××›Ö·×œ}} ('you shall eat'), {{IPA|/toËˆÏ‡al/}}, root ×Ö¾×›Ö¾×œ‎, without niqqud ×ª××›×œ. ** The prefix of the first person singular is itself Alef and in spelling with niqqud only one Alef is written: {{script/Hebrew|×Ö¹×Ö·×¨}} ('I shall say'), {{IPA|/Ê”oËˆmaÊ/}}, root ×Ö¾×Ö¾×¨, and in spelling without niqqud a ''{{transl|he|vav}}'' ''is'' added: ××•××¨. This always happens in the roots ×Ö¾×‘Ö¾×“ ('perish'), ×Ö¾×‘Ö¾×™ ('wish'),Rare in modern Hebrew. ×Ö¾×›Ö¾×œ ('eat'), ×Ö¾×Ö¾×¨ ('say'), ××¤×™ ('bake') and less consistently in the roots ×Ö¾×”Ö¾×‘ ('love'), ×Ö¾×—Ö¾×– ('hold'), ×Ö¾×¡Ö¾×£ ('collect'), ×Ö¾×ªÖ¾×™ ('come'). In the root ×Ö¾×Ö¾×¨ a ''Holam male'' with ''{{transl|he|vav}}'' is used in the infinitive in [[Mishnaic Hebrew|Mishnaic]] and modern Hebrew: ** {{script/Hebrew|×œ×•Ö¹×Ö·×¨}}‎ {{IPA|/loËˆmaÊ/}}.{{Cite GHG|68|nologo=1}}; the [[Even-Shoshan Dictionary]] for the modern forms. * In the infinitive form of a small number of verbs whose [[Semitic root|root]]s' last letter is [[Aleph|Alef]]: {{script/Hebrew|×‘Ö´Ö¼×Ö°×œÖ¹××ª}} ('upon becoming full'), {{IPA|/bimËˆlot/}}, root ×Ö¾×œÖ¾×‎.''Academy Decisions: Grammar, 2nd edition'', Â§3.5. * In the following words the mater lectionis is always Alef (×‎): ** {{script/Hebrew|×–Ö¹××ª}} ('this' fem.), {{IPA|/zot/}} ** {{script/Hebrew|×œÖ¹×}} ('no'), {{IPA|/lo/}}This word is written ×œ×•Ö¹× several times in the Bible, but such spelling never occurs in modern Hebrew. With the particle {{Hebrew|×”Ö²Ö¾}} ''and only'' when it is used as a synonym of {{Hebrew|×”Ö´× ÖµÖ¼×”}} ('here') it may be written both as ×”×œ×•× and as ×”×œ× (''Academy Decisions: Grammar, 2nd edition'', Â§2.4.4), but this usage is rare in modern Hebrew. ** {{script/Hebrew|×Ö¹××–Ö°× Ö·×™Ö´×}} ('scales'), {{IPA|/mozËˆnajim/}}, without niqqud ×××–× ×™×™×‎ ** {{script/Hebrew|× Ö¹××“}} ('wineskin'), {{IPA|/nod/}}The word {{script|Hebrew|× ×•Ö¹×“}} is pronounced identically and means "wandering". It appears in the Bible and is rare in modern Hebrew. The Even-Shoshan dictionary also notes that it is an incorrect spelling for {{script/Hebrew|× Ö¹××“}}‎. ** {{script/Hebrew|×¦Ö¹××Ÿ}} ('sheep' or 'goats'), {{IPA|/tÍ¡son/}} ** {{script/Hebrew|×¨Ö¹××©×}} ('head'), {{IPA|/ÊoÊƒ/}} ** {{script/Hebrew|×©Ö°×‚×Ö¹××œ}} ('left'), {{IPA|/sÉ™mol/}}This word is actually spelled as ×©×××•×œ several times in the Bible, but never in modern Hebrew. However, the intentionally wrong spelling ×¡××•×œ is often used as a disparaging term for the [[political left]] and is documented in [[Uri Orbach]]'s lexicon of [[Religious Zionist]] slang. * In the following words the ''mater lectionis'' is always He (×”‎): ** {{script/Hebrew|×›Ö¹Ö¼×”}} ('such'), {{IPA|/ko/}} ** {{script/Hebrew|×¤Ö¹Ö¼×”}} ('here'), {{IPA|/po/}} ** {{script/Hebrew|×Öµ×™×¤Ö¹×”}} ('where?'), {{IPA|/eËˆfo/}}The [[Even-Shoshan Dictionary]] also registers the modern Hebrew word {{Hebrew|×Öµ×™×¤Ö¹×©Ö¶××”×•Ö¼}} ('somewhere'), {{IPA|/efoÊƒehu/}}, which is based on {{script/Hebrew|×Öµ×™×¤Ö¹×”}} and Ö¾×©Ö¶××”×•Ö¼‎, the ending of the indefinite pronouns ××©×”×•‎, ×›×œ×©×”×•, ('some'). The Academy has not decided on a standard spelling of this word. * In the ''a enbsolute infinitive'' form of verbs whichd in [[He (letter)|He]]: {{script/Hebrew|×”Ö¸×™Ö¹×”}} ({{IPA|/haËˆjo/}} 'be'). This form is common in the Bible, but in modern Hebrew it is not [[Productivity (linguistics)|productive]] and it is preserved only in fossilized sayings. For example, a common opening for fairy tales, {{script/Hebrew|×”Ö¸×™Ö¹×” ×”Ö¸×™Ö¸×”}} ('there once was'), {{IPA|/haËˆjo haËˆja/}} is written ×”×™×” ×”×™×” without niqqud. ===Cholam without vav in personal names=== Some examples of usage of Cholam without ''{{transl|he|vav}}'' in personal names: * The names ''[[Pharaoh]]'' ({{script/Hebrew|×¤Ö·Ö¼×¨Ö°×¢Ö¹×”}}, {{IPA|/paÊËˆÊ•o/}}), ('[[Moshe]]') ({{script/Hebrew|×Ö¹×©Ö¶××”}}‎)The related participle {{Hebrew|××•Ö¹×©Ö¶××”}} ('pulling out of water') is written with ''{{transl|he|vav}}'' in modern Hebrew. Modern [[diminutive]] forms of Moshe, such as ''Moshiko'' (××•×©×™×§×•) are written with ''{{transl|he|vav}}''. and ''[[Shlomo]]'' ({{script/Hebrew|×©Ö°××œÖ¹×Ö¹×”}}‎)A common modern [[diminutive]] version of this name is regularly spelled ×©×œ×•××™ (''Shlomi''). are never written with ''{{transl|he|vav}}''. ''[[Shiloh (biblical city)|Shilo]]'' ({{script/Hebrew|×©Ö´××™×œÖ¹×”}}) is sometimes written with ''{{transl|he|vav}}'' in the Bible, but always with He in modern Hebrew. Note also that the adjectives {{script/Hebrew|×¤Ö·Ö¼×¨Ö°×¢×•Ö¹× Ö´×™}}‎, {{script/Hebrew|×©Ö´××™×œ×•Ö¹× Ö´×™}} are written with ''{{transl|he|vav}}'' and with a nun in the suffix. * The name ''[[Aharon (given name)|Aharon]]'' ({{script/Hebrew|×Ö·×”Ö²×¨Ö¹×Ÿ}}) is spelled with ''Cholam chaser'' in the Bible. In modern Hebrew both ××”×¨×Ÿ and ××”×¨×•×Ÿ are used. * The name ''[[Noah]]'' ({{script/Hebrew|× Ö¹×—Ö·}}) is spelled with ''Cholam chaser'' in the Bible, but it is sometimes written with the ''{{transl|he|vav}}'' in the MishnaFor example, in ''[[Pirkei Avot|Avot]]'' 5:2 in the [[Kaufmann manuscript]]. and in modern Hebrew. * Several other names of places and people are spelled with Holam and Alef in the Bible include ''[[Yoshiyahu]]'' ({{script/Hebrew|×™Ö¹××©Ö´××™Ö¸Ö¼×”×•Ö¼}}, ''Josiah''), ''[[Tel Dor|Dor]]'' ({{script/Hebrew|×“Ö¹Ö¼××¨}}, in modern Hebrew {{script/Hebrew|×“Ö¼×•Ö¹×¨}}) and ''No Amon'' ({{script/Hebrew|× Ö¹× ×Ö¸××•Ö¹×Ÿ}}, the Hebrew name of [[Thebes, Egypt|Thebes]]). * The word {{script/Hebrew|×›Ö¹Ö¼×”Öµ×Ÿ}} ('priest'), {{IPA|/koËˆhen/}} is spelled with ''Cholam chaser'' in the Bible. It is a common Jewish last name, ''[[Cohen (surname)|Cohen]]''. The Academy mandates ''Cholam malei'' for the noun {{script/Hebrew|×›Ö¼×•Ö¹×”Öµ×Ÿ}}, but allows the omission of ''{{transl|he|vav}}'' for spelling the personal name.''Academy Decisions: Grammar, 2nd edition'', Â§1.3 fn. 55. * Some personal names, such as ''Ohad'' ({{script/Hebrew|×Ö¹×”Ö·×“}}), ''Zohar'' ({{script/Hebrew|×–Ö¹×”Ö·×¨}}) and ''Nogah'' ({{script/Hebrew|× Ö¹×’Ö·×”Ö¼}}), are sometimes spelled without ''{{transl|he|vav}}'' in modern writing without niqqud, although this varies from person to person. * [[God]]'s name ''[[Adonai]]'' ({{script/Hebrew|×Ö²×“Ö¹× Ö¸×™}}) is written with ''Cholam chaser'' to distinguish it from the word "Lord" ({{script/Hebrew|×Ö¸×“×•Ö¹×Ÿ}}) used for humans.According to The [[Brownâ€“Driverâ€“Briggs]] Hebrew Lexicon. When the ''[[Tetragrammaton]]'' is written with niqqud, it follows that of [[Adonai]], so it is written with ''Cholam chaser'', too. For religious reasons writing Adonai and the Tetragrammaton is avoided in modern religious texts except in direct quotes from the Bible. They rarely appear in secular modern Hebrew texts and their spelling there is inconsistent. * The name ''[[Elohim]]'' ({{script/Hebrew|×Ö±×œÖ¹×”Ö´×™×}}) is written with ''Cholam chaser'' in the Bible, although its singular form Eloah ({{script/Hebrew|×Ö±×œ×•Ö¹×”Ö·Ö¼}}) is usually written with ''Cholam malei''. In modern Hebrew ''Elohim'' is a common word for "God" and it is usually spelled with the ''{{transl|he|vav}}'', which is also the Academy's recommendation. ==Pronunciation== The following table contains the [[pronunciation]] and [[transliteration]] of the different ''Cholams'' in reconstructed historical forms and [[dialect]]s using the [[help:IPA|International Phonetic Alphabet]]. '''[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] 259''' is a series of international standards for the [[romanization of Hebrew|romanization]] of [[Hebrew alphabet|Hebrew characters]] into [[Latin alphabet|Latin characters]], dating to 1984, with updated '''ISO 259-2''' (a simplification, disregarding several vowel signs, 1994) and '''ISO 259-3''' ([[Phonemic]] Conversion, 1999).

== ISO 259 ==
ISO 259, dating to 1984, is a [[transliteration]] of the [[Hebrew script]], including the [[diacritic]]al signs (''[[niqqud]]'') used for [[Biblical Hebrew]].

{{ISO 259}}

The ''[[dagesh]]'' (dot inside the letter) is always transcribed with an [[Dot (diacritic)|overdot]]: ''á¸ƒ'', ''Ä¡'', ''Å¼'', etc. The apostrophe (<big>{{Hebrew|×³}}</big>‎) in the table above is the Hebrew sign ''[[geresh]]'' used after some letters to write down non-Hebrew sounds: <big>{{Hebrew|×’×³}}</big> {{IPAblink|dÍ¡Ê’}}, <big>{{Hebrew|×–×³}}</big> {{IPAblink|Ê’}}, <big>{{Hebrew|×¦×³}}</big> {{IPAblink|tÍ¡Êƒ}}, etc.<ref name=ksng>{{Cite web |title=ProtokÃ³Å‚ 74. posiedzenia KSNG |url=http://ksng.gugik.gov.pl/pliki/protokol_ksng/protokol_ksng-74_posiedzenie.pdf#8 |website=KSNG (Commission on Standardization of Geographic Names outside Poland) |date=7 November 2012 |language=Polish |trans-title=Record of the 74th meeting of KSNG}}.</ref>

== ISO 259-2 ==
ISO 259-2 simplifies the diacritical signs for vowels of ISO 259, and is designed for [[Modern Hebrew]].

{{ISO 259-2}}

The ''[[dagesh]]'' is not transcribed excepted in the indicated cases. The apostrophe (<big>{{Hebrew|×³}}</big>‎) in the table above is the Hebrew sign ''[[geresh]]'' used after some letters to write down non-Hebrew sounds.<ref name=ksng/><ref>{{Cite book |title=Regole italiane di catalogazione (REICAT) |trans-title=Italian cataloguing rules |url=http://www.iccu.sbn.it/upload/documenti/REICA_bozza_complessiva_genn2009.pdf#359 |author1=[[Istituto Centrale per il Catalogo Unico|ICCU]] |date=2009 |chapter=Appendice F: Traslitterazione o trascrizione di scritture diverse dallâ€™alfabeto latino â€” 4. Ebraico |isbn=9788871071275 |pages=359â€“360 |language=Italian}}</ref>

== ISO 259-3 ==
ISO 259-3 is [[Uzzi Ornan]]'s romanization, which reached the stage of an [[ISO]] Final Draft ([[FDIS]])<ref>{{cite book |last=Kuzar |first=Ron |date=2001 |title=Hebrew and Zionism: A Discourse Analytic Cultural Study |chapter=[[Canaanism|Canaanite]] alternatives â€” Canaanite linguistic discourse |url={{Google books|gSbgKxtB1HoC|page=274|plainurl=yes}} |location=Berlin & New York |publisher=[[Mouton de Gruyter]] |pages=274â€“275 |isbn=3-11-016993-2}}</ref> but not of a published International Standard (IS).<ref>[http://www.iso.org/iso/home/search/extendedsearchstandards.htm?from_js=true&type=adv&displayResult=true&published=on&development=on&withdrawn=on&deleted=on&formKeyword=&formISO_number=259&formPart_number=&formDocument_type=ALL&formDocument_lang=ALL&formSupp_type=&formICS=&formStage_code=&repost=1&formDate_stage=0&formOther_date=&formCommittee=&formSub_committee=&formSubmit=Search Search for ISO 259] on the [[ISO]] website.</ref> It is designed to deliver the common structure of the Hebrew word throughout the different dialects or pronunciation styles of Hebrew, in a way that it can be reconstructed into the original Hebrew characters by both man and machine.

It is neither a character-by-character [[transliteration]] nor a [[phonetic transcription]] of one pronunciation style of Hebrew, but is instead [[phoneme|phonemic]] from the view point that all the different dialects and pronunciations of Hebrew through the generations can be regarded as different realizations of the same structure, and by predefined reading rules every pronunciation style can be directly derived from it.

{{ISO 259-3}}

Each consonant character in the Hebrew script is converted into its unique Latin character. ISO 259-3 has five [[vowel]] characters, corresponding to the five vowel phonemes of [[Modern Hebrew]]: a, e, i, o, u. In addition there is a sixth sign for denoting the vowel {{IPA|/ej/}} or {{IPAslink|eÌ|e}} that is written followed by âŸ¨<big>{{Hebrew|[[×™]]}}</big>âŸ© in common Hebrew spelling: {{transl|he|ei}}.

The [[Dagesh#Dagesh hazak|dagesh ''forte'']] ([[gemination]] in Biblical Hebrew) is transcribed with a double consonant. Non-[[phonemic]] vowels are ignored, such as:
* [[Shva|schwa]] <big>{{Hebrew|×˜Ö°}}</big>, which is however transcribed with an underscore (_) between two identical consonants in order to distinguish it from a geminate consonant: <big>{{Hebrew|×™Ö°×œÖ¸×“Ö´×™×}}</big> {{IPA|[jeladim]}} "boys" = ''yladim'', <big>{{Hebrew|×”Ö·×œÖ°×œ×•Ö¼×™Ö¸×”Ö¼}}</big> {{IPA|[halelujah]}} "[[Hallelujah]]" = ''hal_luyah'',
* "[[segolate]]" vowel (on the second to last consonant an unaccented vowel <big>{{Hebrew|×˜Ö¶}}</big>, which can also be the vowel <big>{{Hebrew|×—Ö·}}</big> on some [[laryngeal consonants]], or <big>{{Hebrew|×™Ö´}}</big>, etc.) : <big>{{Hebrew|×’Ö¹Ö¼×œÖ¶×}}</big> {{IPA|[golem]}} "[[golem]]" = ''golm'', <big>{{Hebrew|×¦Ö¹×”Ö·×¨}}</big> {{IPA|[tsohar]}} "opening, window" = ''cohr'',
* "furtive" ''[[pataá¸¥]]'' <big>{{Hebrew|×—Ö·}}</big> (an unaccented {{IPA|[a]}} sound before some final laryngeal consonants): <big>{{Hebrew|×¨×•Ö¼×—Ö·}}</big> {{IPA|[Êuax]}} "breeze, spirit" = ''ruá¸¥'', but ISO 259-3 also allows -- (in section 5., "SIMPLIFIED VERSION"<ref name=259-3/>) -- the transcription with ''a'' for non-linguistic purposes: ''ruaá¸¥''.<ref name=259-3>[http://www.cs.technion.ac.il/~ornan/maamarim/taatiq-latini/ISO.doc ISO 259-3]</ref>

{{Unreferenced|date=August 2017}} {| align="right" class="wikitable" | colspan="2" |
'''Qamatz
|- | colspan="2" align="center" style="background:white;height:100px"|Ö¸ |- | [[Help:IPA/Hebrew|IPA]] | style="background:white" | {{IPAblink|Ã¤|a}} or {{IPAblink|Ã¤}} |- | [[Romanization of Hebrew|Transliteration]] | style="background:white" | a |- | English approximation | style="background:white" | f'''a'''r |- | Same sound | style="background:white" | {{transl|he|[[pataá¸¥]]}} |- | colspan="2" |
Example
|- | colspan="2" align="center" style="background:white;height:50px"|{{Hebrew|×“Ö¸Ö¼×’}} |- | colspan="2" style="width:250px;background:white" |
The word for fish in [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]], ''dag''. The only vowel (the two perpendicular lines) is a qamatz.
|- | colspan="2" |
Other [[Niqqud]]
|- | colspan="2" style="width:250px;background:white text-align:center;"|[[Shva|Shwa]]{{Â·}}[[Hiriq]]{{Â·}}[[Tzere]]{{Â·}}[[Segol]]{{Â·}}[[Pataá¸¥]]{{Â·}}Kamatz{{Â·}}[[Holam]]{{Â·}}[[Dagesh]]{{Â·}}[[Mappiq]]{{Â·}}[[Shuruk]]{{Â·}}[[Kubutz]]{{Â·}}[[Rafe]]{{Â·}}[[Shin dot|Sin/Shin Dot]] |} '''Kamatz''' or '''qamatz''' ({{lang-he-n|×§Ö¸×Ö·×¥}}, {{IPA-he|kaËˆmats|IPA}}) is a [[Hebrew alphabet|Hebrew]] [[niqqud]] ([[vowel]]) sign represented by two [[perpendicular]] lines (looking like an [[uppercase]] [[T]]) {{angle bracket|{{Hebrew| ָ }} }} underneath a letter. In [[modern Hebrew]] (Sephardi/Israeli), it usually indicates the [[phoneme]] {{IPAslink|Ã¤|a}} which is close to the "[[a]]" sound in the English word ''f'''a'''r'' and is [[Romanization of Hebrew|transliterated]] as ''a ''. In these cases, its sound is identical to the sound of ''{{transl|he|[[pataá¸¥]] }}'' in [[modern Hebrew]]. In a minority of cases it indicates the phoneme {{IPAslink|oÌ|o}}, equal to the sound of ''{{transl|he|[[holam|á¸¥olam]]}}''. ==Qamatz Qaá¹­an, Qamatz Gadol, á¸¤ataf Qamatz== ===Qamatz Qaá¹­an vs. Qamatz Gadol=== {{anchor|Qamatz Qaá¹­an}}{{anchor|Qamatz Gadol}} The Hebrew of the late centuries BCE and early centuries of the [[Common Era]] had a system with five [[phoneme|phonemic]] long vowels {{IPA|/aË eË iË oË uË/}} and five short vowels {{IPA|/a e i o u/}}. In the later dialects of the 1st millennium CE, phonemic vowel length disappeared, and instead was automatically determined by the context, with vowels pronounced long in [[syllable#open syllable|open syllables]] and short in closed ones. However, the previous vowel phonemes merged in various ways that differed from dialect to dialect: * In [[Tiberian Hebrew]], which underlies the written system of vowels, short {{IPA|/a/}} became {{IPA|[a]}} (indicated by ''{{transl|he|pataá¸¥}}''); long {{IPA|/oË/}} became {{IPA|[o]}} (indicated by ''{{transl|he|[[holam|á¸¥olam]]}}''); while {{IPA|/aË/}} and {{IPA|/o/}} both merged into an in-between sound {{IPA|[É”]}} (similar to the vowel in English "caught" without the [[cot-caught merger]]), which was indicated by qamatz. * In the [[Babylonian vocalization]], however, short and long variants simply merged, with {{IPA|/a/}} and {{IPA|/aË/}} becoming [a], while {{IPA|/o/}} and {{IPA|/oË/}} became [o]; and this system underlies the pronunciation of [[Modern Hebrew]]. The result is that the vowel written with qamatz might be pronounced as either [a] or [o], depending on historical origin. It is often said that the two sounds can be distinguished by context: *The qamatz sound of {{IPA|[o]}}, known as '''{{transl|he|Qamatz Qaá¹­an}}''' ({{lang-he-n|×§Ö¸×Ö·×¥ ×§Ö¸×˜Ö¸×Ÿ}}, {{IPA-he|kaËˆmats kaËˆtan|IPA}}, "small qamatz") occurs in a "closed syllable", i.e. one which ends in a consonant marked with a [[Shva|shwa nakh]] (zero vowel) or with a [[Dagesh#Dagesh á¸¤azak|{{transl|he|dagesh á¸¥azaq}}]] (which indicates that the consonant was pronounced [[gemination|geminated]], i.e. doubled); *The qamatz sound of {{IPA|[a]}}, known as '''{{transl|he|Qamatz Gadol}}''' ({{lang-he-n|×§Ö¸×Ö·×¥ ×’×“×•×œ}} {{IPA-he|kaËˆmats É¡aËˆdol|}}, "big qamatz") occurs in an "open syllable", i.e. any other circumstance: one which ends in a consonant followed by a normal vowel, a consonant at the end of a word and with no vowel marking, or a consonant marked with a [[shva|shwa na]] (originally pronounced {{IPA|[É™]}}). Unfortunately, the two varieties of shwa are written identically, and pronounced identically in Modern Hebrew; as a result, there is no reliable way to distinguish the two varieties of qamatz when followed by a vowel marked with a shwa. (In some cases, Biblical texts are marked with a ''metheg'' or other [[cantillation]] mark that helps to indicate which pronunciation is intended, but this usage is not consistent, and in any case such marks are absent in non-Biblical texts.) An example of the ''qamatz qatan'' is the Modern Hebrew word {{Hebrew|×ªÖ¸Ö¼×›Ö°× Ö´×™×ª}} ({{IPA-he|toÏ‡Ëˆnit|}}, "program"). According to the standard [[Hebrew spelling]] rules as published by the [[Academy of the Hebrew Language]], words which have a qamatz qatan in their base form must be written without a [[Waw (letter)|vav]], hence the standard vowel-less spelling of {{Hebrew|×ªÖ¸Ö¼×›Ö°× Ö´×™×ª}} is {{Hebrew|×ª×›× ×™×ª}}. In practice, however, Modern Hebrew words containing a qamatz qatan do add a ''vav'' {{angle bracket|{{Hebrew|×•}}}} to indicate the {{IPA|[o]}} pronunciation; hence the "nonstandard" spelling {{Hebrew|×ª×•×›× ×™×ª}} is common in newspapers and is even used in several dictionaries, for example [[Rav Milim]]. Words, which in their base form have a [[holam|{{transl|he|á¸¥olam}}]] that changes to {{transl|he|qamatz qaá¹­an}} in declination, retain the ''vav'' in vowel-less spelling: the noun {{Hebrew|×—Ö¹×¤Ö¶×©×}} ({{IPA-he|ËˆÏ‡ofeÊƒ|}}, "freedom") is spelled {{Hebrew|×—×•×¤×©}} in vowel-less texts; the adjective {{Hebrew|×—Ö¸×¤Ö°×©Ö´××™}} ({{IPA-he|Ï‡ofËˆÊƒi|}}, "free") is spelled {{Hebrew|×—×•×¤×©×™}} in vowel-less text, despite the use of qamatz qatan, both according to the standard spelling and in common practice. Some books print the {{transl|he|qamatz qaá¹­an}} differently, although it is not consistent. For example, in siddur [[Rinat Yisrael]] the vertical line of qamatz qatan is longer. In a book of ''[[Psalms]]'' used by some [[Breslov (Hasidic group)|Breslov hassidim]] the qamatz qatan is bolder. In the popular niqqud textbook ''Niqqud halakha le-maase'' by [[Nisan Netser]], the qamatz qatan is printed as an encircled qamatz for didactic purposes. [[Unicode]] defines the code point {{unichar|05C7|HEBREW POINT QAMATS QATAN}}, although its usage is not required. ===á¸¤aá¹­af Qamatz=== '''{{transl|he|á¸¤aá¹­af Qamatz}}''' ({{lang-he-n|×—Ö²×˜Ö·×£ ×§Ö¸×Ö¸×¥|}}, {{IPA-he|Ï‡aËˆtaf kaËˆmats|IPA}}) is a "reduced qamatz". Like qamatz qatan, it is pronounced {{IPAblink|oÌ|o}}, but the rationale for its usage is different: it replaces the [[shva]] on letters which require a shva according to the grammar, but where the traditional pronunciation is {{IPAblink|oÌ|o}}. This mostly happens with gutturals, for example in {{Hebrew|×Ö³×¨Ö¸× Ö´×™×}} ({{IPA-he|oÊaËˆnim|}}, "pines", the plural form of {{Hebrew|×Ö¹×¨Ö¶×Ÿ}}, {{IPA-he|ËˆoÊen|}}), but occasionally also on other letters, for example {{Hebrew|×©Ö³××¨Ö¸×©Ö´××™×}} ({{IPA-he|ÊƒoÊaËˆÊƒim|}}, "roots", the plural of {{Hebrew|×©Ö¹××¨Ö¶×©×}} {{IPA-he|ËˆÊƒoÊeÊƒ|}}) and {{Hebrew|×¦Ö´×¤Ö³Ö¼×¨Ö´×™×}} ({{IPA-he|tsipoËˆÊim|}}, "birds", the plural of {{Hebrew|×¦Ö´×¤Ö¼×•Ö¹×¨}} ({{IPA-he|tsiËˆpoÊ|}}). ==Pronunciation and transliteration== The following table contains the [[pronunciation]] and [[transliteration]] of the different qamatzes in reconstructed historical forms and [[dialect]]s using the [[help:IPA|International Phonetic Alphabet]]. The transcription in IPA is above and the transliteration is below. The short ''o'' ({{transl|he|''qamatz qaá¹­an''}}) and long ''a'' (''qamatz'') have the same ''niqqud''. Because of this, the short ''o'' ({{transl|he|Qamatz Qaá¹­an}}) is usually promoted to a long ''o'' ({{transl|he|''[[holam]] male''}}) in Israeli writing, written as a ''vav'' {{angle bracket|{{Hebrew|×•}}}}, for the sake of disambiguation. pages.text:
{{Infobox Semitic letter |letname = Kaph |previouslink = Yodh |previousletter= Yodh |nextlink = Lamedh |nextletter = Lamedh |archar = {{lang|ar|Ú©, Ùƒ}} |sychar = ÜŸÜŸ |hechar = {{Hebrew|×›, ×š}} |amchar = kaph |gechar = áŠ¨ |phchar = kaph |grchar = Îš |lachar = K |cychar = Ğš |ipa = [[k (IPA)|k]], [[x (IPA)|x]] |num = 11 |gem = 20 }} {{UgariticText}} '''Kaf''' (also spelled '''kaph''') is the eleventh [[Letter (alphabet)|letter]] of the [[Semitic abjads]], including [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician]] KÄp {{Script|Phnx|ğ¤Š}} [[File:Phoenician kaph.svg|12px]], [[Hebrew alphabet|Hebrew]] KÄf {{Script|Hebr|×›}}, [[Aramaic alphabet|Aramaic]] KÄp {{Script|Armi|ğ¡Š}} [[File:Kaph.svg|10 px]], [[Syriac alphabet|Syriac]] KÄpÌ„ {{Script|Syre|ÜŸÜŸ}}, and [[Arabic alphabet|Arabic]] KÄf {{Script|Arab|Ú©}}/{{Script|Arab|Ùƒ}} (in [[Abjadi order]]). The Phoenician letter gave rise to the [[Greek alphabet|Greek]] [[Kappa (letter)|kappa]] (Îš), [[Latin alphabet|Latin]] [[K]], and [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]] [[Ka (Cyrillic)|Ğš]]. ==Origin of kaph== Kaph is thought to be derived from a pictogram of a hand (in both modern [[Arabic]] and [[Hebrew language|modern Hebrew]], '''kaph''' means palm/grip). D46 ==Arabic kÄf== The letter is named ''kÄf'', and it is written in several ways depending on its position in the word. There are three variants of the letter: * the basic form is used for the Arabic language and many other languages: {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Ùƒ}} * the cross-barred form, notably ''{{transl|ar|'al-kÄf al-mashkÅ«lah/al-mashqÅ«qah}}'',{{cite book|last1=Gacek|first1=Adam|title=The Arabic manuscript tradition: a glossary of technical terms and bibliography: supplement|date=2008|publisher=Brill|location=Leiden|isbn=9004165401|page=43|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GfZYCcOL8dYC&pg=PA43}} is used predominantly as an alternative form of the version above in all forms of Arabic and in the languages that use the [[Persian alphabet|Perso-Arabic script]]. {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Ú©}} * the long s-shaped variant form, ''al-kÄf al-mabsÅ«á¹­ah'',{{cite book|last1=Gacek|first1=Adam|title=The Arabic manuscript tradition: a glossary of technical terms and bibliography: supplement|date=2008|publisher=Brill|location=Leiden|isbn=9004165401|page=8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GfZYCcOL8dYC&pg=PA8}} which is used in Arabic texts and for writing the Qur'an. It has a particular use in the [[Sindhi language]] of Pakistan, where it represents the unaspirated /k/, in contrast to the [[Aspiration (phonetics)|aspirated]] /kÊ°/, which is written using the "normal" kÄf {{lang|sd|Ú©}} (called ''[[keheh]]''). {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Úª}} In [[varieties of Arabic]] ''kÄf'' is almost universally pronounced as the [[voiceless velar plosive]] {{IPA|/k/}}, but in [[Palestinian Arabic|rural Palestinian]] and [[Iraqi Arabic|Iraqi]], it is pronounced as a [[voiceless postalveolar affricate]] {{IPA|[tÍ¡Êƒ]}}. In Moroccan Arabic it's pronounced as k, g or ch. ===Use in literary Arabic=== In [[Modern Standard Arabic|Literary Arabic]], ''kÄf'' is used as a prefix meaning ''"like"'', ''"as"'', or ''"as though"''. For example, {{lang|ar|ÙƒÙØ·ÙØ§Ø¦ÙØ±}} ({{IPA|/katË¤aËÊ”ir/}}), meaning "like a bird" or "as though a bird" (as in Hebrew, above). The prefix {{lang|ar|ÙƒÙÙ€}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|ka}}'' is one of the Arabic words for "like" or "as" (the other, {{lang|ar|Ù…ÙØ«Ù’Ù„}} {{IPA|/miÎ¸l/}}, is unrelated). The {{IPA|/ka/}} prefix sometimes has been added to other words to create fixed constructions. For instance, it is prefixed to {{lang|ar|Ø°Ù°Ù„ÙÙƒ}} {{IPA|/Ã°aËlik/}} "this, that" to form the fixed word {{lang|ar|ÙƒÙØ°Ù°Ù„ÙÙƒ}} {{IPA|/kaÃ°aËlik/}} "like so, likewise." ''kÄf'' is used as a [[possessive]] suffix for second-person singular nouns (feminine taking ''{{transl|ar|DIN|kÄf-kasrah}}'' {{lang|ar|ÙƒÙ}}, {{IPA|/ki/}} and masculine ''{{transl|ar|DIN|kÄf-fatá¸¥ah}}'' {{lang|ar|ÙƒÙ}} {{IPA|/ka/}}); for instance, {{lang|ar|ÙƒÙØªÙØ§Ø¨}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|kitÄb}}'' ("book") becomes {{lang|ar|ÙƒÙØªÙØ§Ø¨ÙÙƒÙ}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|kitÄbuka}}'' ("your book", where the person spoken to is masculine) {{lang|ar|ÙƒÙØªÙØ§Ø¨ÙÙƒÙ}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|kitÄbuki}}'' ("your book", where the person spoken to is feminine). At the ends of sentences and often in conversation the final vowel is suppressed, and thus {{lang|ar|ÙƒÙØªÙØ§Ø¨ÙÙƒ}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|kitÄbuk}}'' ("your book"). In several varieties of vernacular Arabic, however, the ''kÄf'' with no [[harakat]] is the standard second-person possessive, with the literary Arabic harakah shifted to the letter ''before'' the ''kÄf'': thus masculine "your book" in these varieties is {{lang|ar|ÙƒÙØªÙØ§Ø¨ÙÙƒ}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|kitÄbak}}'' and feminine "your book" {{lang|ar|ÙƒÙØªÙØ§Ø¨ÙÙƒ}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|kitÄbik}}''. ==Hebrew kaf== {|class=wikitable style="text-align:center;" !colspan=5|[[Orthography|Orthographic]] variants |- !colspan=3|Various print fonts !rowspan=2|[[Cursive Hebrew|Cursive
Hebrew]] !rowspan=2|[[Rashi script|Rashi
script]] |- !|Serif !! [[Sans-serif]] !! [[Monospaced]] |- |width=20%|×› |width=20%|×› |width=20%|×› |width=20%|[[File:Hebrew letter Kaf handwriting.svg|24px]] |width=20%|[[File:Hebrew letter Kaf-nonfinal Rashi.png|35px]] |} Hebrew spelling: {{Hebrew|×›Ö¸Ö¼×£}} ===Hebrew pronunciation=== {{main|Modern Hebrew phonology}} The letter kaf is one of the six letters which can receive a [[dagesh]] kal. The other five are [[Beth (letter)|bet]], [[Gimel (letter)|gimel]], [[daleth]], [[Pe (letter)|pe]], and [[Taw (letter)|tav]] (see [[Hebrew alphabet#Ancient Hebrew|Hebrew Alphabet]] for more about these letters). There are two orthographic variants of this letter which alter the pronunciation: {| class="wikitable" |- !! colspan=1 | Name !! colspan=1 | Symbol !! colspan=1 | [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] !! colspan=1 | [[Transliteration]] !! colspan=1 | Example |- | Kaf | align=center | {{Hebrew|1=×›Ö¼}} | align="center" | {{IPA|[k]}} | align="center" | k | align="center" | '''k'''angaroo |- | Khaf | align=center | {{Hebrew|1=×›}} | align="center" | {{IPAblink|Ï‡}} or {{IPAblink|x}} | align="center" | ch or kh | align="center" | lo'''ch''' |- |} ====Kaf with the dagesh==== When the kaph has a "dot" in its center, known as a [[dagesh]], it represents a [[voiceless velar plosive]] ({{IPA|[k]}}). There are various rules in [[Hebrew grammar]] that stipulate when and why a dagesh is used. ====Kaf without the dagesh (khaf)==== When this letter appears as {{Hebrew|×›}} ''without'' the [[dagesh]] ("dot") in its center it represents {{IPAblink|Ï‡}}, like the ''ch'' in German "Bach". In [[Hebrew language|modern Israeli Hebrew]] the letter [[Heth (letter)|heth]] is often pronounced as a {{IPAblink|Ï‡}}, but many communities have differentiated between these letters as in other Semitic languages. ====Final form of kaf==== {|class=wikitable style="text-align:center;" !colspan=5|[[Orthography|Orthographic]] variants |- !colspan=3|Various Print Fonts !rowspan=2|[[Cursive Hebrew|Cursive
Hebrew]] !rowspan=2|[[Rashi Script|Rashi
script]] |- !|[[Serif]] !! [[Sans-serif]] !! [[Monospace]]d |- |width=20%|×š |width=20%|×š |width=20%|×š |width=20%|[[File:Hebrew letter Kaf-final handwriting.svg|21px]] |width=20%|[[File:Hebrew letter Kaf-final Rashi.png|35px]] |} If the letter is at the end of a word the symbol is drawn differently. However, it does not change the pronunciation or [[transliteration]] in any way. The name for the letter is ''final kaf'' ({{lang|he-Latn|kaf sofit}}). Four additional Hebrew letters take final forms: [[tsade|tsadi]], [[mem]], [[nun (letter)|nun]], and [[pe (letter)|pei]]. Kaf/khaf is the only Hebrew letter that can take a vowel in its word-final form which is pronounced after the consonant, that vowel being the [[niqqud|qamatz]]. {| class="wikitable" |- !! colspan=1 | Name !! colspan=1 | Alternate name !! colspan=1 | Symbol |- | Final kaf | Kaf sofit | align=center | {{Hebrew|1=×šÖ¼}} |- | Final khaf | Khaf sofit | align=center | {{Hebrew|1=×š}} |- |} ===Significance of kaph in Hebrew=== In [[gematria]], kaph represents the number 20. Its final form represents 500, but this is rarely used, [[Tau (letter)|tav]] and [[qoph]] (400+100) being used instead. As a [[Prefix (linguistics)|prefix]], kaph is a [[preposition]]: *It can mean "like" or "as", as in literary Arabic (see below). *In colloquial Hebrew, kaph and [[Shin (letter)|shin]] together have the meaning of "when". This is a contraction of {{Hebrew|×›Ö·Ö¼×Ö²×©Ö¶××¨}}, ''ka'asher'' (when). ==Character encodings== {{charmap |05DB|name1=Hebrew Letter Kaf |05DA|name2=Hebrew Letter Final Kaf |0643|name3=Arabic Letter Kaf/Caf |06A9|name4=Arabic Letter Keheh |071F|name5=Syriac Letter Kaph |06AA|name6=ARABIC LETTER SWASH KAF (Urdu) }} {{charmap |080A|name1=Samaritan Letter Kaaf |1038B|name2=Ugaritic Letter Kaf |1084A|name3=Imperial Aramaic Letter Kaph |1090A|name4=Phoenician Letter Kaf }} == See also == * [[Ca (Indic)]] * [[Gaf]] * [[Ka (Indic)]] * [[Ngaph]] ==References== {{commons category|×›}} {{reflist}} {{Hebrew language}} {{Arabic language}} {{Northwest Semitic abjad}} [[Category:Phoenician alphabet]] [[Category:Arabic letters]] [[Category:Hebrew alphabet]] [[Category:Letters with final form]]

[[Shva]]{{Â·}}[[Hiriq]]{{Â·}}[[Tzere]]{{Â·}}[[Segol]]{{Â·}}[[Patach]]{{Â·}}[[Kamatz]]{{Â·}}[[Holam]]{{Â·}}[[Dagesh]]{{Â·}}[[Mappiq]]{{Â·}}Shuruk{{Â·}}Kubutz{{Â·}}[[Rafe]]{{Â·}}[[Shin dot|Sin/Shin Dot]] |} '''Kubutz''' ({{lang-he-n|×§Ö»×‘Ö¼×•Ö¼×¥}} {{IPA-he|kuËˆbuts|IPA}}) and '''Shuruk''' ({{lang-he-n|×©××•Ö¼×¨×•Ö¼×§}} {{IPA-he|ÊƒuËˆÉ¾uk|IPA}}) are two [[Hebrew alphabet|Hebrew]] [[niqqud]] [[vowel]] signs that represent the sound {{IPA|[u]}}. Kubutz is a short ''u'' and Shuruk is long ''u''.×“×§×“×•×§×™ ××‘×™×¢"×”, a classic work on pronunciation; a summary can be found in the preface in the common Sefardic E"M Siddur ''Avodath Hashem''. In an alternate, Ashkenazi naming, the Kubutz (three diagonal dots) is called "Shuruk" and Shuruk is called "Melopum" ({{Hebrew|××œ××¤×•×}}). ==Appearance== The '''Kubutz''' sign is represented by three diagonal dots "Ö»" underneath a letter. The '''Shuruk''' is the letter Vav with a dot in the middle and to the left of it. The dot is identical to the grammatically different signs [[Dagesh]] and [[Mappiq]], but in a fully vocalized text it is practically impossible to confuse them: Shuruk itself is a vowel sign, so if the letter before the Waw doesn't have its own vowel sign, then the Waw with the dot is a Shuruk and otherwise it is a Waw with a Dagesh or a Mappiq. Furthermore, the Mappiq only appears at the end of the word and only in the letter [[He (letter)|He]] (×”) in modern Hebrew and in the Bible it sometimes appears in [[Aleph]] (×) and only in some Bible manuscripts it appears in the letter Waw, for example in the word ×’ÖµÖ¼×•Ö¼ ('[[torso]]') {{IPA|[É¡ev]}}.{{Cite GHG|8|m|nologo=1}} footnote. In modern Hebrew letter this word is written ×’ÖµÖ¼×•. Compare for example Waw with Dagesh in ×Ö°×’Ö»×•Ö¸Ö¼×Ÿ {{IPA|[mÉ™É¡uvËˆvan]}} 'varied' (without niqqud: ××’×•×•×Ÿ) as opposed to Shuruk in ×Ö´×’Ö¼×•Ö¼×Ÿ {{IPA|[miÉ¡ËˆÉ¡un]}} 'protection' (without niqqud: ××™×’×•×Ÿ); see also [[Waw (letter)#Pronunciation|orthographic variants of Waw]]. ==Name== In older grammar books the Kubbutz is called '''QibbÃ»á¹£ Pum''' etc. (×§Ö´×‘Ö¼×•Ö¼×¥ ×¤Ö¼×•Ö¼×), ''compression ''or'' contraction of the mouth''. This was shortened to '''QibbÃ»á¹£''' (also transliterated as '''Kibbutz''' etc.) but later all the names of vowel signs were changed to include their own sound in their first syllable.{{Cite GHG|8|d|nologo=1}} This way K'''i'''butz changed to K'''u'''butz, and this is the common name today, although the name "Kibutz" is still occasionally used, for example by the Academy of the Hebrew Language.''Academy Decisions: Grammar'', Â§1.3. Shuruk was earlier called '''Shureq''' (×©××•Ö¼×¨Ö¶×§), but this name is rarely used today. ==Usage== ===Shuruk in modern texts=== ''For details on the sounds of Hebrew, see [[Help:IPA/Hebrew]] and [[Modern Hebrew phonology|Hebrew phonology]]'' The Shuruk is used to mark {{IPA|[u]}} at the last syllable of the word and in open syllables in the middle of the word: * ×©Ö¸××Ö°×¨×•Ö¼ ('they guarded') {{IPA|[ÊƒaËˆmÉ™Êu]}} * ×—Ö¸×ª×•Ö¼×œ ('cat') {{IPA|[Ï‡aËˆtul]}} * ×ªÖ°Ö¼×©××•Ö¼×‘Ö¸×” ('answer', ''[[Tshuva]]'') {{IPA|[tÉ™ÊƒuËˆva]}} Regardless of syllable type, Shuruk is always written in foreign words and names if they weren't adapted to Hebrew word structure (''mishkal''): * ××•Ö¼× Ö´×™×‘Ö¶×¨Ö°×¡Ö´×™×˜Ö¸×” ('university') {{IPA|[universita]}} * ×”Ö·×Ö°×‘Ö¼×•Ö¼×¨Ö°×’ ('[[Hamburg]]') {{IPA|[hambuÊÉ¡]}} * ××•Ö¼×§Ö°×¨Ö¸×Ö´×™× Ö¸×” ('[[Ukraine]]') {{IPA|[ukÊaÊ”ina]}} (closed syllable) Differently from all other niqqud signs, a Shuruk can stand on its own in the beginning of the word and not after a consonant when it is the [[Grammatical conjunction|conjunction]] ×•Ö¾ ''and''. Hebrew one-letter words are written together with the next word and their pronunciation may change according to the first letters of that word. The basic vocalization of this conjunction is ''[[Shva na]]'' (×•Ö°Ö¾ {{IPA|[vÉ™]}}), but before the [[labial consonant]]s [[Bet (letter)|Bet]] (×‘), [[Waw (letter)|Waw]] (×•), [[Mem (letter)|Mem]] (×) and [[Pe (letter)|Pe]] (×¤), and before any letter with ''[[Shva]]'' (except [[Yodh]]) it becomes a Shuruk (×•Ö¼Ö¾ {{IPA|[u]}}). This is the consistent vocalization in the Bible{{Cite GHG|26|a|nologo=1}}, {{Cite GHG|104|e|notitle=1}} and in normative modern Hebrew, but in spoken modern Hebrew it is not consistently productive and the conjunction may simply remain ×•Ö°Ö¾ in these cases.{{citation needed|date=January 2009}} It is not reflected in writing without niqqud. Examples: * ×•Ö¼×Ö´×›Ö°×ªÖ¸Ö¼×‘ ('and a letter') {{IPA|[umiÏ‡Ëˆtav]}} * ×•Ö¼×•Ö¶×¨Ö¶×“ ('and a rose') {{IPA|[uËˆveÊed]}} * ×•Ö¼×¡Ö°×¤Ö¸×¨Ö´×™× ('and books') {{IPA|[usÉ™faËˆÊim]}} ===Kubutz in modern texts=== Kubutz is used only in native Hebrew words and in words with foreign roots that were adapted to Hebrew word structure (''mishkal''), for example ×Ö°×¤Ö»×¨Ö°×Ö¸×˜ ('[[Disk formatting|formatted (disk)]]') {{IPA|[mÉ™fuÊËˆmat]}} (without niqqud ××¤×•×¨××˜). It is written in closed syllables which do not appear at the end of the word. A closed syllable is one which ends in a consonant with [[Shva nakh]] (zero vowel) or in a consonant with [[Dagesh khazak]] (essentially two identical consonants, the first of which has Shva nakh). ====Kubutz in base forms of nouns==== Common noun patterns in which Kubutz appears in the base form are:Based on the list of noun patterns (''mishkalim'') in the [[Even-Shoshan Dictionary]]. * /CuCCaC/ where the middle CC is a double consonant (with Dagesh): ×¡Ö»×œÖ¸Ö¼× ('scale') {{IPA|[sulËˆlam]}}, ×Ö»×›Ö¸Ö¼×£ ('saddle') {{IPA|[Ê”ukËˆkaf]}}. Without niqqud: ×¡×•×œ×‎, ××•×›×£. * /CuCCa/: ×—Ö»×œÖ°×“Ö¸Ö¼×” ('rat') {{IPA|[Ï‡ulËˆda]}}, without niqqud: ×—×•×œ×“×”. To this pattern belong also the words whose roots' second and third letter are the same and merge into one consonant with Dagesh: ×¡Ö»×›Ö¸Ö¼×” ('hut', ''[[Sukka]]'') {{IPA|[sukËˆka]}}, root ×¡Ö¾×›Ö¾×›, without niqqud: ×¡×•×›×”. * /CÉ™CuCCa/ where the last CC is a double consonant (with Dagesh): × Ö°×§Ö»×“Ö¸Ö¼×” ('point') {{IPA|[nÉ™qudËˆda]}}. The Dagesh is not realized in modern Hebrew, but if the letter with the Dagesh is [[Bet (letter)|Bet]] (×‘‎), [[Kaph]] (×›‎) or [[Pe (letter)|Pe]] (×¤), then it is pronounced as a [[stop consonant]]: ×›Ö°Ö¼×ªÖ»×‘Ö¸Ö¼×” ('[[Ketubba]]', '[[prenuptial agreement]]') {{IPA|[kÉ™tubËˆba]}}, ×—Ö²× Ö»×›Ö¸Ö¼×” ('[[housewarming]]', [[Hanukka]]) {{IPA|[Ä§anukËˆka]}}.{{IPA|[É™]}} changes to {{IPA|[a]}} on a guttural letter. Without niqqud: × ×§×•×“×”‎, ×—× ×•×›×”. * /CuCCan/: ×©Ö»××œÖ°×—Ö¸×Ÿ ('desk') {{IPA|[ÊƒulËˆÏ‡an]}}, without niqqud: ×©×•×œ×—×Ÿ. * /CuCCoCet/ with Dagesh in the middle letter of the root: ×›Ö»Ö¼×ªÖ¹Ö¼× Ö¶×ª ('coat', 'garment') {{IPA|[kutËˆtonet]}}; with a four letter root: ×’Ö»Ö¼×œÖ°×’Ö¹Ö¼×œÖ¶×ª ('skull') {{IPA|[É¡ulËˆÉ¡olet]}}. Without niqqud: ×›×•×ª×•× ×ª‏, ×’×•×œ×’×•×œ×ª. * /CuCCeCet/: ×›Ö»Ö¼×¡Ö¶Ö¼×Ö¶×ª ('[[spelt]]', '[[buckwheat]]') {{IPA|[kusËˆsemet]}}, ×§Ö»×‘Ö·Ö¼×¢Ö·×ª ('[[goblet]]') {{IPA|[qubËˆbaÊ•at]}}.[[Segol]] changes to [[Patach]] on a guttural letter. Without niqqud: ×›×•×¡××ª‏, ×§×•×‘×¢×ª. ====Kubutz in declined forms of nouns==== Common noun patterns in which Kubutz appears in the declined form are: * Declined forms of words, whose roots' second and third letter are the same, and which have a ''[[Holam]] haser'' in the last syllable of their base form: ×“Ö»Ö¼×‘Ö´Ö¼×™× ('bears') {{IPA|[dubËˆbim]}}, the plural of ×“Ö¹Ö¼×‘ {{IPA|[dov]}}, root ×“Ö¾×‘Ö¾×‘‎; ×›Ö»Ö¼×œÖ¸Ö¼× ('all of them') {{IPA|[kulËˆlam]}}, a declined form of ×›Ö¹Ö¼×œ {{IPA|[kol]}}, root ×›Ö¾×œÖ¾×œ. All these words are written with Waw in texts without niqqud: ×“×•×‘×™×‎, ×“×•×‘‎, ×›×•×œ×‎, ×›×•×œ‎.As an exception, ×›×•×œ is written without Waw when it is in [[construct state]], compare: ×›×œÖ¾×”×× ×©×™× ('all the people'), but ×”×™× ×™×•×“×¢×ª ×”×›×•×œ ('she knows all'). In any case, this is in regard to {{IPA|[o]}}; for {{IPA|[u]}}, there are no exceptions. * Declined forms of words which have the pattern /CaCoC/ in the singular and become /CÉ™CuCCim/ in the plural: ×›Ö¸Ö¼×ªÖ¹× ('orange', {{IPA|[kaËˆtom]}}), pl. ×›Ö°Ö¼×ªÖ»×Ö´Ö¼×™× ({{IPA|[kÉ™tumËˆmim]}}), ×¢Ö¸×’Ö¹×œ ('round', {{IPA|[Ê•aËˆÉ¡ol]}}), pl. ×¢Ö²×’Ö»×œÖ´Ö¼×™× ({{IPA|[Ê•aÉ¡ulËˆlim]}}). Without niqqud: ×›×ª×•×‎, ×›×ª×•××™×‎, ×¢×’×•×œ‎, ×¢×’×•×œ×™×‎. Exception: ×Ö¸×ª×•Ö¹×§ ('sweet', {{IPA|[maËˆtok]}}), pl. ×Ö°×ª×•Ö¼×§Ö´×™× ({{IPA|[mÉ™Ëˆtukim]}}), with Holam gadol and Shuruk and without Dagesh. * Some words, in the base form of which the penultimate syllable has {{IPA|[o]}} and is stressed (sometimes called ''seggolate''), may be written with Kubutz or with ''[[Kamatz]] katan'' when declined. For example, base form: ×Ö·×©Ö°×‚×›Ö¹Ö¼×¨Ö¶×ª (''wage'', {{IPA|[masËˆkoÊet]}}); declined: ×Ö·×©Ö°×‚×›Ö¸Ö¼×¨Ö°×ªÖ¸Ö¼×”Ö¼ {{IPA|[maskoÊËˆtah]}} or ×Ö·×©Ö°×‚×›Ö»Ö¼×¨Ö°×ªÖ¸Ö¼×”Ö¼ {{IPA|[maskuÊËˆtah]}}, both being normative spellings and pronunciations of ''her wage''. Without niqqud, in any case: ××©×›×•×¨×ª‎, ××©×›×•×¨×ª×”. The plural form of words which end in Ö¾×•Ö¼×ª was in the past written with a Kubutz in texts with niqqud: sg. ×—Ö¸× ×•Ö¼×ª ('shop'), {{IPA|[Ä§aËˆnut]}}, pl. ×—Ö²× Ö»×™Ö¼×•Ö¹×ª {{IPA|[Ä§anujËˆjot]}}. In March 2009 the Academy decided to simplify the niqqud of such words by eliminating the Dagesh in the letter [[yodh]] and changing the Kubutz to Shuruk: ×—Ö²× ×•Ö¼×™×•Ö¹×ª‎.[http://hebrew-academy.huji.ac.il/decision3.html#a Summary of meeting 308, March 16, 2009]; ×©×ª×™ ×”×—×œ×˜×•×ª ×‘×“×§×“×•×§. ×“×•×¨×•×Ÿ ×™×¢×§×‘, [http://hebrew-academy.huji.ac.il/sifriyya/akadem/Documents/akad40.pdf ××§×“× â€“ ×™×“×™×¢×•×Ÿ ×”××§×“××™×” ×œ×œ×©×•×Ÿ ×”×¢×‘×¨×™×ª, ×’×™×œ×™×•×Ÿ 40, ×©×‘×˜ ×ª×©"×¢] This doesn't change the pronunciation, since in modern Hebrew the dagesh is not realized anyway. The spelling without niqqud is also unchanged: ×—× ×•×™×•×ª. ====Kubutz in verbs==== Kubutz is common in verbs in the passive [[binyan]]im Pual and Huf'al and in some conjugated forms of verbs whose roots' second and third letters are the same. =====Pual===== Verbs and participles in the passive [[binyan]] Pual usually have a Kubutz in the first letter of the root: ×›Ö»Ö¼× Ö·Ö¼×¡ ('was gathered') {{IPA|[kunËˆnas]}}, ××§Ö»×‘Ö¸Ö¼×œ ('acceptable') {{IPA|[mÉ™qubËˆbal]}}, without niqqud: ×›×•× ×¡‎, ××§×•×‘×œ. If the second letter of the root is one of the [[guttural consonant]]s [[Aleph]] (×), [[He (letter)|He]] (×”), [[Ayin]] (×¢) and [[Resh]] (×¨) - but not [[Heth]] (×—) -, the Kubutz changes to ''holam haser'' in a process called ''tashlum dagesh'' (×ª×©×œ×•× ×“×’×©‎): ×™Ö°×ªÖ¹×Ö·×¨ ('will be described') {{IPA|[yÉ™toËˆÊ”aÊ]}}, ×Ö°×“Ö¹×¨Ö¸×’ ('graded') {{IPA|[mÉ™doËˆÊaÉ¡]}}; without niqqud: ×™×ª×•××¨‎, ××“×•×¨×’. =====Huf'al===== Kubutz is used in the prefixes of verbs and participles in the passive [[binyan]] Huf'al: ×”Ö»×¨Ö°×“Ö·Ö¼× ('was put to sleep') {{IPA|[huÊËˆdam]}}, ×Ö»×¡Ö°×“Ö¸Ö¼×¨ ('organized') {{IPA|[musËˆdaÊ]}}. It is also correct to write words in this binyan with ''[[Kamatz katan]]'' in the prefix: ×”Ö¸×¨Ö°×“Ö·Ö¼×‎, ×Ö¸×¡Ö°×“Ö¸Ö¼×¨ ({{IPA|[hoÊËˆdam]}}, {{IPA|[mosËˆdaÊ]}}).{{Cite GHG|53|b|nologo=1}} Without niqqud, in any case: ×”×•×¨×“×‎, ××•×¡×“×¨. The Kubutz is used only if the prefix is a closed vowel, which is the majority of cases. With some root patterns, however, it becomes an open vowel, in which case a Shuruk is written: * Roots whose first letter is [[Yodh]] (×™‎): ×”×•Ö¼×˜Ö·×‘ ('become better') {{IPA|[huËˆtav]}}, root ×™Ö¾×˜Ö¾×‘‎; ×”×•Ö¼×¨Ö·×“ ('brought down') {{IPA|[huËˆrad]}}, root ×™Ö¾×¨Ö¾×“. * Roots whose middle letter is [[Waw (letter)|Waw]] (×•) or [[Yodh]] (×™‎): ×”×•Ö¼×§Ö·× ('erected') {{IPA|[huËˆqam]}}, root ×§×•×‎; ×”×•Ö¼×‘Ö·×Ÿ ('understood') {{IPA|[huËˆvan]}}, root ×‘×™×Ÿ. * Roots whose second and third letter are the same: ×”×•Ö¼×’Ö·×Ÿ ('protected') {{IPA|[huËˆÉ¡an]}}, root ×’× × . In many roots whose first letter is [[Nun (letter)|Nun]] (× ) and in six roots whose first two letters are [[Yodh]] (×™) and [[Tsade]] (×¦), this letter is assimilated with the second letter of the root, which in turn takes a complementary Dagesh. This makes the syllable of the prefix closed, so accordingly the prefix takes Kubutz: ×”Ö»×¡Ö·Ö¼×¢ ('driven') {{IPA|[husËˆsaÊ•]}}, root × ×¡×¢‎; ×”Ö»×¦Ö·Ö¼×’ ('presented') {{IPA|[hutÍ¡sËˆtÍ¡saÉ¡]}}, root ×™×¦×’. Without niqqud: ×”×•×¡×¢‎, ×”×•×¦×’. =====Double roots===== Kubutz appears in some conjugated forms of verbs with roots whose second and third letter are the same (also called double stems and ×¢"×¢). Most of them are rarely used. Examples with verb ×¡Ö¸×‘Ö·×‘ ('turn') {{IPA|[saËˆvav]}} in the future tense of binyan Qal: * ×Ö²×¡Ö»×‘ÖµÖ¼×šÖ° {{IPA|[asubËˆbeÏ‡]}} (1 sg. with possessive suffix) * ×ªÖ°Ö¼×¡Ö»×‘Ö¶Ö¼×™× Ö¸×” {{IPA|[tÉ™subËˆbena]}} (3 pl. f.) ===In older texts=== In the Bible ''Shuruk'' and ''Kubutz'' are not always used according to the above consistent rules and sometimes quite arbitrarily.{{Cite GHG|8|l|nologo=1}}. For example, in {{bibleverse||Jeremiah|2:19||}} appear the words: ×•Ö¼×Ö°×©Ö»××‘×•Ö¹×ªÖ·×™Ö´×šÖ° ×ªÖ¼×•Ö¹×›Ö´×—Ö»×šÖ° ('and your backslidings shall reprove you', {{IPA|[umÉ™ÊƒuvoËˆtajiÏ‡ toÏ‡iËˆÄ§uÏ‡]}}). Kubutz is used in both of them, even though in the first word the syllable is not closed and the Waw is even a part of this word's root, and in the second word the {{IPA|[u]}} sound is in the last syllable. Contrariwise, a Shuruk is used in closed syllables where a Kubutz would be expected, for example in {{bibleverse||Genesis|2:25||}} - ×¢Ö²×¨×•Ö¼×Ö´Ö¼×™× ('naked', {{IPA|[Ê•arumËˆmim]}}, the plural of ×¢Ö¸×¨Ö¹×, {{IPA|[Ê•aËˆrom]}}), instead of the more regular ×¢Ö²×¨Ö»×Ö´Ö¼×™× (in modern Hebrew without niqqud: ×¢×¨×•××™×). The word × Ö°×Ö»× (''speech'', {{IPA|[nÉ™um]}}) is written with Kubutz in the Bible. It was previously frequently used to mark the signature on documents (e.g. × ×× ×™×•×¡×£ ×œ×•×™ - 'so says Yosef Levi'), but this usage is rare in modern Hebrew, where this word usually means "(a delivered) speech" and is regularly spelled with Shuruk - × Ö°××•Ö¼×. The name ×™Ö°×”×•Ö¹×©Ö»××¢Ö· ('[[Joshua]]', {{IPA|[jÉ™hoËˆÊƒuaÊ•]}}) is spelled with Kubutz in the Bible, but usually ×™Ö°×”×•Ö¹×©××•Ö¼×¢Ö· in modern Hebrew. In the first decades of the [[revival of the Hebrew language]] it was common in spelling without niqqud not to write the Waw in words which were written with Kubutz. For example, in the printed works of [[Eliezer Ben-Yehuda]] the word ××¨×‘×” may mean ×Ö°×¨Ö»×‘Ö¶Ö¼×” ('multiplied', {{IPA|[mÉ™ÊubËˆbe]}}) and ×Ö·×¨Ö°×‘Ö¶Ö¼×” ('multiplying', {{IPA|[maÊËˆbe]}}).There are several other possible readings, but this is enough for the example. This practice disappeared in the middle of twentieth century and now ×Ö°×¨Ö»×‘Ö¶Ö¼×” is written ××¨×•×‘×” and ×Ö·×¨Ö°×‘Ö¶Ö¼×” is written ××¨×‘×”. ==Pronunciation== In Biblical Hebrew both signs may have indicated the same sound and when the Bible manuscripts were vocalized Kubutz was simply used where the letter Waw was not written,Preliminary Remark to {{Cite GHG|8|nologo=1}} although other possibilities were proposed by researchers, most commonly that the vowels had different [[Length (phonetics)|length]] (quantity), Kubutz being shorter,{{Cite GHG|9|n|nologo=1}} or that the signs indicated different sounds (quality), Kubutz being more rounded,{{Cite GHG|9|o|nologo=1}} although this is a matter of debate. It is also possible that Biblical Hebrew had several varieties of {{IPA|[u]}} sounds, which were not consistently represented in writing.[[Chaim Rabin]], 'Short Vowels in Tiberian Hebrew', in ''á¸¤iqre LaÅ¡on'' 1999 (originally published 1961). {{he icon}}. Shuruk is usually a reflection of reconstructed [[Proto-Semitic language|Proto-Semitic]] long {{IPA|/uË/}} (Å«) sound, although most likely in the Bible Kubutz stands for it when the letter Waw is not written. Kubutz is one of the reflections of the short Proto-Semitic short {{IPA|/u/}} (Å­) sound. [[Kamatz Katan]] is a variant of Kubutz in the Bible, as they are found in [[complementary distribution]] in closely related morphological patterns. In modern Hebrew, both signs indicate the [[phoneme]] {{IPA|/u/}}, a [[close back rounded vowel]]. Its closest equivalent in English is the "oo" sound in m'''oo'''n, but the modern Hebrew pronunciation is shorter. It is [[Romanization of Hebrew|transliterated]] as a "u". In modern Hebrew writing without niqqud the {{IPA|/u/}} sound is always written as [[Waw (letter)|Waw]], in which case it is considered a ''[[mater lectionis]]''.
