Å› {{IPA|[É¬]}} | sÌ  | {{script/Arabic|Ø´}} || Å¡ | [[File:Phoenician sin.svg|16px|Å¡]] || Å¡ | {{script/Hebrew|×©×‚}} || s | {{script/Hebrew|×©×‚}} or {{script/Hebrew|×¡}} || s | {{script|Ethi|áˆ }} || Å› |- ! á¹£Ì {{IPA|[É¬Ê¼]}} | á¹£ | {{script/Arabic|Ø¶}} || á¸ | [[File:Phoenician sade.svg|16px|á¹£]] || á¹£ | {{script/Hebrew|×¦}} || á¹£ | {{script/Hebrew|×¢}} || Ê¿ | {{script|Ethi|á€}} || á¹£Ì |- |} ==Arabic Å¡Ä«n/sÄ«n== In the Arabic alphabet, ''{{transl|ar|DIN|Å¡Ä«n}}'' is at the original (21st) position in [[Abjadi order]]. A letter variant {{lang|ar|Ø³}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|sÄ«n}}'' takes the place of [[Samekh]] at 15th position. ''{{transl|ar|DIN|Å Ä«n}}'' represents {{IPA|/Êƒ/}}, and is the 13th letter of the modern alphabet order and is written thus: {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Ø´}} The Arabic letter ''Å¡Ä«n'' was an acronym for "something" ({{lang|ar|Ø´ÙŠØ¡}} ''Å¡ayÊ¾(un)'' {{IPA-ar|ÊƒajÊ”(un)|}}) meaning the unknown in algebraic equations. In the transcription into Spanish, the Greek letter [[Chi (letter)#Greek|''chi'' (Ï‡)]] was used which was later transcribed into Latin ''x''. According to some sources, this is the origin of ''x'' used for the unknown in the equations.[http://www.ted.com/talks/terry_moore_why_is_x_the_unknown.html Terry Moore: Why is 'x' the unknown?][http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?allowed_in_frame=0&search=x&searchmode=none Online Etymological Dictionary] However, according to other sources, there is no historical evidence for this.{{cite book|last=Cajori|first=Florian|title=A History of Mathematical Notation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7juWmvQSTvwC&pg=PA382&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false|publisher=Courier Dover Publications|accessdate=11 October 2012|pages=382â€“383|quote=Nor is there historical evidence to support the statement found in Noah Webster's Dictionary, under the letter x, to the effect that 'x was used as an abbreviation of Ar. shei (a thing), something, which, in the Middle Ages, was used to designate the unknown, and was then prevailingly transcribed as xei.'}}{{cite book |title=Oxford Dictionary |edition=2nd |quote=There is no evidence in support of the hypothesis that x is derived ultimately from the mediaeval transliteration xei of shei "thing", used by the Arabs to denote the unknown quantity, or from the compendium for L. res "thing" or radix "root" (resembling a loosely-written x), used by mediaeval mathematicians.}} In [[Modern Arabic mathematical notation#Mathematical letters|Modern Arabic mathematical notation]], {{lang|ar|Ø³}} ''sÄ«n'', i.e. ''Å¡Ä«n'' [[Rasm|without its dots]], often corresponds to Latin ''x''. In [[Moroccan Arabic]], the letter {{lang|ar|Úœ}}, ''Å¡Ä«n'' with an additional three dots below, is used to transliterate the {{IPAslink|tÍ¡Êƒ}} sound. {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Úœ}} ==Aramaic Shin/Sin {{anchor|Arabic Å¡Ä«n/sÄ«n}}== In [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]], where the use of ''shin'' is well-determined, the orthography of ''sin'' was never fully resolved. To express an etymological /Å›/, a number of dialects chose either ''sin'' or ''samek'' exclusively, where other dialects switch freely between them (often 'leaning' more often towards one or the other). For example:[http://cal1.cn.huc.edu The Comprehensive Aramaic Lexicon] {| class="wikitable" ! ''Ê¿aÅ›ar'' "ten" ! Old Aramaic ! Imperial Aramaic ! Middle Aramaic ! Palestinian Aramaic ! Babylonian Aramaic |- | {{Hebrew|×¢×©×¨}} | Syrian Inscriptions | Idumaean Ostraca, Egyptian, Egyptian-Persian, Ezra | Qumran | Galilean | Gaonic, Jewish Babylonian Aramaic |- | {{Hebrew|×¢×¡×¨}} | Tell Halaf | ''(none recorded)'' | Palmyrene, Syriac | Zoar, [[Christian Palestinian Aramaic]] | Mandaic |- | both | ''(none recorded)'' | ''(none recorded)'' | ''(none recorded)'' | Targum Jehonathan, Original Manuscript Archival Texts, Palestinian Targum (Genizah), Samaritan | Late Jewish Literary Aramaic |} Regardless of how it is written, /Å›/ in spoken Aramaic seems to have universally resolved to /s/. ==Hebrew Shin / Sin== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" ! colspan="5" |[[Orthography|Orthographic]] variants |- ! colspan="3" |Various print fonts ! rowspan="2" |[[Cursive Hebrew|Cursive
Hebrew]] ! rowspan="2" |[[Rashi script|Rashi
script]] |- !|Serif !! [[Sans-serif]] !! [[Monospaced font|Monospaced]] |- | width="20%" |×© | width="20%" |×© | width="20%" |×© | width="20%" |[[File:Hebrew letter Shin handwriting.svg|28px]] | width="20%" |[[File:Hebrew letter Shin Rashi.png|40px]] |} Hebrew spelling: {{lang|he|×©Ö´××™×Ÿ}} The Hebrew {{IPA|/s/}} version according to the reconstruction shown above is descended from Proto-Semitic *{{transl|sem|Å›}}, a [[phoneme]] thought to correspond to a [[voiceless alveolar lateral fricative]] {{IPA|/É¬/}}, similar to Welsh ''Ll'' in "Llandudno". See also [[Biblical Hebrew phonology|Hebrew phonology]], [[Åšawt]]. ===Sin and Shin Dot=== {| class="infobox bordered" style="text-align: center; width: 250px" ! colspan="2" | Sin and Shin dot |- | colspan="2" style="height: 60px" |
{{script/Hebrew|×©× ×©×‚}} |- | [[Help:IPA/Hebrew|IPA]] | {{IPA link|s}}, {{IPA link|Êƒ}} |- | [[Romanization of Hebrew|Transliteration]] | s, sh |- | English example | '''s'''ought, '''sh'''ot |- | colspan="2" | Sin Dot |- | colspan="2" | {{Hebrew|1= ×™Ö´×©Ö°×‚×¨Ö¸×Öµ×œ }} |- | colspan="2" | The word Israel in [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]], ''Yisrael''. The upper left hand dot on the Sin is a Sin dot. |- | colspan="2" | Shin Dot |- | colspan="2" | {{script/Hebrew|1= ×™Öµ×©× }} |- | colspan="2" | The [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] word '''''yesh''''', ''there is''. The upper right hand dot on the Shin is a Shin dot. |- | colspan="2" | Other [[niqqud]] |- | colspan="2" | [[Shva]]{{,}} [[Hiriq]]{{,}} [[Zeire]]{{,}} [[Segol]]{{,}} [[Patach]]{{,}} [[Kamatz]]{{,}} [[Holam]]{{,}} [[Dagesh]]{{,}} [[Mappiq]]{{,}} [[Kubutz|Shuruk]]{{,}} [[Kubutz]]{{,}} [[Rafe]]{{,}} Sin/Shin Dot |} The Hebrew letter represents two different phonemes: a [[sibilant]] {{IPAslink|s}}, like English '''s'''our, and a {{IPAslink|Êƒ}}, like English '''sh'''oe. The two are distinguished by a dot above the left-hand side of the letter for {{IPAslink|s}} and above the right-hand side for {{IPAslink|Êƒ}}. In the biblical name [[Issachar]] ({{lang-he-n|×™Ö´×©Ö¸Ö¼×‚×©×›Ö¸×¨}}) only, the second sin/shin letter is always written without any dot, even in fully vocalized texts. This is because the second sin/shin is always silent. {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="1" ! | Name ! colspan="1" ! | Symbol ! colspan="1" ! | [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] ! colspan="1" ! | [[Transliteration]] ! colspan="1" ! | Example |- | Sin dot (left) | align="center" | {{Hebrew|1=×©×‚}} | align="center" | {{IPAslink|s}} | align="center" | s | align="center" | '''s'''our |- | Shin dot (right) | align="center" | {{Hebrew|1=×©×}} | align="center" | {{IPAslink|Êƒ}} | align="center" | sh | align="center" | '''sh'''op |- |} ===Unicode encoding=== {| class="wikitable" ! Glyph ! Unicode ! Name |- | {{Hebrew|1=ׁ}} |U+05C1 |SHIN DOT |- | {{Hebrew|1=ׂ}} |U+05C2 |SIN DOT |} ===Significance=== In [[gematria]], Shin represents the number 300. Shin, as a [[Prefix (linguistics)|prefix]], bears the same meaning as the [[relative pronoun]]s "that", "which" and "who" in English. In colloquial Hebrew, [[Kaph]] and Shin together have the meaning of "when". This is a contraction of {{lang|he|×›Ö¼××©×¨}}, ''ka'asher'' (as, when). Shin is also one of the seven letters which receive special crowns (called ''[[Tag (Hebrew writing)|tagin]]'') when written in a [[Sefer Torah]]. See [[Gimmel]], [[Ayin]], [[Teth]], [[Nun (letter)|Nun]], [[Zayin]], and [[Tzade|Tzadi]]. According to [[Book of Judges|Judges]] 12:6, the tribe of [[Ephraim]] could not differentiate between Shin and [[Samekh]]; when the [[Gilead]]ites were at war with the [[Ephraimite]]s, they would ask suspected Ephraimites to say the word '''''shi'''bolet''; an Ephraimite would say '''''si'''bolet'' and thus be exposed. From this episode we get the English word [[shibboleth]]. ====In Judaism==== Shin also stands for the word [[El Shaddai|Shaddai]], a name for God. Because of this, a [[kohen]] (priest) forms the letter Shin with his hands as he recites the [[Priestly Blessing]]. In the mid 1960s, actor [[Leonard Nimoy]] used a single-handed version of this gesture to create the [[Vulcan salute|Vulcan hand salute]] for his character, [[Mr. Spock]], on ''[[Star Trek: The Original Series|Star Trek]]''.[[Star Trek: The Original Series]], episode #30 "[[Amok Time]]" (production #34), and ''[[I Am Not Spock]]'', [[Leonard Nimoy]], 1977.{{cite AV media |people=Nimoy, Leonard (Narrator) |date=February 6, 2014 |title=Live Long and Prosper: The Jewish Story Behind Spock, Leonard Nimoy's Star Trek Character |medium= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DyiWkWcR86I |access-date=February 27, 2015 |publisher=Yiddish Book Center }} The letter Shin is often inscribed on the case containing a [[mezuzah]], a scroll of parchment with Biblical text written on it. The text contained in the mezuzah is the [[Shema Yisrael]] prayer, which calls the Israelites to love their God with all their heart, soul and strength. The mezuzah is situated upon all the doorframes in a home or establishment. Sometimes the whole word ''Shaddai'' will be written. The Shema Yisrael prayer also commands the Israelites to write God's commandments on their hearts (Deut. 6:6); the shape of the letter Shin mimics the structure of the human [[heart]]: the lower, larger left [[Ventricle (heart)|ventricle]] (which supplies the full body) and the smaller right ventricle (which supplies the lungs) are positioned like the lines of the letter Shin. A religious significance has been applied to the fact that there are three valleys that comprise the city of Jerusalem's geography: the Valley of Ben Hinnom, Tyropoeon Valley, and [[Kidron Valley]], and that these valleys converge to also form the shape of the letter shin, and that the [[Temple in Jerusalem]] is located where the dagesh (horizontal line) is. This is seen as a fulfillment of passages such as Deuteronomy 16:2 that instructs Jews to celebrate the Pasach at "the place the LORD will choose as a dwelling for his Name" (NIV). In the [[Sefer Yetzirah]] the letter Shin is King over Fire, Formed Heaven in the Universe, Hot in the Year, and the Head in the Soul. The 13th-century Kabbalistic text Sefer HaTemunah, holds that a single letter of unknown pronunciation, held by some to be the four-pronged shin on one side of the [[teffilin]] box, is missing from the current alphabet. The world's flaws, the book teaches, are related to the absence of this letter, the eventual revelation of which will repair the universe. ==== In Russian ==== [[File:Cyrillic letter Sha - uppercase and lowercase.svg|thumb|The [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]] letter "[[Sha (Cyrillic)|sha]]" is sometimes said to derive from the Hebrew letter ''shin'', showing how both letters are nearly identical.]] The corresponding letter for the {{IPAslink|Êƒ}} sound in [[Russian language|Russian]] is nearly identical in shape to the Hebrew ''shin''. Given that the [[Cyrillic script]] includes borrowed letters from a variety of different alphabets such as [[Greek alphabet|Greek]] and [[Latin alphabet|Latin]], it is often suggested that the letter ''[[Sha (Cyrillic)|sha]]'' is directly borrowed from the Hebrew letter ''shin'' (other hypothesized sources include [[Coptic alphabet|Coptic]] and [[Samaritan alphabet|Samaritan]]). ====Sayings with Shin==== The '''Shin-[[Bet (letter)|Bet]]''' was an old acronym for the Israeli [[Shin Bet|Department of Internal General Security]]. A '''Shin-Shin Clash''' is [[Israel Defense Forces|Israeli military]] parlance for a battle between two tank divisions ("armour" in Hebrew is ×©Ö´××¨Ö°×™×•Ö¹×Ÿ - ''shiryon''). '''Sh'at haShin''' (the Shin hour) is the last possible moment for any action, usually military. Corresponds to the English expression ''the eleventh hour''. ==Character encodings== {{charmap |05E9|name1=Hebrew Letter Shin |0633|name2=Arabic Letter Seen |0634|name3=Arabic Letter Sheen |072B|name4=Syriac Letter Shin |FB2A|name5=Hebrew Letter Shin With Shin Dot |FB2B|name6=Hebrew Letter Shin With Sin Dot |FB2C|name7=Hebrew Letter Shin With Dagesh And Shin Dot |FB2D|name8=Hebrew Letter Shin With Dagesh And Sin Dot }} {{charmap |0814|name1=Samaritan Letter Shan |10398|name2=Ugaritic Letter Shen |10854|name3=Imperial Aramaic Letter Shin |10914|name4=Phoenician Letter Shin }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|×©}} {{Arabic language}} {{Hebrew language}} {{Northwest Semitic abjad}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Shin (Letter)}} [[Category:Phoenician alphabet]] [[Category:Arabic letters]] [[Category:Hebrew alphabet]]

This offers no conclusive indication as to its pronunciation in Modern Hebrew; it is however relevant to the application of standard [[niqqud]], e.g.: a ×‘×’×´×“ ×›×¤×´×ª letter following a letter marked with a shva nacá¸¥ must be marked with a [[Dagesh#Dagesh Kal|dagesh qal]] (Modern Hebrew [[phonology]] sometimes disagrees with this [[linguistic prescription]], as in ×œÖ°×¤Ö·×¡Ö°×¤Öµ×¡ â€“ "to miss" â€“ in which the second [[Pe (letter)|pe]] lacks a dagesh qal although preceded by a shva naá¸¥), or: the vowel preceding a letter marked with a shva naá¸¥ must be represented by the "short" niqqud-variant for that vowel: [[patah|pataá¸¥ and not]] [[Kamatz|qamats]], [[segol]] and not [[tsere]] etc.{{ref label|long-short-variants|â†‘|}}. Furthermore, in standard [[syllabification]], the letter under which a shva naá¸¥ is marked is grouped with the preceding syllable. The [[Academy of the Hebrew Language]]'s transliteration guidelines specify that shva naá¸¥ should not be represented in transliteration. === Shva Meraá¸¥ef === "Shva meraá¸¥ef" is the grammatical designation of a shva which does not comply with all criteria characterizing a shva na (specifically, one marked under a letter following a letter marked with a "short", not a "long", niqqud-variant{{ref label|long-short-variants|â†‘|}}), but which does, like a shva na, supersede a vowel (or a shva na) that exists in the basic form of a word but not after this word underwent [[inflection]] or [[declension]]. The classification of a shva as "shva meraá¸¥ef" is relevant to the application of standard [[niqqud]], e.g.: a ×‘×’×´×“ ×›×¤×´×ª letter following a letter marked with a shva meraá¸¥ef should not be marked with a [[Dagesh#Dagesh Kal|dagesh qal]], although the vowel preceding this letter could be represented by the "short" niqqud-variant for that vowel.{{ref label|long-short-variants|â†‘|}} This reflects sometimes, but not always, pronunciation in Modern Hebrew, e.g. ×Ö·×œÖ°×›Öµ×™ ("kings of") is commonly pronounced in accordance with the standard form, {{IPA|/malËˆÏ‡ej/}} (with no dagesh qal in the letter [[Kaph|kaf]]), whereas ×›Ö·Ö¼×œÖ°×‘Öµ×™ ("dogs of"), whose standard pronunciation is {{IPA|/kalËˆvej/}}, is commonly pronounced {{IPA|/kalËˆbej/}} (as if there were a dagesh qal in the letter [[Bet (letter)|bet]]). In standard [[syllabification]], the letter under which a shva meraá¸¥ef is marked is grouped with the preceding syllable. === Shva Ga'ya === [[File:Gaâ€˜yÃ¡.png|thumb|The word /vÉ™nÄ'Å¡Å«á¸‡Ä/ in ''[[Book of Lamentations|Ekhah]]'' (Lamentations) 5:21. The ga'ja in the word (marked in red) renders the shva stressed. In the [[Spanish and Portuguese Jews|Spanish and Portuguese]] [[Sephardim|Sephardic]] tradition, the pronunciation is ['vanÄ'Å¡Å«á¸‡Ä].]] "Shva Ga'ya" designates a shva marked under a letter that is also marked with the [[cantillation]] mark "[[Meteg|ga'ya]]" ({{Hebrew|×’Ö·Ö¼×¢Ö°×™Ö¸×”}} lit. "bleating" or "bellowing"){{rp|22-23}}, or "meteg", e.g. the shva under the letter [[Bet (letter)|bet]] in the word ×‘Ö°Ö¼×”×•Ö¹× ×•Ö¹×ª ("toes") would normally be classified a shva na and be transliterated "e": "behonÃ³t" (or according to the precise standard, "Ä•": "bÄ•honÃ³t"), however, if marked with the ga'ya cantillation mark, [[File:Shwa-gaja.jpg|50px]], this shva is classified as shva ga'ya, and the transliteration reflecting its historical pronunciation would be "bohonÃ³t". For more on the strict application of the Shva Ga'ya, see {{main article|Yemenite Hebrew#Strict Application of Mobile ShewÄ}}. ==T'nua hatufa== Within [[niqqud]], vowel [[Hebrew diacritics|diacritics]] are sorted into three groups: "big", "small" and "fleeting" or "furtive" ("T'nuot g'dolot" â€“ "×’×“×•×œ×•×ª", "T'nuot k'tanot" â€“ "×§×˜× ×•×ª" and "T'nuot chatufot" "×—×˜×•×¤×•×ª"), sometimes also referred to as "long", "short" and "very short" or "ultrashort". This grouping might have correlated to different [[vowel length]]s in earlier forms of Hebrew (see [[Tiberian vocalization#Vowels|Tiberian vocalization â†’ Vowels]]; spoken Israeli Hebrew however does not distinguish between different vowel lengths, thus this orthographic differentiation is not manifest in speech). The vowel diacritics classified as "chatufot" ("fleeting") all share the common feature of being a [[Digraph (orthography)|digraph]] of a "small vowel" diacritic ([[patah|Patach]], [[Segol]] or [[Kamatz Katan]]) plus a shva sign. Similarly, their names are derived from the respective "small vowel" diacritic's name plus the [[Noun adjunct|adjunct]] "chataf": "chataf patach", "chataf segol" and "chataf kamatz". As with a shva na, standard ([[Linguistic prescription|prescribed]]) [[syllabification]] determines that letters [[Niqqud|pointed]] with a "fleeting vowel" diacritic be considered part of the subsequent [[syllable]], even if in modern Hebrew pronunciation this diacritic represents a full-fledged syllable, thus e.g. the [[phonology|phonologically]] trisyllabic word "×”Ö¶×¢Ö±×Ö´×™×“" ("he placed upright"), pronounced {{IPA|/he.eËˆmid/}}, should [[standard language|standardly]] be syllabified into only two syllables, "×”Ö¶â€”×¢Ö±×Ö´×™×“" ("he'emid"). {| class="wikitable" |- !! rowspan=2 | Name !! rowspan=2 | Symbol !! colspan=3 |[[Israeli Hebrew]] |- !! colspan=1 | [[Help:IPA chart for Hebrew|IPA]] !! colspan=1 | [[Transliteration]] !! colspan=1 | English

{{about|the Semitic letter}} {{Phoenician glyph|letname=Taw|previouslink=Shin (letter)|previousletter=Shin|nextlink=á¹®ÄÊ¾|nextletter=á¹®ÄÊ¾|archar=Øª|sychar= Ü¬|hechar= ×ª|amchar=Taw|gechar=á‰°|phch×š×¤ar=taw|grchar=Î¤|lachar=T|cychar=Ğ¢|ipa=t (also Î¸, s)|num=22|gem=400}} '''Taw''', '''tav''', or '''taf''' is the twenty-second and last [[Letter (alphabet)|letter]] of the [[Semitic abjads]], including [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician]] TÄw [[File:Phoenician_taw.svg|12px]], [[Hebrew alphabet|Hebrew]] Tav {{script|Hebr|×ª}}, [[Aramaic alphabet|Aramaic]] Taw [[File:Taw.svg| 10 px]], [[Syriac alphabet|Syriac]] Taw Ü¬, and [[Arabic script|Arabic]] Øª [[TÄÊ¼]] (22nd in [[abjadi order]], 3rd in modern order). In Arabic, it is also gives rise to the derived letter Ø« [[á¹®ÄÊ¼]]. Its original sound value is {{IPAslink|t}}. The Phoenician letter gave rise to the [[Greek alphabet|Greek]] ''[[tau]]'' (Î¤), [[Latin alphabet|Latin]] [[T]], and [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]] [[Te (Cyrillic)|Ğ¢]]. ==Origins of taw== Taw is believed to be derived from the [[Egyptian hieroglyph]] meaning "mark" Z9 {| class=wikitable style="text-align: center;" |- ! [[Egyptian hieroglyphs|Hieroglyph]] ! [[Proto-Sinaitic script|Proto-Sinaitic]] ! [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician]] ! [[Paleo-Hebrew alphabet|Paleo-Hebrew]] |- | align="center" | Z9 | align="center" | [[File:Proto-Canaanite_-_tof.png]] | align="center" | [[File:Phoenician_taw.svg|30px]] | align="center" | [[File:Early_Aramaic_character_-_tof.png]] |} ==Arabic tÄÊ¼== {{Refimprove | date = February 2013 }} The letter is named ''{{transl|ar|ALA|tÄÊ¼ }}''. It is written in several ways depending on its position in the word: {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Øª}} Final {{lang|ar| Ù€ÙØªÙ’ }} (''[[fathah]]'', then {{transl|ar|ALA|tÄÊ¼ }} with a [[sukun]] on it, [[Arabic phonology|pronounced]] {{IPA|/at/}}, though diacritics are normally omitted) is used to mark feminine gender for third-person [[perfective aspect|perfective]]/[[past tense]] verbs, while final {{lang|ar| ØªÙ }} ({{transl|ar|ALA|tÄÊ¼-fatá¸¥ah}}, {{IPA|/ta/}}) is used to mark past-tense second-person singular masculine verbs, final {{lang|ar| ØªÙ }} ({{transl|ar|ALA|tÄÊ¼-kasrah}}, {{IPA|/ti/}}) to mark past-tense second-person singular feminine verbs, and final {{lang|ar| ØªÙ }} ({{transl|ar|ALA|tÄÊ¼-[[damma|á¸ammah]]}}, {{IPA|/tu/}}) to mark past-tense first-person singular verbs. The plural form of Arabic letter {{lang|ar|Øª }} is ''{{transl|ar|ALA|tÄÊ¼Ät}}'' ({{lang|ar|ØªØ§Ø¡Ø§Øª}}), a [[palindrome]]. Recently the isolated {{lang|ar| Øª }} has been used online as an [[emoticon]], because it resembles a smiling face.{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}} ===TÄÊ¼ marbÅ«á¹­ah=== An alternative form called ''{{transl|ar|ALA|tÄÊ¼ marbÅ«á¹­ah}}'' ({{Lang|ar|ØªØ§Ø¡ Ù…Ø±Ø¨ÙˆØ·Ø©}}, "bound ''{{transl|ar|DIN|tÄÊ¼ }}''") is used at the end of words to mark [[grammatical gender|feminine gender]] for [[noun]]s and [[adjective]]s. In [[Modern Standard Arabic]], it denotes {{IPA|/-a/}} or {{IPA|/-at/}}. Regular ''{{transl|ar|ALA|tÄÊ¼}}'', to distinguish it from ''{{transl|ar|ALA|tÄÊ¼ marbÅ«á¹­ah}}'', is referred to as ''{{transl|ar|ALA|tÄÊ¼ maftÅ«á¸¥ah}}'' ({{Lang|ar|ØªØ§Ø¡ Ù…ÙØªÙˆØ­Ø©}}, "open ''{{transl|ar|ALA|tÄÊ¼ }}''"). {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Ø©}} In words such as ''{{transl|ar|ALA|risÄlah}}'' {{Lang|ar|Ø±Ø³Ø§Ù„Ø©}} ('letter, message'), ''{{Transl|ar|ALA|tÄÊ¼ marbÅ«á¹­ah}}'' is denoted as ''{{transl|ar|ALA|h}}'', and pronounced as {{IPA|/-a/}}. When a word ending with a tÄÊ¼ marbÅ«á¹­ah is suffixed with a [[Ê¾IÊ¿rab#Types of declension|grammatical case ending]] or (in Modern Standard Arabic or the dialects) any other suffix, the {{IPA|/t/}} is clearly pronounced. For example, the word {{lang|ar|Ø±Ø³Ø§Ù„Ø©}} ('letter, message') is pronounced as ''{{transl|ar|Wehr|risÄla}}'' in [[pausa]] but is pronounced ''{{transl|ar|risÄlatu}}'' in the nominative case ({{IPA|/u/}} being the nominative case ending). The pronunciation is {{IPA|/t/}}, just like a regular ''{{Transl|ar|ALA|tÄÊ¼ }}'' ({{Lang|ar|Øª}}), but the identity of the "character" remains a ''{{Transl|ar|ALA|tÄÊ¼ marbÅ«á¹­ah}}''. Note that the isolated and final forms of this letter combine the shape of ''{{Transl|ar|ALA|hÄÊ¼ }}'' and the two dots of ''{{Transl|ar|ALA|tÄÊ¼ }}''. When words containing the symbol are borrowed into other languages written in the Arabic alphabet (such as [[Persian language|Persian]]), ''{{Transl|ar|ALA|tÄÊ¼ marbÅ«á¹­ah}}'' usually becomes either a regular {{lang|ar|[[Ù‡]]}} or a regular {{lang|ar|Øª}}. ==Hebrew tav== {|class=wikitable style="text-align:center;" !colspan=5|[[Orthography|Orthographic]] variants |- !colspan=3|Various print fonts !rowspan=2|[[Cursive Hebrew|Cursive
Hebrew]] !rowspan=2|[[Rashi script|Rashi
script]] |- !|Serif !! [[Sans-serif]] !! [[Monospaced]] |- |width=20%|×ª |width=20%|×ª |width=20%|×ª |width=20%|[[File:Hebrew letter Taf handwriting.svg|26px]] |width=20%|[[File:Hebrew letter Taf Rashi.png|40px]] |} Hebrew spelling: {{lang|he|×ªÖ¸×•}} ===Hebrew pronunciation=== The letter ''tav'' in modern Hebrew usually represents a [[voiceless alveolar plosive]]: {{IPA|/t/}}. ==== Variations on written form and pronunciation ==== The letter ''tav'' is one of the six letters that can receive a [[dagesh kal]] diacritic; the others are [[beth (letter)|bet]], [[gimel]], [[dalet]], [[kaph]] and [[pe (letter)|pe]]. Bet, kaph and pe have their sound values changed in modern Hebrew from the fricative to the plosive, by adding a dagesh. In modern Hebrew, the other three do not change their pronunciation with or without a dagesh, but they have had alternate pronunciations at other times and places. In traditional [[Ashkenazi]] pronunciation, tav represents an {{IPA|/s/}} without the [[dagesh]] and has the plosive form when it has the dagesh. Among [[Yemenite Jews|Yemen]] and some [[Sephardi]] areas, tav without a dagesh represented a [[voiceless dental fricative]] {{IPA|/Î¸/}} - a pronunciation hailed by the [[Bension Kohen|Sfath Emeth]] work as wholly authentic, while the tav with the dagesh is the plosive {{IPA|/t/}}. In traditional [[Italian Jews|Italian]] pronunciation, tav without a dagesh is sometimes {{IPA|/d/}}.{{clarify|date=February 2017}} ===Significance of tav=== In [[gematria#Values table|gematria]], tav represents the number 400, the largest single number that can be represented without using the ''sophit'' (final) forms (see [[kaph]], [[mem]], [[nun (letter)|nun]], [[Pe (letter)|pe]], and [[tzade]]). In representing names from foreign languages, a ''[[Hebrew numerals#Gershayim|geresh]]'' or ''chupchik'' can also be placed after the tav ({{lang|he|×ª×³}}), making it represent {{IPAslink|Î¸}}. (See also: [[Hebraization of English]]) ====In Judaism==== Tav is the last letter of the Hebrew word ''emet'', which means '[[truth]]'. The [[midrash]] explains that ''emet'' is made up of the first, middle, and last letters of the [[Hebrew alphabet]] ([[aleph]], [[mem]], and tav: {{lang|he|×××ª}}). ''Sheqer'' (×©×§×¨, falsehood), on the other hand, is made up of the 19th, 20th, and 21st (and penultimate) letters. Thus, truth is all-encompassing, while falsehood is narrow and deceiving. In [[Jewish mythology]] it was the word ''emet'' that was carved into the head of the [[golem]] which ultimately gave it life. But when the letter ''aleph'' was erased from the golem's forehead, what was left was "''met''"â€”dead. And so the golem died. [[Book of Ezekiel|Ezekiel]] 9:4 depicts a vision in which the ''tav'' plays a [[Passover]] role similar to the blood on the lintel and doorposts of a Hebrew home in Egypt.''Exodus'' 12:7,12. In Ezekielâ€™s vision, the Lord has his angels separate the demographic wheat from the chaff by going through Jerusalem, the capital city of ancient Israel, and inscribing a mark, a tav, â€œupon the foreheads of the men that sigh and that cry for all the abominations that be done in the midst thereof.â€ In Ezekiel's vision, then, the Lord is counting tav-marked Israelites as worthwhile to spare, but counts the people worthy of annihilation who lack the tav and the critical attitude it signifies. In other words, looking askance at a culture marked by dire moral decline is a kind of [[shibboleth]] for loyalty and zeal for God.Cf. the New Testament's condemnation of lukewarmness in ''Revelation'' 3:15-16 ====Sayings with taf==== "From aleph to taf" describes something from beginning to end, the Hebrew equivalent of the English "From A to Z." ==Syriac taw== In the [[Syriac alphabet]], as in the Hebrew and Phoenician alphabets, taw ({{lang|syc|Ü¬}}) is the last letter in the alphabet. It represents either {{IPA|/t/}} ([[voiceless alveolar plosive]]) or between a {{IPA|/t/}} and {{IPA|/d/}} sound. {|class=wikitable style="text-align:center;" !{{transl|syc|Esá¹­rangelÄ}}
